814<article>

815

816 <div class="resize-content">

817

818 <h1>

819Genetics of Breast and Gynecologic Cancers (PDQ)Health Professional Version</h1>

820

821 <div id="cgvBody">

822

823 <div class="summary-sections">

824

825 <nav class="on-this-page" role="navigation">

826

827 <h6>

828On This Page</h6>

829

830 <ul>

831

832 <li>

833<a href="#_2946">

834Executive Summary</a>

835</li>

836

837 <li>

838<a href="#_1">

839Introduction</a>

840</li>

841

842 <li>

843<a href="#_2730">

844Penetrance of Inherited Susceptibility to Hereditary Breast and/or Gynecologic Cancers</a>

845</li>

846

847 <li>

848<a href="#_3165">

849Genes Associated With Breast and/or Gynecologic Cancer Susceptibility</a>

850</li>

851

852 <li>

853<a href="#_88">

854High-Penetrance Breast and/or Gynecologic Cancer Susceptibility Genes</a>

855</li>

856

857 <li>

858<a href="#_156">

859Moderate-Penetrance Genes Associated With Breast and/or Gynecologic Cancers</a>

860</li>

861

862 <li>

863<a href="#_2857">

864Single Nucleotide VariantAssociated Cancer Risks</a>

865</li>

866

867 <li>

868<a href="#_2742">

869Clinical Management of Hereditary Breast and/or Gynecologic Cancer Syndromes</a>

870</li>

871

872 <li>

873<a href="#_271">

874Psychosocial Issues in Hereditary Breast and Gynecologic Cancers</a>

875</li>

876

877 <li>

878<a href="#_589">

879Changes to This Summary (03/10/2023)</a>

880</li>

881

882 <li>

883<a href="#_AboutThis_1">

884About This PDQ Summary</a>

885</li>

886

887 </ul>

888

889</nav>

890

891

892 <div class="accordion">

893

894

895

896 <section id="_2946">

897

898 <h2>

899Executive Summary</h2>

900

901 <div id="_section_2946" class="pdq-sections">

902<p id="_2923" tabindex="-1">

903This executive summary reviews the topics covered in this PDQ summary on the genetics of breast and gynecologic cancers.</p>

904<div class="pdq-content-list">

905<ul id="_2924">

906<li>

907<strong>

908Inheritance and Risk</strong>

909<p id="_2925" tabindex="-1">

910Factors suggestive of a <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_4">

911genetic contribution to both breast cancer and gynecologic cancer</a>

912 include 1) an increased incidence of these cancers among individuals with a family history of these cancers; 2) multiple family members affected with these and other cancers; and 3) a pattern of cancers compatible with autosomal dominant inheritance. Both males and females can inherit and transmit an autosomal dominant cancer predisposition gene. </p>

913<p id="_2941" tabindex="-1">

914Additional factors coupled with family history can influence an individual's risk of developing cancer&#8212;such as <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_339">

915reproductive history</a>

916, <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_340">

917 contraceptive</a>

918 and <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_1055">

919hormone replacement use</a>

920, <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_341">

921radiation exposure</a>

922 early in life, <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_342">

923alcohol consumption and smoking</a>

924, and <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_1583">

925physical activity</a>

926.</p>

927<p id="_2928" tabindex="-1">

928Risk assessment models have been developed to clarify an individual's 1) <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_66">

929lifetime risk of developing breast and/or gynecologic cancer</a>

930; 2) <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_3794">

931likelihood of having a pathogenic variant in <em class="gene-name">

932BRCA1</em>

933 or <em class="gene-name">

934BRCA2</em>

935</a>

936; and 3) <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2832">

937likelihood of having a pathogenic variant in one of the mismatch repair genes associated with Lynch syndrome</a>

938.</p>

939</li>

940</ul>

941</div>

942<div class="pdq-content-list">

943<ul id="_2930">

944<li>

945<strong>

946Associated Genes and Syndromes</strong>

947<p id="_2931" tabindex="-1">

948Breast and ovarian cancer are present in several autosomal dominant cancer syndromes, although they are most strongly associated with highly penetrant germline pathogenic variants in <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq">

949BRCA1 and BRCA2</a>

950. Other genes, such as <em class="gene-name">

951<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_3784">

952PALB2</a>

953</em>

954, <em class="gene-name">

955<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_3755">

956TP53</a>

957</em>

958 (associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome), <em class="gene-name">

959<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_3778">

960PTEN</a>

961</em>

962 (associated with <em class="gene-name">

963PTEN</em>

964 hamartoma tumor syndromes, including Cowden syndrome), <em class="gene-name">

965<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_3780">

966CDH1</a>

967</em>

968 (associated with diffuse gastric and lobular breast cancer syndrome), and <em class="gene-name">

969<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_3783">

970STK11</a>

971</em>

972 (associated with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome), confer a risk to either or both of these cancers with relatively high penetrance. </p>

973<p id="_2932" tabindex="-1">

974Inherited endometrial cancer is most commonly associated with <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_3750">

975Lynch syndrome</a>

976, a condition caused by inherited pathogenic variants in the highly penetrant mismatch repair genes <em class="gene-name">

977MLH1</em>

978, <em class="gene-name">

979MSH2</em>

980, <em class="gene-name">

981MSH6</em>

982, <em class="gene-name">

983PMS2</em>

984, and <em class="gene-name">

985EPCAM</em>

986. Colorectal cancer (and, to a lesser extent, ovarian cancer and stomach cancer) is also associated with Lynch syndrome.</p>

987<p id="_2933" tabindex="-1">

988Additional genes, such as <em class="gene-name">

989<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_1309">

990CHEK2</a>

991</em>

992, <em class="gene-name">

993<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2780">

994BRIP1</a>

995</em>

996, <em class="gene-name">

997<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2111">

998RAD51</a>

999</em>

1000, and <em class="gene-name">

1001<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_1311">

1002ATM</a>

1003</em>

1004, are associated with breast and/or gynecologic cancers with moderate penetrance. <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_1314">

1005Genome-wide searches</a>

1006 are showing promise in identifying common, low-penetrance susceptibility alleles for many complex diseases, including breast and gynecologic cancers, but the clinical utility of these findings remains uncertain. </p>

1007</li>

1008</ul>

1009</div>

1010<div class="pdq-content-list">

1011<ul id="_2934">

1012<li>

1013<strong>

1014Clinical Management</strong>

1015<p id="_2935" tabindex="-1">

1016<a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq#_3603">

1017Breast cancer screening strategies</a>

1018, including breast magnetic resonance imaging and mammography, are commonly performed in carriers of <em class="gene-name">

1019BRCA</em>

1020 pathogenic variants and in individuals at increased risk of breast cancer. Initiation of screening is generally recommended at earlier ages and at more frequent intervals in individuals with an increased risk due to genetics and family history than in the general population. There is evidence to demonstrate that these strategies have utility in early detection of cancer. In contrast, there is currently no evidence to demonstrate that <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq#_3494">

1021ovarian cancer screening</a>

1022 using cancer antigen&#8211;125 testing and transvaginal ultrasound leads to early detection of cancer. </p>

1023<p id="_2936" tabindex="-1">

1024Risk-reducing surgeries, including <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq#_3632">

1025risk-reducing mastectomy</a>

1026 (RRM) and <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq#_3639">

1027risk-reducing salpingo-oophorectomy</a>

1028 (RRSO), have been shown to significantly reduce the risk of developing breast and/or ovarian cancer and improve overall survival in carriers of <em class="gene-name">

1029BRCA1</em>

1030 and <em class="gene-name">

1031BRCA2</em>

1032 pathogenic variants. <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq#_3638">

1033Chemoprevention strategies for breast cancer</a>

1034 and <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq#_3640">

1035chemoprevention strategies for ovarian cancer</a>

1036 have been examined in this population. For example, <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq#_3638">

1037tamoxifen</a>

1038 use has been shown to reduce the risk of <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq#_3471">

1039contralateral breast cancer</a>

1040 among carriers of <em class="gene-name">

1041BRCA1</em>

1042 and <em class="gene-name">

1043BRCA2</em>

1044 pathogenic variants after treatment for breast cancer, but there are limited data in the primary cancer prevention setting to suggest that it reduces the risk of breast cancer among healthy female carriers of <em class="gene-name">

1045BRCA2</em>

1046 pathogenic variants. The use of <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq#_3744">

1047OCs</a>

1048 also has been associated with a protective effect on the risk of developing ovarian cancer, including in carriers of <em class="gene-name">

1049BRCA1</em>

1050 and <em class="gene-name">

1051BRCA2</em>

1052 pathogenic variants, with no association of increased risk of breast cancer when using formulations developed after 1975.</p>

1053</li>

1054</ul>

1055</div>

1056<div class="pdq-content-list">

1057<ul id="_2937">

1058<li>

1059<strong>

1060Psychosocial and Behavioral Issues</strong>

1061<p id="_2938" tabindex="-1">

1062<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_271">

1063Psychosocial factors</a>

1064 influence decisions about genetic testing for inherited cancer risk and risk-management strategies. <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2556">

1065Uptake of genetic testing</a>

1066 varies widely across studies. Psychological factors that have been associated with testing uptake include cancer-specific distress and perceived risk of developing breast or ovarian cancer. Studies have shown <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_298">

1067low levels of distress</a>

1068 after genetic testing for both carriers and noncarriers, particularly in the longer term. <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_1519">

1069Uptake of RRM and RRSO</a>

1070 also varies across studies and may be influenced by factors such as cancer history, age, family history, recommendations of the health care provider, and pretreatment genetic education and counseling. <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_964">

1071Patients' communication with their family members</a>

1072 about an inherited risk of breast and gynecologic cancer is complex; gender, age, and the degree of relatedness are some elements that affect disclosure of this information. Research is ongoing to better understand and address psychosocial and behavioral issues in high-risk families. </p>

1073</li>

1074</ul>

1075</div>

1076</div>

1077

1078 </section>

1079

1080

1081

1082 <section id="_1">

1083

1084 <h2>

1085Introduction</h2>

1086

1087 <div id="_section_1" class="pdq-sections">

1088<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

1089<h6>

1090In This Section</h6>

1091<ul>

1092<li>

1095</li>

1096<li>

1097<a href="#_2723_toc">

1098Risk Factors for Breast Cancer<ul>

1099<li>

1100<a href="#_338_toc">

1101Age</a>

1102</li>

1103<li>

1104<a href="#_6_toc">

1106</li>

1218BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

1220</li>

1223Considerations When Conducting Genetic Testing<ul>

1224<li>

1226Indications for hereditary breast and gynecologic cancers genetic testing </a>

1227</li>

1238</li>

1239</ul>

1240</nav>

1241<section id="_2">

1242<h3 id="_2_toc">

1243General Information</h3>

1244<p id="_3" tabindex="-1">

1245Among women in the United States, breast cancer is the most commonly diagnosed cancer after

1246nonmelanoma skin cancer, and it is the second leading cause of cancer deaths after

1247lung cancer. In 2022, an estimated 290,560 new cases of breast cancer (including 2,710 cases in men) will be diagnosed, and

124843,780 deaths (including 530 deaths in men) will occur.[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

12491</a>

1250] The incidence of breast cancer, particularly for estrogen receptor (ER)&#8211;positive cancers occurring after age 50 years, is declining and has declined at a faster rate since 2003; this may be temporally related to a decrease in hormone replacement therapy (HRT) after early reports from the Women&#8217;s Health Initiative (WHI).[<a href="#cit/section_2.2">

12512</a>

1252] An estimated 19,880 new cases of ovarian cancer are expected in the United States in 2022, with an estimated 12,810 deaths. Ovarian cancer is the fifth most deadly cancer in women.[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

12531</a>

1254] An estimated 65,950 new cases of endometrial cancer are expected in the United States in 2022, with an estimated 12,550 deaths.[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

12551</a>

1256] (Refer to the PDQ summaries on <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-treatment-pdq">

1257Breast Cancer Treatment</a>

1258; <a href="/types/ovarian/hp/ovarian-epithelial-treatment-pdq">

1259Ovarian Epithelial, Fallopian Tube, and Primary Peritoneal Cancer Treatment</a>

1260; and <a href="/types/uterine/hp/endometrial-treatment-pdq">

1261Endometrial Cancer Treatment</a>

1262 for more information about breast, ovarian, and endometrial cancer rates, diagnosis, and management.)</p>

1263<p id="_4" tabindex="-1">

1264A possible genetic contribution to both breast and ovarian cancer risk is indicated by the

1265increased incidence of these cancers among women with a family history (refer to the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2723">

1266Risk Factors for Breast Cancer</a>

1267, <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2724">

1268Risk Factors for Ovarian Cancer</a>

1269, and <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2725">

1270Risk Factors for Endometrial Cancer</a>

1271 sections below for more information), and by the observation of some families in which multiple family

1272members are <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460124&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460124&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1273affected</a>

1274 with breast and/or ovarian cancer, in a pattern compatible with an inheritance of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=793860&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000793860&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1275autosomal dominant</a>

1276 cancer susceptibility. Formal studies of families (<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=425374&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000425374&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1277linkage analysis</a>

1278) have subsequently proven the

1279existence of autosomal dominant predispositions to breast and ovarian cancer and have led to the

1280identification of several highly <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339344&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339344&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1281penetrant</a>

1282 <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1283genes</a>

1284 as the cause

1285of inherited cancer risk in many families. (Refer to the PDQ

1286summary <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/overview-pdq">

1287Cancer Genetics Overview</a>

1288 for more information about linkage

1289analysis.) <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1290Pathogenic variants</a>

1291 in these genes are rare in the general population and are estimated to account for no more

1292than 5% to 10% of breast and ovarian cancer cases overall. It is likely that other

1293genetic factors contribute to the etiology of some of these cancers.</p>

1294</section>

1295<section id="_2723">

1296<h3 id="_2723_toc">

1297Risk Factors for Breast Cancer</h3>

1298<p id="_3378" tabindex="-1">

1299This section discusses factors that can modify an individual's risk of developing breast cancer. These risk factors can affect women in the general population, women who have a family histories of breast cancer, and women who carry pathogenic variants in breast cancer risk genes. For more information on breast cancer risk factors in the general population, see <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-prevention-pdq">

1300Breast Cancer Prevention</a>

1301, and for more information on risks associated with <em class="gene-name">

1302BRCA1/2</em>

1303 pathogenic variants, see the<a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq#_3468">

1304 Cancer Risks, Spectrum, and Characteristics</a>

1305 section in <em class="gene-name">

1306BRCA1</em>

1307 and <em class="gene-name">

1308BRCA2</em>

1309: Cancer Risks and Management.</p>

1310<p id="_3387" tabindex="-1">

1311The following breast cancer risk factors are discussed in this section:</p>

1312<div class="pdq-content-list">

1313<ul id="_3388">

1314<li>

1315<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_338">

1316Age</a>

1317.</li>

1318<li>

1319<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_6">

1320Family history of breast cancer</a>

1321.</li>

1322<li>

1323<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_343">

1324Benign breast disease, mammographic density, and background parenchymal enhancement</a>

1325.</li>

1326<li>

1327<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_339">

1328Parity, age at first birth, and breastfeeding</a>

1329.</li>

1330<li>

1331<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_340">

1332Contraceptives</a>

1333.</li>

1334<li>

1335<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_1055">

1336Hormone replacement therapy (HRT)</a>

1337.</li>

1338<li>

1339<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_341">

1340Radiation exposure</a>

1341.</li>

1342<li>

1343<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_342">

1344Alcohol and smoking</a>

1345.</li>

1346<li>

1347<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_1583">

1348Physical activity</a>

1349.</li>

1350</ul>

1351</div>

1352<p id="_3389" tabindex="-1">

1353These factors can increase or decrease breast cancer risk in all women. However, they may affect breast cancer risk differently in women with increased breast cancer susceptibility (i.e., women who have high-risk family histories and/or pathogenic variants in hereditary breast cancer genes). Factors that increase breast cancer risk in the general population may lower breast cancer risk, increase breast cancer risk more than expected, or have no effect on breast cancer risk in women with high breast cancer susceptibility. In some cases, these risk factors may affect high-risk women in the same way that they affect average-risk women. Furthermore, modifying risk factors has a greater effect on the absolute breast cancer risk in women with high breast cancer susceptibility than in women with low breast cancer susceptibility.[<a href="#cit/section_2.3">

13543</a>

1355] It is imperative that providers discuss breast cancer risk factors with high-susceptibility patients, since risk patterns deviate from those seen in women in the general population. Providers may also want to convey whether these risk factors increase, decrease, or do not affect breast cancer risk in women with high breast cancer susceptibility, based on available evidence. This information may change how providers approach breast cancer risk management in women with high breast cancer susceptibility.</p>

1356<section id="_338">

1357<h4 id="_338_toc">

1358Age</h4>

1359<p id="_28" tabindex="-1">

1360Like other cancer types, breast cancer's cumulative risk increases with age. As individuals age, they encounter more environmental exposures and accumulate genomic changes. Hence, most breast cancers

1361occur after age 50 years.[<a href="#cit/section_2.4">

13624</a>

1363] Women with pathogenic variants in breast cancer risk genes often develop breast cancer at younger ages than women with <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339347&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339347&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1364sporadic</a>

1365 breast cancers.</p>

1366</section>

1367<section id="_6">

1368<h4 id="_6_toc">

1369Family history of breast cancer</h4>

1370<p id="_7" tabindex="-1">

1371A family history of breast cancer is a well-established, consistent risk factor for breast cancer. Approximately 5% to 10% of women with breast cancer also had a

1372mother or sister with breast cancer in cross-sectional studies. About 10% to 20% of women had a

1373<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460150&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460150&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1374first-degree relative</a>

1375 (FDR) or a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=485395&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000485395&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1376second-degree relative</a>

1377 (SDR) with breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.5">

13785</a>

1379-<a href="#cit/section_2.8">

13808</a>

1381] A pooled analysis of 38 studies showed that women had increased breast cancer risk when they had at least one FDR with breast cancer (relative risk [RR], 2.1; 95% confidence interval [CI], 2.0&#8211;2.2).[<a href="#cit/section_2.9">

13829</a>

1383] A large population-based study that used the Swedish Family Cancer Database found that women had a significantly increased risk of breast cancer when they had a mother or a sister with breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.6">

13846</a>

1385,<a href="#cit/section_2.7">

13867</a>

1387,<a href="#cit/section_2.9">

13889</a>

1389-<a href="#cit/section_2.11">

139011</a>

1391]</p>

1392<p id="_3403" tabindex="-1">

1393The following factors can increase a woman's breast cancer risk:</p>

1394<div class="pdq-content-list">

1395<ul id="_3394">

1396<li>

1397Large number of affected relatives.</li>

1398<li>

1399Family members who were diagnosed with breast cancer at young ages.</li>

1400<li>

1401Family members with bilateral breast cancers.</li>

1402<li>

1403Family members with multiple ipsilateral breast cancers.</li>

1404<li>

1405Male relatives with breast cancer.</li>

1406</ul>

1407</div>

1408<p id="_3419" tabindex="-1">

1409 Furthermore, women with family histories of multiple breast cancers had higher hazard ratios (HRs) (HR, 2.7; 95% CI, 2.6&#8211;2.9) than women who had a single breast cancer in their families (HR, 1.8; 95% CI, 1.8&#8211;1.9). When women had multiple breast cancers in their families (with one breast cancer occurring before age 40 years), the HR was 3.8 (95% CI, 3.1&#8211;4.8). However, breast cancer risk also significantly increased when a relative was diagnosed with breast cancer at 60 years or older, suggesting that having a relative with breast cancer at any age can increase risk.[<a href="#cit/section_2.11">

141011</a>

1411] Another study in women with unilateral versus contralateral breast cancer (CBC) evaluated CBC risk among family members.[<a href="#cit/section_2.12">

141212</a>

1413] Results indicated that women with at least one affected FDR had an 8.1% chance of developing CBC after 10 years. Participants' risks also increased when relatives were diagnosed with breast cancer before age 40 years (10-year absolute risk [AR], 13.5%; 95% CI, 8.8%&#8211;20.8%) or if relatives had CBC (10-year AR, 14.1%; 95% CI, 9.5%&#8211;20.7%). These risks were similar to those seen among <em class="gene-name">

1414BRCA</em>

1415 carriers (10-year AR, 18.4%; 95% CI, 16.0%&#8211;21.3%). These risk estimates remained unchanged when the analysis was restricted to women who tested negative for a pathogenic variant in <em class="gene-name">

1416BRCA1</em>

1417/<em class="gene-name">

1418BRCA2</em>

1419,<em class="gene-name">

1420 ATM</em>

1421, <em class="gene-name">

1422CHEK2</em>

1423, or <em class="gene-name">

1424PALB2</em>

1425.</p>

1426<p id="_3405" tabindex="-1">

1427Albright et al. addressed how affected <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=809963&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000809963&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1428third-degree relatives</a>

1429 (TDRs) can contribute to an individual's breast cancer risk.[<a href="#cit/section_2.13">

143013</a>

1431] These researchers used the Utah Population Database and the Utah Cancer Registry to estimate RRs for participants to develop breast cancer. They collected family histories with FDRs, SDRs, and TDRs and included both paternal and maternal relatives. They confirmed that individuals with affected FDRs had the highest breast cancer risk, particularly if the FDR was diagnosed with breast cancer early in life. When participants had five or more affected TDRs (and no FDRs/SDRs with breast cancer), they had an RR of 1.32 (95% CI, 1.11&#8211;1.57).</p>

1432<p id="_2996" tabindex="-1">

1433One of the largest studies of twins ever conducted examined 80,309 monozygotic twins and 123,382 dizygotic twins. This study had a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=781848&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000781848&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1434heritability</a>

1435 estimate of 31% for breast cancer (95% CI, 11%&#8211;51%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.14">

143614</a>

1437] If a monozygotic twin had breast cancer, her twin sister had a 28.1% chance of developing breast cancer (95% CI, 23.9%&#8211;32.8%), and if a dizygotic twin had breast cancer, her twin sister had a 19.9% chance of developing breast cancer (95% CI, 17%&#8211;23.2%). These estimates suggest that monozygotic twins have a 10% higher risk of developing breast cancer than dizygotic twins. However, the high rate of discordance seen, even between monozygotic twins, suggests that environmental factors can also modify breast cancer risk.</p>

1438</section>

1439<section id="_343">

1440<h4 id="_343_toc">

1441Benign breast disease, mammographic density, and background parenchymal enhancement</h4>

1442<p id="_3406" tabindex="-1">

1443<strong>

1444Benign breast disease (BBD)</strong>

1445</p>

1446<div class="pdq-content-list">

1447<ul id="_3407">

1448<li>

1449BBD is a broad group of conditions characterized by non-cancerous changes in breast tissue. BBD can be divided into three categories: nonproliferative lesions, proliferative lesions without atypia, and atypical hyperplasias. BBD is a consistent risk factor for breast cancer in the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_2.15">

145015</a>

1451,<a href="#cit/section_2.16">

145216</a>

1453]</li>

1454<li>

1455BBD is also an important risk factor in women who have high breast cancer susceptibility due to family histories of cancer or pathogenic variants in breast cancer risk genes. For example, a study of 17,154 women found that women with a history of BBD have an increased risk of breast cancer that is independent of their underlying familial and genetic risks.[<a href="#cit/section_2.17">

145617</a>

1457] However, breast cancer risk associated with personal histories of BBD did not vary between women with <em class="gene-name">

1458BRCA1</em>

1459 pathogenic variants (RR, 1.64; 95% CI, 1.04&#8211;2.58), women with <em class="gene-name">

1460BRCA2</em>

1461 pathogenic variants (RR, 1.34; 95% CI, 0.78&#8211;2.3), and women who only had family histories of breast cancer (RR, 1.31; 95% CI, 1.13&#8211;1.53). In women with high breast cancer susceptibility, BBD can further increase breast cancer risk, because it multiplies their underlying familial and genetic risks.</li>

1462</ul>

1463</div>

1464<p id="_3408" tabindex="-1">

1465<strong>

1466Mammographic density</strong>

1467</p>

1468<div class="pdq-content-list">

1469<ul id="_3409">

1470<li>

1471Women with dense breast tissue (assessed by mammogram) also have an increased risk of developing breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.15">

147215</a>

1473,<a href="#cit/section_2.18">

147418</a>

1475,<a href="#cit/section_2.19">

147619</a>

1477] Studies have shown that breast density likely has a genetic etiology.[<a href="#cit/section_2.20">

147820</a>

1479-<a href="#cit/section_2.22">

148022</a>

1481]</li>

1482<li>

1483A systematic review reported that women who had dense breast tissue and an FDR with breast cancer had an increased chance of developing breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.23">

148423</a>

1485] Two retrospective studies also investigated the association between mammographic density and breast cancer risk in <em class="gene-name">

1486BRCA1</em>

1487 and <em class="gene-name">

1488BRCA2</em>

1489 carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

149024</a>

1491,<a href="#cit/section_2.25">

149225</a>

1493] These retrospective studies had samples of 206 and 691 <em class="gene-name">

1494BRCA</em>

1495 pathogenic variant carriers. In these studies, 96 and 248 women developed breast cancer, respectively.[<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

149624</a>

1497,<a href="#cit/section_2.25">

149825</a>

1499] The studies found that mammographic density is an independent risk factor for breast cancer in both <em class="gene-name">

1500BRCA1</em>

1501 and <em class="gene-name">

1502BRCA2</em>

1503 pathogenic variant carriers. Associations between breast density and breast cancer risk were similar to those observed in the general population (RR, 2.30 for density &#8805;50% vs. &lt;50%).</li>

1504</ul>

1505</div>

1506<p id="_3411" tabindex="-1">

1507<strong>

1508Background parenchymal enhancement (BPE)</strong>

1509</p>

1510<div class="pdq-content-list">

1511<ul id="_3412">

1512<li>

1513Like breast density (assessed by mammogram), BPE (assessed by breast magnetic resonance imaging [MRI]) may increase breast cancer risk. Data have shown that moderate BPE (odds ratio [OR], 1.6; 95% CI, 1.0&#8211;2.6) and mild BPE (OR, 2.1; 95% CI, 1.5&#8211;3.0) can increase breast cancer risk in women with high breast cancer susceptibility. However, an association between mild/moderate BPE and breast cancer risk was not found in women with average breast cancer susceptibility.[<a href="#cit/section_2.26">

151426</a>

1515]</li>

1516</ul>

1517</div>

1518</section>

1519<section id="_339">

1520<h4 id="_339_toc">

1521Parity, age at first birth, and breastfeeding

1522</h4>

1523<p id="_3413" tabindex="-1">

1524<strong>

1525Parity</strong>

1526</p>

1527<div class="pdq-content-list">

1528<ul id="_3418">

1529<li>

1530A large prospective study analyzed the relationship between parity and breast cancer risk in female <em class="gene-name">

1531BRCA1</em>

1532 and <em class="gene-name">

1533BRCA2</em>

1534 carriers. Results showed that parity affected breast cancer risk in <em class="gene-name">

1535BRCA1</em>

1536 and <em class="gene-name">

1537BRCA2</em>

1538 carriers differently. Breast cancer risk increased in uniparous <em class="gene-name">

1539BRCA1</em>

1540 carriers and parous <em class="gene-name">

1541BRCA2</em>

1542 carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_2.27">

154327</a>

1544] In <em class="gene-name">

1545BRCA1</em>

1546 carriers, there was no overall association between parity and breast cancer risk when compared with nulliparity and breast cancer risk. Uniparous <em class="gene-name">

1547BRCA1</em>

1548 carriers were at an increased risk of breast cancer in the prospective analysis (HR<sub>

1549prospective</sub>

1550 , 1.69; 95% CI, 1.09&#8211;2.62) when compared with nulliparous <em class="gene-name">

1551BRCA1</em>

1552 carriers. The results also suggested that uniparous women who breastfed may have decreased breast cancer risk when compared with those who did not breastfeed. In <em class="gene-name">

1553BRCA2 </em>

1554carriers, being parous was associated with a 33% increase in breast cancer risk (HR<sub>

1555combined </sub>

1556, 1.33; 95% CI, 1.05&#8211;1.69). Multiparity did not decrease breast cancer risk in <em class="gene-name">

1557BRCA2 </em>

1558carriers, unless they had at least four full-term pregnancies (HR<sub>

1559combined</sub>

1560, 0.72; 95% CI, 0.54&#8211;0.98). </li>

1561</ul>

1562</div>

1563<p id="_3414" tabindex="-1">

1564<strong>

1565Age at first birth</strong>

1566</p>

1567<div class="pdq-content-list">

1568<ul id="_3415">

1569<li>

1570In the general population, breast cancer risk increases when women have early menarche and/or late menopause. Breast cancer risk decreases when a woman&#8217;s first full-term pregnancy occurs at a young age. However, these risk factors can affect women with high breast cancer susceptibility differently than women in the general population. <em class="gene-name">

1571BRCA1</em>

1572 and <em class="gene-name">

1573BRCA2</em>

1574 pathogenic variant <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460132&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460132&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1575carriers</a>

1576 who become pregnant prior to age 30 years may have increased breast cancer risk. This effect is even more significant in <em class="gene-name">

1577BRCA1</em>

1578 pathogenic variant carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_2.28">

157928</a>

1580-<a href="#cit/section_2.30">

158130</a>

1582] <em class="gene-name">

1583BRCA1</em>

1584 and <em class="gene-name">

1585BRCA2</em>

1586 pathogenic variant carriers who developed breast cancer during pregnancy or became pregnant after developing breast cancer did not experience adverse survival outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_2.31">

158731</a>

1588]</li>

1589</ul>

1590</div>

1591<p id="_3416" tabindex="-1">

1592<strong>

1593Breastfeeding</strong>

1594</p>

1595<div class="pdq-content-list">

1596<ul id="_3417">

1597<li>

1598Breastfeeding can reduce breast cancer risk in <em class="gene-name">

1599BRCA1</em>

1600 (but not <em class="gene-name">

1601BRCA2</em>

1602) pathogenic variant carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_2.32">

160332</a>

1604] Breastfeeding for long periods of time was associated with decreased breast cancer risk in <em class="gene-name">

1605BRCA1</em>

1606 carriers (<em>

1607P</em>

1608-trend = .0003).[<a href="#cit/section_2.27">

160927</a>

1610] </li>

1611</ul>

1612</div>

1613<p id="_2939" tabindex="-1">

1614Reproductive history can also affect a woman's risk for ovarian cancer and endometrial cancer. For more information, see the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2724">

1615Risk Factors for Ovarian Cancer</a>

1616 and <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2725">

1617Risk Factors for Endometrial Cancer</a>

1618 sections.</p>

1619</section>

1620<section id="_340">

1621<h4 id="_340_toc">

1622Contraceptives</h4>

1623<p id="_33" tabindex="-1">

1624Breast cancer risk is one of the factors to consider when prescribing contraceptives, which assist with pregnancy control, abnormal bleeding, and other gynecological symptoms. Oral contraceptives (OCs) may slightly increase breast cancer risk in

1625long-term users, but this appears to be a short-term effect.[<a href="#cit/section_2.33">

162633</a>

1627]</p>

1628<p id="_34" tabindex="-1">

1629Some studies show that OC use does not further increase breast cancer risk in women with high breast cancer susceptibility. For example, a meta-analysis

1630with data from 54 studies showed that women with family histories of breast cancer did not have increased breast cancer risk from OC use.[<a href="#cit/section_2.33">

163133</a>

1632] Although the data are not entirely consistent, a meta-analysis of <em class="gene-name">

1633BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

1634 pathogenic variant carriers concluded that breast cancer risk did not significantly increase when participants used OCs.[<a href="#cit/section_2.34">

163534</a>

1636] More specifically, the International <em class="gene-name">

1637BRCA1/2</em>

1638 Carrier Cohort Study (IBCCS), the Kathleen Cuningham Foundation Consortium for Research into Familial Breast Cancer (kConFab) Follow-Up Study, and the Breast Cancer Family Registry (BCFR) did not report associations between OC use and increased breast cancer risk in women with <em class="gene-name">

1639BRCA1</em>

1640 pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_2.35">

164135</a>

1642] In fact, OCs are sometimes recommended for ovarian cancer prevention in <em class="gene-name">

1643BRCA1</em>

1644 and <em class="gene-name">

1645BRCA2</em>

1646 pathogenic variant carriers. For more information, see the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_1059">

1647Oral contraceptives</a>

1648 and <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2724">

1649Risk Factors for Ovarian Cancer</a>

1650 sections. However, in the prospective analyses of the IBCCS, kConFab, and BCFR studies mentioned above, women with <em class="gene-name">

1651BRCA2</em>

1652 pathogenic variants had increased breast cancer risk when they took OCs (HR, 1.75; 95% CI, 1.03&#8211;2.97). Additionally, a systematic review of the published data concluded that it is unclear if OC use increases breast cancer risk in <em class="gene-name">

1653BRCA1/2</em>

1654 carriers due to inconsistencies across studies.[<a href="#cit/section_2.36">

165536</a>

1656]</p>

1657<p id="_3400" tabindex="-1">

1658Some studies also suggest that the year an OC was made and a woman's age when beginning OC use may matter. For example, OCs made before 1975 are associated with increased breast cancer risk in <em class="gene-name">

1659BRCA1/2</em>

1660 carriers (summary relative risk [SRR], 1.47; 95% CI, 1.06&#8211;2.04).[<a href="#cit/section_2.34">

166134</a>

1662] A case-control study of 2,492 matched pairs of women with a <em class="gene-name">

1663BRCA1</em>

1664 pathogenic variant also found that OC use significantly increased breast cancer risk when women began using OCs prior to age 20 years (OR, 1.45; 95% CI, 1.20&#8211;1.75).[<a href="#cit/section_2.37">

166537</a>

1666]</p>

1667<p id="_3381" tabindex="-1">

1668Other contraceptive methods have not been studied in women with pathogenic variants in breast cancer risk genes. However, studies have investigated associations between intrauterine devices and breast cancer risk in the general population. A meta-analysis and systematic review of seven studies examined the effect of the levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system (LNG-IUS) on breast cancer risk. The meta-analysis included studies that controlled for family history of breast cancer, but associations were not separately evaluated or stratified by family history of breast cancer. In LNG-IUS users, breast cancer risk increased in all women (OR, 1.16; 95% CI, 1.06&#8211;1.28), in women younger than 50 years (OR, 1.12; 95% CI, 1.02&#8211;1.22), and in women 50 years and older (OR, 1.52; 95% CI, 1.34&#8211;1.72).[<a href="#cit/section_2.38">

166938</a>

1670]</p>

1671</section>

1672<section id="_1055">

1673<h4 id="_1055_toc">

1674Hormone replacement therapy</h4>

1675<p id="_35" tabindex="-1">

1676Both observational studies and randomized clinical trials have examined the association between postmenopausal HRT and breast cancer. Short-term use of HRT for treatment of postmenopausal symptoms appears to

1677confer little or no breast cancer risk.[<a href="#cit/section_2.39">

167839</a>

1679,<a href="#cit/section_2.40">

168040</a>

1681] A meta-analysis with data from 51

1682observational studies found a 1.35 RR for breast cancer (95% CI, 1.21&#8211;1.49)

1683in women who used HRT for 5 or more years after menopause.[<a href="#cit/section_2.39">

168439</a>

1685] The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00000611">

1686WHI</a>

1687, a randomized, controlled trial of about 160,000 postmenopausal women, investigated the risks and benefits of HRT. The estrogen-plus-progestin arm of the study, in which more than 16,000 women were randomly assigned to receive combined estrogen and progestin or placebo, was halted early because health risks exceeded health benefits.[<a href="#cit/section_2.41">

168841</a>

1689,<a href="#cit/section_2.42">

169042</a>

1691] Significant increases in both total breast cancer cases (245 in the estrogen-plus-progestin group vs. 185 in the placebo group) and invasive breast cancer cases (199 in the estrogen-plus-progestin group vs. 150 in the placebo group) prompted early closure of the study (RR, 1.24; 95% CI, 1.02&#8211;1.5; <em>

1692P</em>

1693 &lt; .001). Risks for coronary heart disease, stroke, and pulmonary embolism also increased in the estrogen-plus-progestin group. The WHI study did not stratify data by participants' family histories of breast cancer, and subjects were not systematically tested for <em class="gene-name">

1694BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

1695 pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_2.42">

169642</a>

1697] Similar findings were seen in the estrogen-progestin arm of the prospective, observational Million Women&#8217;s Study in the United Kingdom.[<a href="#cit/section_2.43">

169843</a>

1699] However, breast cancer risk was not elevated in women randomly assigned to the estrogen-only group when compared with those in the placebo group in the WHI study (RR, 0.77; 95% CI, 0.59&#8211;1.01). Hysterectomy was required for women to qualify for the estrogen-only arm of this study; 40% of these patients also had a bilateral oophorectomy, which can potentially decrease breast cancer risk.[<a href="#cit/section_2.44">

170044</a>

1701]</p>

1702<p id="_36" tabindex="-1">

1703Among women with family histories of breast cancer, the associations between HRT and breast cancer risk have not been consistent. Some studies suggested risk was particularly elevated among women with family histories of breast cancer, while others did not report an interaction between these factors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.45">

170445</a>

1705-<a href="#cit/section_2.49">

170649</a>

1707,<a href="#cit/section_2.39">

170839</a>

1709]

1710A large meta-analysis found that women who used HRT had increased breast cancer risk. However, risk did not differ significantly between subjects with or without family histories of cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.49">

171149</a>

1712]</p>

1713<p id="_3401" tabindex="-1">

1714The effect of HRT on breast cancer risk among carriers of <em class="gene-name">

1715BRCA1</em>

1716 and <em class="gene-name">

1717BRCA2</em>

1718 pathogenic variants has been studied in the context of bilateral risk-reducing oophorectomy. Short-term HRT use does not seem to alter an oophorectomy's protective effect on breast cancer risk.[<a href="#cit/section_2.50">

171950</a>

1720] For example, a prospective, longitudinal cohort study recruited <em class="gene-name">

1721BRCA1</em>

1722 carriers from 80 centers in 17 countries. This study found that HRT use after oophorectomy was not associated with increased breast cancer risk in <em class="gene-name">

1723BRCA1</em>

1724 carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_2.51">

172551</a>

1726] The HR was 0.97 (95% CI, 0.62&#8211;1.52) for individuals who used HRT when compared with individuals who had never used HRT. However, the effects of estrogen-only HRT and estrogen-plus-progesterone HRT differed. After a 10-year follow-up period, the cumulative breast cancer incidence was 12% in women who used estrogen-only HRT and 22% in women who used estrogen-plus-progesterone HRT. These associations were stronger for women who underwent oophorectomy before age 45 years. The study concluded that using estrogen-only HRT after oophorectomy did not increase risk of <em class="gene-name">

1727BRCA1</em>

1728-associated breast cancers. However, the potential harmful effects of progesterone-containing HRT warrant further study.[<a href="#cit/section_2.52">

172952</a>

1730] For more information, see the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq#_3495">

1731HRT in Carriers of <em class="gene-name">

1732BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

1733 Pathogenic Variants</a>

1734 section in <em class="gene-name">

1735BRCA1</em>

1736 and <em class="gene-name">

1737BRCA2</em>

1738: Cancer Risks and Management.</p>

1739<p id="_2940" tabindex="-1">

1740HRT use may also increase a woman's chance of developing endometrial cancer. For more information, see the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2729">

1741Hormones</a>

1742 section.</p>

1743</section>

1744<section id="_341">

1745<h4 id="_341_toc">

1746Radiation exposure</h4>

1747<p id="_38" tabindex="-1">

1748Radiation exposure can increase an individual's breast cancer risk. This is demonstrated by the survivors of the atomic bombings in Hiroshima and Nagasaki and by women who have received

1749therapeutic radiation treatments to the chest and upper body. However, it is unclear how much radiation exposure affects breast cancer risk in women with high breast cancer susceptibility.

1750

1751</p>

1752<p id="_872" tabindex="-1">

1753Early data suggested that carriers of <em class="gene-name">

1754BRCA1</em>

1755 and

1756<em class="gene-name">

1757BRCA2</em>

1758 pathogenic variants may have increased sensitivity to

1759radiation, which may contribute to cancer susceptibility.[<a href="#cit/section_2.53">

176053</a>

1761-<a href="#cit/section_2.56">

176256</a>

1763] Studies have shown that individuals with germline <em class="gene-name">

1764ATM</em>

1765 and <em class="gene-name">

1766TP53</em>

1767 variants also have increased sensitivity to radiation.[<a href="#cit/section_2.57">

176857</a>

1769,<a href="#cit/section_2.58">

177058</a>

1771] </p>

1772<p id="_42" tabindex="-1">

1773It is possible that radiation exposure from diagnostic procedures, including mammography, poses

1774a greater risk to women with high breast cancer susceptibility than to women who are at average risk of developing breast cancer.

1775Therapeutic radiation could also increase cancer risk in women with high breast cancer susceptibility. However, a cohort study of

1776 <em class="gene-name">

1777BRCA1</em>

1778 and <em class="gene-name">

1779BRCA2</em>

1780 pathogenic variant carriers treated with breast-conserving therapy did not show evidence of increased radiation sensitivity in participants. Sequelae were not observed in

1781the breasts, lungs, or bone marrow of <em class="gene-name">

1782BRCA</em>

1783 carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_2.59">

178459</a>

1785]</p>

1786<p id="_3402" tabindex="-1">

1787Conversely,

1788tumors in women with pathogenic variants in breast cancer risk genes may be more responsive to radiation treatment than tumors in women at average breast cancer risk. Studies examining the impact of radiation exposure in carriers of <em class="gene-name">

1789BRCA1</em>

1790 and <em class="gene-name">

1791BRCA2 </em>

1792pathogenic variants have had conflicting results.[<a href="#cit/section_2.60">

179360</a>

1794-<a href="#cit/section_2.65">

179565</a>

1796] A large European study showed a dose-response relationship, in which breast cancer risk increased with total radiation exposure. However, this occurred most often when patients had nonmammographic radiation exposure before age 20 years.[<a href="#cit/section_2.64">

179764</a>

1798] A significant association was not observed between prior mammography exposure and breast cancer risk in a prospective study of 1,844 <em class="gene-name">

1799BRCA1</em>

1800 carriers and 502 <em class="gene-name">

1801BRCA2</em>

1802 carriers without breast cancer diagnoses upon study entry. The average follow-up period in this study was 5.3 years.[<a href="#cit/section_2.65">

180365</a>

1804]</p>

1805<p id="_3382" tabindex="-1">

1806A retrospective cohort study estimated the effect of adjuvant radiation therapy (for primary breast cancer) on CBC risk in <em class="gene-name">

1807BRCA1</em>

1808 and <em class="gene-name">

1809BRCA2</em>

1810 carriers (N, 691; median follow-up period, 8.6 y).[<a href="#cit/section_2.66">

181166</a>

1812] An association was not found between radiation therapy and CBC risk (HR, 0.82; 95% CI, 0.45&#8211;1.45). This was also true in patients who were younger than 40 years when they were diagnosed with their primary breast cancers (HR, 1.36; 95% CI, 0.60&#8211;3.09). A study examined the impact of radiation therapy on CBC risk in <em class="gene-name">

1813ATM</em>

1814, <em class="gene-name">

1815BRCA1/2</em>

1816, and <em class="gene-name">

1817CHEK2</em>

1818 1100delC carriers. CBC risk was not modified by radiation therapy, even though these women had a higher baseline risk of CBC than women in the general population (<em class="gene-name">

1819BRCA1/2</em>

1820 pathogenic variant carriers without radiation therapy: RR, 3.52; 95% CI, 1.76&#8211;7.01; <em class="gene-name">

1821BRCA1/2</em>

1822 pathogenic variant carriers with radiation therapy: RR, 4.46; 95% CI, 2.96&#8211;6.71).[<a href="#cit/section_2.67">

182367</a>

1824] Thus, it is important to differentiate individuals with increased CBC risk due to pathogenic variants from individuals with increased CBC risk due to radiation therapy. For more information, see the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq#_3612">

1825Mammography</a>

1826 section in <em class="gene-name">

1827BRCA1</em>

1828 and <em class="gene-name">

1829BRCA2</em>

1830: Cancer Risks and Management.</p>

1831</section>

1832<section id="_342">

1833<h4 id="_342_toc">

1834Alcohol and smoking</h4>

1835<p id="_1056" tabindex="-1">

1836The risk of breast cancer increases by approximately 10% for each 10 g of daily alcohol intake (approximately one drink or less) in the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_2.68">

183768</a>

1838,<a href="#cit/section_2.69">

183969</a>

1840] Prior studies of <em class="gene-name">

1841BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

1842 pathogenic variant carriers have not found an association between alcohol consumption and increased breast cancer risk.[<a href="#cit/section_2.70">

184370</a>

1844-<a href="#cit/section_2.72">

184572</a>

1846] The association between cigarette smoking and breast cancer risk in women with <em class="gene-name">

1847BRCA1/2</em>

1848 pathogenic variants is inconclusive.[<a href="#cit/section_2.73">

184973</a>

1850,<a href="#cit/section_2.74">

185174</a>

1852]</p>

1853<p id="_3383" tabindex="-1">

1854Recent studies have evaluated the association between alcohol consumption, tobacco smoking, and breast cancer risk in individuals with <em class="gene-name">

1855BRCA1/2</em>

1856 pathogenic variants or family histories of breast cancer. One study evaluated if tobacco smoking and alcohol consumption are associated with increased breast cancer risk in <em class="gene-name">

1857BRCA1</em>

1858 and <em class="gene-name">

1859BRCA2</em>

1860 carriers using pooled data from an international cohort.[<a href="#cit/section_2.75">

186175</a>

1862] This study did not find an association between alcohol consumption and increased breast cancer risk in <em class="gene-name">

1863BRCA1</em>

1864 and <em class="gene-name">

1865BRCA2</em>

1866 carriers. Parous <em class="gene-name">

1867BRCA </em>

1868carriers who smoked for more than 5 years before their first full-term pregnancy had a significantly increased breast cancer risk when compared with parous <em class="gene-name">

1869BRCA</em>

1870 carriers who did not smoke. A prospective study evaluating a cohort of women with family histories of breast cancer found that alcohol consumption was associated with an increased number of ER-positive breast cancers in women at the lowest quantile of absolute breast cancer risk (HR, 1.46; 95% CI, 1.07&#8211;1.99).[<a href="#cit/section_2.76">

187176</a>

1872] Cigarette smoking was also associated with increased breast cancer risk in those at the highest quantile of absolute breast cancer risk.</p>

1873</section>

1874<section id="_1583">

1875<h4 id="_1583_toc">

1876Physical activity</h4>

1877<p id="_3317" tabindex="-1">

1878Increased physical activity has been associated with reduced breast cancer risk in most epidemiological studies. This risk reduction has also been seen in studies of female <em class="gene-name">

1879BRCA1</em>

1880 or <em class="gene-name">

1881BRCA2</em>

1882 pathogenic variant carriers. For example, one study reported a 38% reduction in premenopausal breast cancer risk from moderate physical activity (OR for the top quartile of physical activity compared with the lowest level, 0.62; 95% CI, 0.40&#8211;0.96).[<a href="#cit/section_2.77">

188377</a>

1884] This reduction in breast cancer risk has been seen in women with varying levels of breast cancer susceptibility, including women who have family histories of breast cancer but do not have known <em class="gene-name">

1885BRCA1</em>

1886 or <em class="gene-name">

1887BRCA2</em>

1888 pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_2.78">

188978</a>

1890]</p>

1891</section>

1892</section>

1893<section id="_2724">

1894<h3 id="_2724_toc">

1895Risk Factors for Ovarian Cancer</h3>

1896<p id="_2753" tabindex="-1">

1897Refer to the PDQ summary on <a href="/types/ovarian/hp/ovarian-prevention-pdq">

1898Ovarian, Fallopian Tube, and Primary Peritoneal Cancers Prevention</a>

1899 for information about risk factors for ovarian cancer in the general population.</p>

1900<section id="_345">

1901<h4 id="_345_toc">

1902Age</h4>

1903<p id="_59" tabindex="-1">

1904Ovarian cancer incidence rises in a linear fashion from age 30 years to age 50 years and continues to increase, though at a slower rate, thereafter. Before age 30 years, the risk of developing epithelial ovarian cancer is remote, even in hereditary cancer families.[<a href="#cit/section_2.79">

190579</a>

1906]</p>

1907</section>

1908<section id="_11">

1909<h4 id="_11_toc">

1910Family history including inherited cancer genes</h4>

1911<p id="_12" tabindex="-1">

1912Although reproductive, demographic, and lifestyle

1913factors affect risk of ovarian cancer, the single greatest ovarian cancer risk

1914factor is a family history of the disease. A large meta-analysis of 15 published studies estimated an OR of 3.1 for the risk of ovarian cancer associated with at least one FDR with ovarian cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.80">

191580</a>

1916]</p>

1917</section>

1918<section id="_347">

1919<h4 id="_347_toc">

1920Reproductive

1921history</h4>

1922<p id="_63" tabindex="-1">

1923Nulliparity is consistently associated with an increased risk of ovarian cancer, including among carriers of <em class="gene-name">

1924BRCA</em>

1925/<em class="gene-name">

1926BRCA2</em>

1927 pathogenic variants, yet a meta-analysis identified a risk reduction only in women with four or more live births.[<a href="#cit/section_2.30">

192830</a>

1929] Risk may also be increased among women who have used fertility drugs, especially those who remain nulligravid.[<a href="#cit/section_2.81">

193081</a>

1931,<a href="#cit/section_2.82">

193282</a>

1933] Several studies have reported a risk reduction in ovarian cancer after OC use in carriers of <em class="gene-name">

1934BRCA</em>

1935/<em class="gene-name">

1936BRCA2</em>

1937 pathogenic variants;[<a href="#cit/section_2.83">

193883</a>

1939-<a href="#cit/section_2.85">

194085</a>

1941] a risk reduction has also been shown after tubal ligation in <em class="gene-name">

1942BRCA1</em>

1943 carriers, with a statistically significant decreased risk of 22% to 80% after the procedure.[<a href="#cit/section_2.85">

194485</a>

1945,<a href="#cit/section_2.86">

194686</a>

1947]

1948 Breastfeeding for more than 12 months may also be associated with a reduction in ovarian cancer among carriers of <em class="gene-name">

1949BRCA1</em>

1950/<em class="gene-name">

1951BRCA2</em>

1952 pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_2.87">

195387</a>

1954] On the other hand, evidence is growing that the use of menopausal HRT is associated with an increased risk of ovarian cancer, particularly in long-time users and users of sequential estrogen-progesterone schedules.[<a href="#cit/section_2.88">

195588</a>

1956-<a href="#cit/section_2.91">

195791</a>

1958]</p>

1959</section>

1960<section id="_348">

1961<h4 id="_348_toc">

1962Surgical history

1963</h4>

1964<p id="_65" tabindex="-1">

1965Bilateral tubal ligation and hysterectomy are associated with reduced ovarian cancer risk,[<a href="#cit/section_2.81">

196681</a>

1967,<a href="#cit/section_2.92">

196892</a>

1969,<a href="#cit/section_2.93">

197093</a>

1971] including in carriers of <em class="gene-name">

1972BRCA</em>

1973/<em class="gene-name">

1974BRCA2</em>

1975 pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_2.94">

197694</a>

1977] Ovarian cancer risk is reduced more than 90% in women with documented <em class="gene-name">

1978BRCA1</em>

1979 or <em class="gene-name">

1980BRCA2</em>

1981 pathogenic variants who chose risk-reducing salpingo-oophorectomy (RRSO). In this same population, risk-reducing oophorectomy also resulted in a nearly 50% reduction in the risk of subsequent breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.95">

198295</a>

1983,<a href="#cit/section_2.96">

198496</a>

1985] While some studies have shown more benefit for breast cancer reduction in patients with <em class="gene-name">

1986BRCA2</em>

1987 versus <em class="gene-name">

1988BRCA1</em>

1989 pathogenic variants, others have shown no benefit for <em class="gene-name">

1990BRCA1</em>

1991 carriers. Additionally, many of the studies remain underpowered to demonstrate benefit.[<a href="#cit/section_2.97">

199297</a>

1993] (Refer to the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq#_3637">

1994Risk-reducing salpingo-oophorectomy for breast cancer risk reduction</a>

1995 section in <em class="gene-name">

1996BRCA1</em>

1997 and <em class="gene-name">

1998BRCA2</em>

1999: Cancer Risks and Management for more information about these studies.)</p>

2000</section>

2001<section id="_1059">

2002<h4 id="_1059_toc">

2003Oral contraceptives (OCs)</h4>

2004<p id="_1060" tabindex="-1">

2005Use of OCs for 4 or more years is associated with an approximately 50% reduction in ovarian cancer risk in the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_2.81">

200681</a>

2007,<a href="#cit/section_2.98">

200898</a>

2009] A majority of, but not all, studies also support OCs being protective among carriers of <em class="gene-name">

2010BRCA</em>

2011/<em class="gene-name">

2012BRCA2</em>

2013 pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_2.86">

201486</a>

2015,<a href="#cit/section_2.99">

201699</a>

2017-<a href="#cit/section_2.102">

2018102</a>

2019] A meta-analysis of 18 studies including 13,627 carriers of <em class="gene-name">

2020BRCA</em>

2021 pathogenic variants reported a significantly reduced risk of ovarian cancer (SRR, 0.50; 95% CI, 0.33&#8211;0.75) associated with OC use.[<a href="#cit/section_2.34">

202234</a>

2023] (Refer to the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq#_3640">

2024Chemopreventive agents for reducing ovarian cancer risk</a>

2025 section in <em class="gene-name">

2026BRCA1</em>

2027 and <em class="gene-name">

2028BRCA2</em>

2029: Cancer Risks and Management.)</p>

2030</section>

2031</section>

2032<section id="_2725">

2033<h3 id="_2725_toc">

2034Risk Factors for Endometrial Cancer</h3>

2035<p id="_2754" tabindex="-1">

2036Refer to the PDQ summary on <a href="/types/uterine/hp/endometrial-prevention-pdq">

2037Endometrial Cancer Prevention</a>

2038 for information about risk factors for endometrial cancer in the general population.</p>

2039<section id="_2726">

2040<h4 id="_2726_toc">

2041Age</h4>

2042<p id="_2734" tabindex="-1">

2043

2044

2045Age is an important risk factor for endometrial cancer. Most women with endometrial cancer are diagnosed after menopause. Only 15% of women are diagnosed with endometrial cancer before age 50 years, and fewer than 5% are diagnosed before age 40 years.[<a href="#cit/section_2.103">

2046103</a>

2047]

2048 Women with Lynch syndrome tend to develop endometrial cancer at an earlier age, with the median age at diagnosis of 48 years.[<a href="#cit/section_2.104">

2049104</a>

2050]</p>

2051</section>

2052<section id="_2703">

2053<h4 id="_2703_toc">

2054Family history including inherited cancer genes</h4>

2055<p id="_2704" tabindex="-1">

2056Although the hyperestrogenic state is the most common predisposing factor for endometrial cancer, family history also plays a significant role in a woman&#8217;s risk for disease. Approximately 3% to 5% of uterine cancer cases are attributable to a hereditary cause,[<a href="#cit/section_2.105">

2057105</a>

2058] with the main hereditary endometrial cancer syndrome being Lynch syndrome, an autosomal dominant genetic condition with a population prevalence of 1 in 300 to 1 in 1,000 individuals.[<a href="#cit/section_2.106">

2059106</a>

2060,<a href="#cit/section_2.107">

2061107</a>

2062] (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2986">

2063Lynch Syndrome</a>

2064 section in Genetics of Colorectal Cancer for more information.)</p>

2065<p id="_3020" tabindex="-1">

2066Non-Lynch syndrome genes may also contribute to endometrial cancer risk. In an unselected endometrial cancer cohort undergoing <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=775581&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000775581&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2067multigene panel testing</a>

2068, approximately 3% of patients tested positive for a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=781852&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000781852&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2069germline pathogenic variant</a>

2070 in non-Lynch syndrome genes, including <em class="gene-name">

2071CHEK2</em>

2072, <em class="gene-name">

2073APC</em>

2074, <em class="gene-name">

2075ATM</em>

2076, <em class="gene-name">

2077BARD1</em>

2078, <em class="gene-name">

2079BRCA1</em>

2080, <em class="gene-name">

2081BRCA2</em>

2082, <em class="gene-name">

2083BRIP1</em>

2084, <em class="gene-name">

2085NBN</em>

2086, <em class="gene-name">

2087PTEN</em>

2088, and <em class="gene-name">

2089RAD51C</em>

2090.[<a href="#cit/section_2.108">

2091108</a>

2092] Notably, patients with pathogenic variants in non-Lynch syndrome genes were more likely to have serous tumor histology than were patients without pathogenic variants. Furthermore, although the overall risk of endometrial cancer after RRSO was not increased among carriers of <em class="gene-name">

2093BRCA1</em>

2094 pathogenic variants, these patients seemed to have an increased risk of serous and serous-like endometrial cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.109">

2095109</a>

2096]

2097

2098These findings were supported by a Dutch multicenter cohort study in women with germline <em class="gene-name">

2099BRCA1</em>

2100 and <em class="gene-name">

2101BRCA2</em>

2102 pathogenic variants. This study concluded that participants' AR for endometrial cancer was approximately 3%. Because some serous and p53-aberrant endometrial cancers may harbor germline or somatic <em class="gene-name">

2103BRCA1</em>

2104/<em class="gene-name">

2105BRCA2</em>

2106 mutations, poly (ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP) inhibitor therapy may also be a therapeutic option.[<a href="#cit/section_2.110">

2107110</a>

2108] </p>

2109</section>

2110<section id="_2727">

2111<h4 id="_2727_toc">

2112Reproductive history</h4>

2113<p id="_2735" tabindex="-1">

2114Reproductive factors such as multiparity, late menarche, and early menopause decrease the risk of endometrial cancer because of the lower cumulative exposure to estrogen and the higher relative exposure to progesterone.[<a href="#cit/section_2.111">

2115111</a>

2116,<a href="#cit/section_2.112">

2117112</a>

2118]</p>

2119</section>

2120<section id="_2729">

2121<h4 id="_2729_toc">

2122Hormones</h4>

2123<p id="_2736" tabindex="-1">

2124Hormonal factors that increase the risk of type I endometrial cancer are better understood. All endometrial cancers share a predominance of estrogen relative to progesterone. Prolonged exposure to estrogen or unopposed estrogen increases the risk of endometrial cancer. Endogenous exposure to estrogen can result from obesity, polycystic ovary syndrome, and nulliparity, while exogenous estrogen can result from taking unopposed estrogen or tamoxifen. Unopposed estrogen increases the risk of developing endometrial cancer by twofold to twentyfold, proportional to the duration of use.[<a href="#cit/section_2.113">

2125113</a>

2126,<a href="#cit/section_2.114">

2127114</a>

2128] Tamoxifen, a selective estrogen receptor modulator, acts as an estrogen agonist on the endometrium while acting as an estrogen antagonist in breast tissue, and increases the risk of endometrial cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.115">

2129115</a>

2130] In contrast, OCs, the LNG-IUS, and combination estrogen-progesterone HRT all reduce the risk of endometrial cancer through the antiproliferative effect of progesterone acting on the endometrium.[<a href="#cit/section_2.116">

2131116</a>

2132-<a href="#cit/section_2.119">

2133119</a>

2134]</p>

2135</section>

2136</section>

2137<section id="_15">

2138<h3 id="_15_toc">

2139Autosomal Dominant Inheritance of Breast and Gynecologic Cancer Predisposition</h3>

2140<p id="_16" tabindex="-1">

2141Autosomal dominant inheritance of breast and gynecologic cancers is characterized by transmission of

2142cancer <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460153&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460153&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2143predisposition</a>

2144 from generation to generation, through either the mother&#8217;s or the father&#8217;s

2145side of the family, with the following characteristics:

2146</p>

2147<div class="pdq-content-list">

2148<ul id="_726">

2149<li>

2150Inheritance risk of 50%. When a parent carries an autosomal dominant genetic predisposition, each child has a 50:50 chance of inheriting the predisposition. Although the risk of inheriting the predisposition is 50%, not everyone with the predisposition will develop cancer because of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=792352&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000792352&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2151incomplete penetrance</a>

2152 and/or gender-restricted or gender-related expression.</li>

2153<li>

2154Both males and females can inherit and transmit an autosomal dominant

2155cancer predisposition. A male who

2156inherits a cancer predisposition can still

2157pass the altered gene on to his sons and daughters.

2158</li>

2159</ul>

2160</div>

2161<p id="_1194" tabindex="-1">

2162Breast and ovarian cancer are components of several autosomal dominant cancer syndromes. The syndromes most strongly associated with both cancers are the syndromes associated with <em class="gene-name">

2163BRCA1</em>

2164 or <em class="gene-name">

2165BRCA2</em>

2166 pathogenic variants. Breast cancer is also a common feature of <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_3755">

2167Li-Fraumeni syndrome</a>

2168 due to <em class="gene-name">

2169TP53</em>

2170 pathogenic variants and of <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_3778">

2171<em class="gene-name">

2172PTEN</em>

2173 hamartoma tumor syndromes (including Cowden syndrome)</a>

2174 due to <em class="gene-name">

2175PTEN</em>

2176 pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_2.120">

2177120</a>

2178] Other genetic syndromes that may include breast cancer as an associated feature include heterozygous carriers of the <em class="gene-name">

2179<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_1311">

2180ATM</a>

2181</em>

2182 gene and <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_3783">

2183Peutz-Jeghers syndrome</a>

2184. Ovarian cancer has also been associated with <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_3750">

2185Lynch syndrome</a>

2186, basal cell nevus (Gorlin) syndrome, and multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1.[<a href="#cit/section_2.120">

2187120</a>

2188] Lynch syndrome is mainly associated with colorectal cancer and endometrial cancer, although several studies have demonstrated that patients with Lynch syndrome are also at risk of developing transitional cell carcinoma of the ureters and renal pelvis; cancers of the stomach, small intestine, liver and biliary tract, brain, breast, prostate, and adrenal cortex; and sebaceous skin tumors (Muir-Torre syndrome).[<a href="#cit/section_2.121">

2189121</a>

2190-<a href="#cit/section_2.127">

2191127</a>

2192]</p>

2193<p id="_2705" tabindex="-1">

2194<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460154&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460154&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2195Germline</a>

2196 pathogenic variants in the genes responsible for these autosomal dominant cancer syndromes produce different clinical <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460203&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460203&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2197phenotypes</a>

2198 of characteristic malignancies and, in some instances, associated nonmalignant abnormalities.</p>

2199<p id="_20" tabindex="-1">

2200The family characteristics that suggest hereditary cancer predisposition include the following:

2201</p>

2202<div class="pdq-content-list">

2203<ul id="_21">

2204<li>

2205Multiple cancers within a family.</li>

2206<li>

2207Cancers typically occur at an earlier age than in

2208sporadic cases (defined as cases not associated with genetic risk).

2209</li>

2210<li>

2211Two or more primary

2212cancers in a single individual. These could be multiple

2213primary cancers of the same type (e.g., bilateral breast cancer) or

2214primary cancer of different types (e.g., breast cancer and ovarian cancer in

2215the same individual or endometrial and colon cancer in the same individual).

2216</li>

2217<li>

2218Cases of male breast cancer. The inheritance risk for autosomal dominant genetic conditions is 50% for both males and females, but the differing penetrance of the genes may result in some <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460224&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460224&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2219unaffected</a>

2220 individuals in the family.</li>

2221</ul>

2222</div>

2223<p id="_2584" tabindex="-1">

2224<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2585">

2225Figure 1</a>

2226 and <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2586">

2227Figure 2</a>

2228 depict some of the classic inheritance features of a <em class="gene-name">

2229BRCA1</em>

2230 and <em class="gene-name">

2231BRCA2</em>

2232 pathogenic variant, respectively. <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2748">

2233Figure 3</a>

2234 depicts a classic family with Lynch syndrome. (Refer to the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/risk-assessment-pdq#_1237">

2235Standard Pedigree Nomenclature</a>

2236 figure in Cancer Genetics Risk Assessment and Counseling for definitions of the standard symbols used in these <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44868&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044868&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2237pedigrees</a>

2238.)</p>

2239<figure id="figure_2585" class="image-center">

2240<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/746227.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

2241Enlarge</a>

2242<img id="_2585" alt="Pedigree showing some of the classic features of a family with a deleterious BRCA1 mutation across three generations, including transmission occurring through maternal and paternal lineages. The unaffected female proband is shown as having an affected mother (breast cancer diagnosed at age 42 y), female cousin (breast cancer diagnosed at age 38 y), maternal aunt (ovarian cancer diagnosed at age 53 y), and maternal grandmother (ovarian cancer diagnosed at age 49 y)." title="Pedigree showing some of the classic features of a family with a deleterious BRCA1 mutation across three generations, including transmission occurring through maternal and paternal lineages. The unaffected female proband is shown as having an affected mother (breast cancer diagnosed at age 42 y), female cousin (breast cancer diagnosed at age 38 y), maternal aunt (ovarian cancer diagnosed at age 53 y), and maternal grandmother (ovarian cancer diagnosed at age 49 y)." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/746227-750.jpg">

2243<figcaption class="caption-container">

2244Figure 1. <em class="gene-name">

2245BRCA1</em>

2246 pedigree. This pedigree shows some of the classic features of a family with a <em class="gene-name">

2247BRCA1</em>

2248 pathogenic variant across three generations, including affected family members with breast cancer or ovarian cancer and a young age at onset. <em class="gene-name">

2249BRCA1</em>

2250 families may exhibit some or all of these features. As an autosomal dominant syndrome, a <em class="gene-name">

2251BRCA1</em>

2252 pathogenic variant can be transmitted through maternal or paternal lineages, as depicted in the figure.</figcaption>

2253</figure>

2254<figure id="figure_2586" class="image-center">

2255<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/746236.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

2256Enlarge</a>

2257<img id="_2586" alt="Pedigree showing some of the classic features of a family with a deleterious BRCA2 mutation across three generations, including transmission occurring through maternal and paternal lineages. The unaffected female proband is shown as having an affected brother (breast cancer diagnosed at age 52 y), mother (breast cancer diagnosed at age 45 y and pancreatic cancer diagnosed at age 55 y), maternal aunt (ovarian cancer diagnosed at age 58 y), and maternal grandfather (prostate cancer diagnosed at age 55 y)." title="Pedigree showing some of the classic features of a family with a deleterious BRCA2 mutation across three generations, including transmission occurring through maternal and paternal lineages. The unaffected female proband is shown as having an affected brother (breast cancer diagnosed at age 52 y), mother (breast cancer diagnosed at age 45 y and pancreatic cancer diagnosed at age 55 y), maternal aunt (ovarian cancer diagnosed at age 58 y), and maternal grandfather (prostate cancer diagnosed at age 55 y)." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/746236-750.jpg">

2258<figcaption class="caption-container">

2259Figure 2. <em class="gene-name">

2260BRCA2</em>

2261 pedigree. This pedigree shows some of the classic features of a family with a <em class="gene-name">

2262BRCA2</em>

2263 pathogenic variant across three generations, including affected family members with breast (including male breast cancer), ovarian, pancreatic, or prostate cancers and a relatively young age at onset. <em class="gene-name">

2264BRCA2</em>

2265 families may exhibit some or all of these features. As an autosomal dominant syndrome, a <em class="gene-name">

2266BRCA2</em>

2267 pathogenic variant can be transmitted through maternal or paternal lineages, as depicted in the figure.</figcaption>

2268</figure>
