2269<figure id="figure_2748" class="image-center">

2270<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/766496.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

2271Enlarge</a>

2272<img id="_2748" alt="Pedigree showing some of the classic features of a family with Lynch syndrome across three generations, including transmission occurring through maternal and paternal lineages and the presence of both colon and endometrial cancers." title="Pedigree showing some of the classic features of a family with Lynch syndrome across three generations, including transmission occurring through maternal and paternal lineages and the presence of both colon and endometrial cancers." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/766496-750.jpg">

2273<figcaption class="caption-container">

2274Figure 3. Lynch syndrome pedigree. This pedigree shows some of the classic features of a family with Lynch syndrome, including affected family members with colon cancer or endometrial cancer, a young age at onset in some individuals, and incomplete penetrance. Lynch syndrome families may exhibit some or all of these features. Lynch syndrome families may also include individuals with other gastrointestinal, gynecologic, and genitourinary cancers, or other extracolonic cancers. As an autosomal dominant syndrome, Lynch syndrome can be transmitted through maternal or paternal lineages, as depicted in the figure. Because the cancer risk is not 100%, individuals who have Lynch syndrome may not develop cancer, such as the mother of the female with colon cancer diagnosed at age 37 years in this pedigree (called incomplete penetrance).</figcaption>

2275</figure>

2276<p id="_789" tabindex="-1">

2277There are no <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=454769&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000454769&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2278pathognomonic</a>

2279 features distinguishing breast and ovarian cancers occurring in carriers of <em class="gene-name">

2280BRCA1</em>

2281 or <em class="gene-name">

2282BRCA2</em>

2283 pathogenic variants from those occurring in <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=556483&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000556483&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2284noncarriers</a>

2285. Breast cancers occurring in carriers of <em class="gene-name">

2286BRCA1</em>

2287 pathogenic variants are more likely to be ER-negative, progesterone receptor (PR)&#8211;negative, human epidermal growth factor receptor two (HER2/neu)&#8211;negative (i.e., <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=639916&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000639916&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2288triple-negative breast cancers</a>

2289 [TNBC]), and have a basal phenotype. <em class="gene-name">

2290BRCA1</em>

2291-associated ovarian cancers are more likely to be high-grade and of serous histopathology. (Refer to the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq#_3473">

2292<em class="gene-name">

2293BRCA1/2</em>

2294-associated breast cancer pathology</a>

2295 and <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq#_3476">

2296Pathologies of <em class="gene-name">

2297BRCA1/2</em>

2298-associated ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancers</a>

2299 sections in <em class="gene-name">

2300BRCA1</em>

2301 and <em class="gene-name">

2302BRCA2</em>

2303: Cancer Risks and Management for more information.)</p>

2304<p id="_2706" tabindex="-1">

2305Some pathologic features distinguish carriers of Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated pathogenic variants from noncarriers. The hallmark feature of endometrial cancers occurring in Lynch syndrome is mismatch repair (MMR) deficiencies, including the presence of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=285933&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000285933&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2306microsatellite instability</a>

2307 (MSI), and the absence of specific MMR proteins. In addition to these molecular changes, there are also histologic changes including tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes, peritumoral lymphocytes, undifferentiated tumor histology, lower uterine segment origin, and synchronous tumors. </p>

2308</section>

2309<section id="_22">

2310<h3 id="_22_toc">

2311Considerations in Risk Assessment and in Identifying a Family History of Breast and Ovarian Cancer Risk</h3>

2312<p id="_23" tabindex="-1">

2313The accuracy and completeness of family histories must be considered when they are used to assess risk. A reported family history may be erroneous, or a person may be unaware of relatives affected with cancer. In

2314addition, small family sizes and premature deaths may limit the information

2315obtained from a family history. Breast or ovarian cancer on the

2316paternal side of the family usually involves more distant relatives than does breast or ovarian cancer on the

2317maternal side, so information may be more difficult to obtain.

2318When self-reported information is compared with independently verified cases, the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=322883&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000322883&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2319sensitivity</a>

2320 of a history of breast cancer is relatively high, at 83% to 97%, but lower for ovarian cancer, at 60%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.128">

2321128</a>

2322,<a href="#cit/section_2.129">

2323129</a>

2324] Additional limitations of relying on family histories include adoption; families with a small number of women; limited access to family history information; and incidental removal of the uterus, ovaries, and/or fallopian tubes for noncancer indications. Family histories will evolve; therefore, it is important to update family histories from both parents over time. (Refer to the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/risk-assessment-pdq#_340">

2325Accuracy of the family history</a>

2326 section in Cancer Genetics Risk Assessment and Counseling for more information.)</p>

2327</section>

2328<section id="_66">

2329<h3 id="_66_toc">

2330Models for Prediction of Breast and Gynecologic Cancer Risk</h3>

2331<p id="_634" tabindex="-1">

2332Models to predict an individual&#8217;s lifetime risk of developing breast and/or gynecologic cancer are available.[<a href="#cit/section_2.130">

2333130</a>

2334-<a href="#cit/section_2.133">

2335133</a>

2336] In addition, models exist to predict an individual&#8217;s likelihood of having a pathogenic variant in <em class="gene-name">

2337BRCA1</em>

2338, <em class="gene-name">

2339BRCA2</em>

2340, or one of the MMR genes associated with Lynch syndrome. (Refer to the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_3794">

2341Models for prediction of the likelihood of a <em class="gene-name">

2342BRCA1</em>

2343 or <em class="gene-name">

2344BRCA2</em>

2345 pathogenic variant</a>

2346 section of this summary for more information about some of these models.) Not all models can be appropriately applied to all patients. Each model is appropriate only when the patient&#8217;s characteristics and family history are similar to those of the study population on which the model was based. Different models may provide widely varying risk estimates for the same clinical scenario, and the validation of these estimates has not been performed for many models.[<a href="#cit/section_2.131">

2347131</a>

2348,<a href="#cit/section_2.134">

2349134</a>

2350,<a href="#cit/section_2.135">

2351135</a>

2352] </p>

2353<section id="_2824">

2354<h4 id="_2824_toc">

2355Breast cancer risk assessment models</h4>

2356<p id="_2737" tabindex="-1">

2357In general, breast cancer <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460214&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460214&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2358risk assessment</a>

2359 models are designed for two types of populations: 1) women without a pathogenic variant or strong family history of breast or ovarian cancer; and 2) women at higher risk because of a personal or family history of breast cancer or ovarian cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.135">

2360135</a>

2361] Models designed for women of the first type (e.g., the Gail model, which is the basis for the Breast Cancer Risk Assessment

2362Tool [BCRAT] [<a href="#cit/section_2.136">

2363136</a>

2364], and the Colditz and Rosner model [<a href="#cit/section_2.137">

2365137</a>

2366]) require only limited information about family history (e.g., number of FDRs with breast cancer). Models designed for women at higher risk require more detailed information about personal and family cancer history of breast and ovarian cancers, including ages at onset of cancer and/or carrier status of specific breast cancer-susceptibility <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339337&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339337&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2367alleles</a>

2368. The genetic factors used by the latter models differ, with some assuming one risk <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460162&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460162&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2369locus</a>

2370 (e.g., the Claus model [<a href="#cit/section_2.138">

2371138</a>

2372]), others assuming two loci (e.g., the International Breast Cancer Intervention Study [IBIS] model [<a href="#cit/section_2.139">

2373139</a>

2374] and the BRCAPRO model [<a href="#cit/section_2.140">

2375140</a>

2376]), and still others assuming an additional polygenic component in addition to multiple loci (e.g., the Breast and Ovarian Analysis of Disease Incidence and Carrier Estimation Algorithm [BOADICEA] model [<a href="#cit/section_2.141">

2377141</a>

2378-<a href="#cit/section_2.143">

2379143</a>

2380]). The models also differ in whether they include information about nongenetic risk factors. Three models (Gail/BCRAT, Pfeiffer,[<a href="#cit/section_2.133">

2381133</a>

2382] and IBIS) include nongenetic risk factors but differ in the risk factors they include (e.g., the Pfeiffer model includes alcohol consumption, whereas the Gail/BCRAT does not). These models have limited ability to discriminate between individuals who are affected and those who are unaffected with cancer; a model with high discrimination would be close to 1, and a model with little discrimination would be close to 0.5; the discrimination of the models currently ranges between 0.56 and 0.63).[<a href="#cit/section_2.144">

2383144</a>

2384]

2385The existing models generally are more accurate in prospective studies that have assessed how well they predict future cancers.[<a href="#cit/section_2.135">

2386135</a>

2387,<a href="#cit/section_2.145">

2388145</a>

2389-<a href="#cit/section_2.147">

2390147</a>

2391] An analysis comparing the 10-year performance of the BOADICEA, BRCAPRO, BCRAT, and IBIS models demonstrated superiority of the models with more detailed pedigree inclusion&#8212;specifically, BOADICEA and IBIS.[<a href="#cit/section_2.148">

2392148</a>

2393]</p>

2394<p id="_635" tabindex="-1">

2395In the United States, BRCAPRO, the Claus model,[<a href="#cit/section_2.138">

2396138</a>

2397,<a href="#cit/section_2.149">

2398149</a>

2399] and the Gail/BCRAT [<a href="#cit/section_2.136">

2400136</a>

2401] are widely used in clinical <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44961&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044961&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2402counseling</a>

2403. Risk estimates derived from the models differ for an individual patient. Several other models that include more detailed family history information are also in use and are discussed below.</p>

2404<section id="_2825">

2405<h5 id="_2825_toc">

2406Additional considerations for clinical use of breast cancer risk assessment models</h5>

2407<p id="_640" tabindex="-1">

2408The Gail model is the basis for the <a href="https://bcrisktool.cancer.gov/" title="https://bcrisktool.cancer.gov/">

2409BCRAT</a>

2410, a computer program available from the National Cancer Institute by calling the Cancer Information Service at 1-800-4-CANCER (1-800-422-6237). This version of the Gail model estimates only the risk of invasive breast cancer. The Gail/BCRAT model has been found to be reasonably accurate at predicting breast cancer risk in large groups of White women who undergo annual screening mammography; however, reliability varies depending on the cohort studied.[<a href="#cit/section_2.150">

2411150</a>

2412-<a href="#cit/section_2.155">

2413155</a>

2414] Risk can be overestimated in the following populations:</p>

2415<div class="pdq-content-list">

2416<ul id="_641">

2417<li>

2418Women who do not adhere to screening recommendations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.150">

2419150</a>

2420,<a href="#cit/section_2.151">

2421151</a>

2422]</li>

2423<li>

2424Women in the highest-risk strata.[<a href="#cit/section_2.153">

2425153</a>

2426]</li>

2427</ul>

2428</div>

2429<p id="_2826" tabindex="-1">

2430The Gail/BCRAT model is valid for women aged 35 years and older. The model was primarily developed for White women.[<a href="#cit/section_2.154">

2431154</a>

2432] Extensions of the Gail model for African American women have been subsequently developed to calibrate risk estimates using data from more than 1,600 African American women with invasive breast cancer and more than 1,600 controls.[<a href="#cit/section_2.156">

2433156</a>

2434] Additionally, extensions of the Gail model have incorporated high-risk <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=803525&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000803525&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2435single nucleotide variants</a>

2436 (SNVs) and pathogenic variants; however, no software exists to calculate risk in these extended models.[<a href="#cit/section_2.157">

2437157</a>

2438,<a href="#cit/section_2.158">

2439158</a>

2440] Other risk assessment models incorporating breast density have been developed but are not ready for clinical use.[<a href="#cit/section_2.159">

2441159</a>

2442,<a href="#cit/section_2.160">

2443160</a>

2444]</p>

2445<p id="_2827" tabindex="-1">

2446Generally, the Gail/BCRAT model should not be the sole model used for families with one or more of the following characteristics:</p>

2447<div class="pdq-content-list">

2448<ul id="_2828">

2449<li>

2450Multiple affected individuals with breast cancer or ovarian cancer (especially when one or more breast cancers are diagnosed before age 50 y).</li>

2451<li>

2452A woman with both breast and ovarian cancer.</li>

2453<li>

2454<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460127&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460127&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2455Ashkenazi Jewish</a>

2456 ancestry with at least one case of breast or ovarian cancer (as these families are more likely to have a hereditary cancer susceptibility syndrome).</li>

2457</ul>

2458</div>

2459<p id="_2829" tabindex="-1">

2460Commonly used models that incorporate family history include the IBIS, BOADICEA, and BRCAPRO models. The IBIS/Tyrer-Cuzick model incorporates both genetic and nongenetic factors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.139">

2461139</a>

2462] A three-generation pedigree is used to estimate the likelihood that an individual carries either a <em class="gene-name">

2463BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

2464 pathogenic variant or a hypothetical low-penetrance gene. In addition, the model incorporates personal risk factors such as parity, body mass index (BMI); height; and age at menarche, first live birth, menopause, and HRT use. Both genetic and nongenetic factors are combined to develop a risk estimate. The BOADICEA model examines family history to estimate breast cancer risk and also incorporates both <em class="gene-name">

2465BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

2466 and non-<em class="gene-name">

2467BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

2468 genetic risk factors.[<a href="#cit/section_2.142">

2469142</a>

2470] The most important difference between BOADICEA and the other models using information on <em class="gene-name">

2471BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

2472 is that BOADICEA assumes an additional polygenic component in addition to multiple loci,[<a href="#cit/section_2.141">

2473141</a>

2474-<a href="#cit/section_2.143">

2475143</a>

2476] which is more in line with what is known about the underlying genetics of breast cancer. The BOADICEA model has also been expanded to include additional pathogenic variants, including <em class="gene-name">

2477CHEK2</em>

2478, <em class="gene-name">

2479ATM</em>

2480, and <em class="gene-name">

2481PALB2</em>

2482.[<a href="#cit/section_2.161">

2483161</a>

2484] However, the discrimination and calibration for these models differ significantly when compared in independent samples;[<a href="#cit/section_2.145">

2485145</a>

2486] the IBIS and BOADICEA models are more comparable when estimating risk over a shorter fixed time horizon (e.g., 10 years),[<a href="#cit/section_2.145">

2487145</a>

2488] than when estimating remaining lifetime risk. As all risk assessment models for cancers are typically validated over a shorter time horizon (e.g., 5 or 10 years), fixed time horizon estimates rather than remaining lifetime risk may be more accurate and useful measures to convey in a clinical setting.</p>

2489<p id="_2830" tabindex="-1">

2490In addition, readily available models that provide information about an individual woman&#8217;s risk in relation to the population-level risk depending on her risk factors may be useful in a clinical setting (e.g., <a href="https://siteman.wustl.edu/prevention/ydr/" title="https://siteman.wustl.edu/prevention/ydr/">

2491Your Disease Risk</a>

2492). Although this tool was developed using information about average-risk women and does not calculate AR estimates, it still may be useful when counseling women about cancer prevention. Risk assessment models are being developed and validated in large cohorts to integrate genetic and nongenetic data, breast density, and other biomarkers.</p>

2493<p id="_3318" tabindex="-1">

2494Although most breast cancer risk models have been shown to be well calibrated overall, model performance can be different for subgroups of women. In particular, independent, prospective validation of risk models for women who tested negative for <em class="gene-name">

2495BRCA1</em>

2496 or <em class="gene-name">

2497BRCA2</em>

2498 pathogenic variants supported that the most commonly used clinical risk models underpredicted risk for this group of women.[<a href="#cit/section_2.162">

2499162</a>

2500] The performance also differed on the basis of whether the test results of relatives were known. The models also underpredicted risk by 26.3% to 56.7% in women who tested negative but whose relatives had not been tested. </p>

2501</section>

2502</section>

2503<section id="_2831">

2504<h4 id="_2831_toc">

2505Ovarian cancer risk assessment models</h4>

2506<p id="_2758" tabindex="-1">

2507Two risk prediction models have been developed for ovarian cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.132">

2508132</a>

2509,<a href="#cit/section_2.133">

2510133</a>

2511]

2512 The Rosner model [<a href="#cit/section_2.132">

2513132</a>

2514]

2515 included age at menopause, age at menarche, oral contraception use, and tubal ligation; the concordance statistic was 0.60 (0.57&#8211;0.62). The Pfeiffer model [<a href="#cit/section_2.133">

2516133</a>

2517]

2518 included oral contraceptive use, menopausal HRT use, and family history of breast cancer or ovarian cancer, with a similar discriminatory power of 0.59 (0.56&#8211;0.62). Although both models were well calibrated, their modest discriminatory power limited their screening potential. </p>

2519</section>

2520<section id="_2832">

2521<h4 id="_2832_toc">

2522Endometrial cancer risk assessment models</h4>

2523<p id="_2777" tabindex="-1">

2524The Pfeiffer model has been used to predict endometrial cancer risk in the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_2.133">

2525133</a>

2526] For endometrial cancer, the RR model included BMI, menopausal HRT use, menopausal status, age at menopause, smoking status, and OC use. The discriminatory power of the model was 0.68 (0.66&#8211;0.70); it overestimated observed endometrial cancers in most subgroups but underestimated disease in women with the highest BMI category, in premenopausal women, and in women taking menopausal HRT for 10 years or more.</p>

2527<p id="_2778" tabindex="-1">

2528In contrast, MMRpredict, PREMM5 (PREdiction Model for gene Mutations), and MMRpro are three quantitative predictive models used to identify individuals who may potentially have Lynch syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_2.163">

2529163</a>

2530-<a href="#cit/section_2.165">

2531165</a>

2532] MMRpredict incorporates only colorectal cancer patients but does include MSI and immunohistochemistry (IHC) tumor testing results. PREMM5 is an update of PREMM (1,2,6) and includes each of the five genes associated with Lynch syndrome, including <em class="gene-name">

2533PMS2</em>

2534 and <em class="gene-name">

2535EPCAM</em>

2536. It accounts for other Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated tumors but does not include tumor testing results.[<a href="#cit/section_2.164">

2537164</a>

2538] MMRpro incorporates tumor testing and germline testing results, but is more time intensive because it includes affected and unaffected individuals in the risk-quantification process. All three predictive models are comparable to the traditional Amsterdam and Bethesda criteria in identifying individuals with colorectal cancer who carry MMR gene pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_2.166">

2539166</a>

2540]

2541However, because these models were developed and validated in colorectal cancer patients, the discriminative abilities of these models to identify Lynch syndrome are lower among individuals with endometrial cancer than among those with colon cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.167">

2542167</a>

2543]

2544In fact, the sensitivity and <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=322884&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000322884&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2545specificity</a>

2546 of MSI and IHC in identifying carriers of pathogenic variants are considerably higher than the prediction models and support the use of molecular tumor testing to screen for Lynch syndrome in women with endometrial cancer.</p>

2547</section>

2548<p id="_2738" tabindex="-1">

2549<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2836">

2550Table 1</a>

2551 summarizes salient aspects of breast and gynecologic cancer risk assessment models that are commonly used in the clinical setting. These models differ by the extent of family history included, whether nongenetic risk factors are included, and whether carrier status and polygenic risk are included (inputs to the models). The models also differ in the type of risk estimates that are generated (outputs of the models). These factors may be relevant in choosing the model that best applies to a particular individual.</p>

2552<table id="_2836" class="table-default expandable-container">

2553<caption>

2554Table 1. Summary of Prediction Models Used to Calculate Age-Specific Absolute Risks of Breast and Gynecologic Cancers</caption>

2555<colgroup>

2556<col width="48.75%">

2557<col width="8.16%">

2558<col width="8.38%">

2559<col width="7.35%">

2560<col width="27.35%">

2561</colgroup>

2562<THead>

2563<tr>

2564<th>

2565Model </th>

2566<th>

2567Family History (input) </th>

2568<th>

2569Pathogenic Variants (input) </th>

2570<th>

2571Risk Factors (input) </th>

2572<th>

2573Risk Estimate Generated (output)</th>

2574</tr>

2575</THead>

2580</tr>

2581<tr>

2583<span class="sup">

2584a</span>

2585High risk is defined as those with a personal or family history of the designated cancer type.</td>

2586</tr>

2671<tr>

2674BRCAPRO</a>

2675 </td>

2676<td>

2677Multigenerational (breast, ovarian cancers)</td>

2678<td>

2679<em class="gene-name">

2680BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

2681 </td>

2683No</td>

2686BRCA1</em>

2690</tr>

2691<tr>

2694IBIS</a>

2695 </td>

2696<td>

2697Multigenerational (ovarian cancer)</td>

2698<td>

2699<em class="gene-name">

2700BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

2701 </td>

2702<td>

2703Yes</td>

2704<td>

2705Breast cancer; % risk of carrying <em class="gene-name">

2706BRCA1</em>

2707/<em class="gene-name">

2708BRCA2</em>

2710</tr>

2711<tr>

2712<td>

2713<a href="http://ccge.medschl.cam.ac.uk/boadicea/" title="http://ccge.medschl.cam.ac.uk/boadicea/">

2714BOADICEA</a>

2715<span class="sup">

2716b</span>

2717

2718

2719</td>

2720<td>

2721Multigenerational (pancreatic, breast, ovarian cancers)</td>

2722<td>

2723<em class="gene-name">

2724BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

2725 </td>

2726<td>

2727No</td>

2728<td>

2729Breast and ovarian cancer; % risk of carrying <em class="gene-name">

2730BRCA1</em>

2732BRCA2</em>

2733 pathogenic variant</td>

2734</tr>

2735<tr>

2736<td colspan="5">

2737<strong>

2738Ovarian Cancer Risk Assessment Models</strong>

2739</td>

2740</tr>

2741<tr>

2742<td colspan="5" align="Left" scope="col">

2743<em>

2744Models for Average-Risk Women</em>

2745</td>

2746</tr>

2747<tr>

2748<td>

2749Rosner [<a href="#cit/section_2.132">

2750132</a>

2751]</td>

2752<td>

2753None

2754

2755</td>

2756<td>

2757No</td>

2758<td>

2759Yes</td>

2760<td>

2761Ovarian cancer </td>

2762</tr>

2763<tr>

2764<td>

2765Pfeiffer (ovarian) [<a href="#cit/section_2.133">

2766133</a>

2767]</td>

2768<td>

2769First-degree relatives (breast, ovarian cancers)</td>

2770<td>

2771No</td>

2772<td>

2773Yes</td>

2774<td>

2775Breast cancer </td>

2776</tr>

2777<tr>

2778<td colspan="5" align="Left" scope="col">

2779<em>

2780Models for High-Risk Women<span class="sup">

2781a</span>

2782 </em>

2783</td>

2784</tr>

2785<tr>

2786<td>

2787<a href="http://ccge.medschl.cam.ac.uk/boadicea/" title="http://ccge.medschl.cam.ac.uk/boadicea/">

2788BOADICEA</a>

2789<span class="sup">

2790b</span>

2791</td>

2794<td>

2795<em class="gene-name">

2796BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

2797 </td>

2798<td>

2799No</td>

2800<td>

2801Breast and ovarian cancer; % risk of carrying <em class="gene-name">

2802BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

2803 pathogenic variant</td>

2804</tr>

2805<tr>

2808Endometrial Cancer Risk Assessment Models</strong>

2809</td>

2810</tr>

2811<tr>

2812<td colspan="5" align="Left" scope="col">

2813<em>

2814Models for Average-Risk Women</em>

2815</td>

2816</tr>

2818<td>

2820(endometrial) [<a href="#cit/section_2.133">

2821133</a>

2901</tbody>

2902</table>

2903</section>

2904<section id="_3794">

2905<h3 id="_3794_toc">

2906Models for Predicting the Likelihood of a <em class="gene-name">

2907BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

2908 Pathogenic Variant</h3>

2909<p id="_3795" tabindex="-1">

2910Many models have been developed to predict the probability of identifying germline <em class="gene-name">

2911BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

2912 pathogenic variants in individuals or families. These models include those using logistic regression,[<a href="#cit/section_2.140">

2913140</a>

2914,<a href="#cit/section_2.168">

2915168</a>

2916-<a href="#cit/section_2.173">

2917173</a>

2918] genetic models using Bayesian analysis (BRCAPRO and BOADICEA),[<a href="#cit/section_2.140">

2919140</a>

2920,<a href="#cit/section_2.142">

2921142</a>

2922] and empiric observations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.174">

2923174</a>

2924-<a href="#cit/section_2.179">

2925179</a>

2926]

2927

2928 </p>

2929<p id="_3796" tabindex="-1">

2930 In addition to BOADICEA, BRCAPRO is commonly used for genetic counseling in the clinical setting. BRCAPRO and BOADICEA predict the probability of being a carrier and produce estimates of breast cancer risk (refer to <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_3800">

2931Table 2</a>

2932). The discrimination and accuracy (factors used to evaluate the performance of prediction models) of these models are much higher for their ability to report on carrier status than for their ability to predict fixed or remaining lifetime risk.</p>

2933<p id="_3797" tabindex="-1">

2934BOADICEA is a polygenetic model that uses complex <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=712689&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000712689&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2935segregation analysis</a>

2936 to examine both breast cancer risk and the probability of having a <em class="gene-name">

2937BRCA1</em>

2938 or <em class="gene-name">

2939BRCA2</em>

2940 pathogenic variant.[<a href="#cit/section_2.142">

2941142</a>

2942] Even among experienced providers, the use of prediction models has been shown to increase the power to discriminate which patients are most likely to be carriers of <em class="gene-name">

2943BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

2944 pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_2.180">

2945180</a>

2946,<a href="#cit/section_2.181">

2947181</a>

2948] Most models do not include other cancers seen in the <em class="gene-name">

2949BRCA1</em>

2950 and <em class="gene-name">

2951BRCA2</em>

2952 spectrum, such as pancreatic cancer and prostate cancer. Interventions that decrease the likelihood that an individual will develop cancer (such as oophorectomy and mastectomy) may influence the ability to predict <em class="gene-name">

2953BRCA1</em>

2954 and <em class="gene-name">

2955BRCA2</em>

2956 pathogenic variant status.[<a href="#cit/section_2.182">

2957182</a>

2958] One study has shown that the prediction models for genetic risk are sensitive to the amount of family history data available and do not perform as well with limited family information.[<a href="#cit/section_2.183">

2959183</a>

2960] BOADICEA is being expanded to incorporate additional risk variants (<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=636779&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000636779&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2961genome-wide association studies</a>

2962 [GWAS] and SNVs) to better predict pathogenic variant status and to improve the accuracy of breast cancer and ovarian cancer risk estimates.[<a href="#cit/section_2.184">

2963184</a>

2964]</p>

2965<p id="_3798" tabindex="-1">

2966The performance of the models can vary in specific ethnic groups. The BRCAPRO model appeared to best fit a series of French Canadian families.[<a href="#cit/section_2.185">

2967185</a>

2968] There have been variable results in the performance of the BRCAPRO model among Hispanic individuals,[<a href="#cit/section_2.186">

2969186</a>

2970,<a href="#cit/section_2.187">

2971187</a>

2972] and both the BRCAPRO model and Myriad tables underestimated the proportion of carriers of pathogenic variants in an Asian American population.[<a href="#cit/section_2.188">

2973188</a>

2974] BOADICEA was developed and validated in British women. Thus, the major models used for both overall risk (<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2836">

2975Table 1</a>

2976) and genetic risk (<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_3800">

2977Table 2</a>

2978) have not been developed or validated in large populations of racially and ethnically diverse women. Of the commonly used clinical models for assessing genetic risk, only the Tyrer-Cuzick model contains nongenetic risk factors.</p>

2979<p id="_3799" tabindex="-1">

2980The power of several of the models has been compared in different studies.[<a href="#cit/section_2.189">

2981189</a>

2982-<a href="#cit/section_2.192">

2983192</a>

2984] Four breast cancer genetic-risk models, BOADICEA, BRCAPRO, IBIS, and eCLAUS, were evaluated for their diagnostic accuracy in predicting <em class="gene-name">

2985BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

2986 pathogenic variants in a cohort of 7,352 German families.[<a href="#cit/section_2.193">

2987193</a>

2988] The family member with the highest likelihood of carrying a pathogenic variant from each family was screened for <em class="gene-name">

2989BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

2990 pathogenic variants. Carrier probabilities from each model were calculated and compared with the actual variants detected. BRCAPRO and BOADICEA had significantly higher diagnostic accuracy than IBIS or eCLAUS. Accuracy for the BOADICEA model was further improved when statuses of the tumor markers ER, PR, and HER2/neu were included in the model. The inclusion of these biomarkers has been shown to improve the performance of BRCAPRO.[<a href="#cit/section_2.194">

2991194</a>

2992,<a href="#cit/section_2.195">

2993195</a>

2994]</p>

2995<table id="_3800" class="table-default expandable-container">

2996<caption>

2997Table 2. Characteristics of Common Models for Estimating the Likelihood of a <em class="gene-name">

2998BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

2999 Pathogenic Variant</caption>

3000<colgroup>

3001<col width="20.00%">

3002<col width="20.00%">

3003<col width="20.00%">

3004<col width="20.00%">

3005<col width="20.00%">

3006</colgroup>

3013170</a>

3014]</th>

3015<th>

3016BRCAPRO [<a href="#cit/section_2.140">

3017140</a>

3018,<a href="#cit/section_2.182">

3019182</a>

3020]</th>

3021<th>

3022BOADICEA [<a href="#cit/section_2.140">

3023140</a>

3024,<a href="#cit/section_2.142">

3025142</a>

3026]</th>

3027<th>

3028Tyrer-Cuzick [<a href="#cit/section_2.139">

3029139</a>

3030]</th>

3039<tbody>

3046Empiric data from Myriad Genetics based on personal and family history reported on requisition forms</td>

3047<td>

3048Statistical model, assumes autosomal dominant inheritance</td>

3058</td>

3059<td>

3061Proband</a>

3062 may or may not have breast or ovarian cancer </td>

3063<td>

3065<td>

3067<td>

3068Proband must be <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460224&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460224&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3069unaffected</a>

3070 </td>

3071</tr>

3072<tr>

3073<td>

3074Considers age of breast cancer diagnosis as &lt;50 y, &gt;50 y </td>

3075<td>

3076Considers exact age at breast and ovarian cancer diagnosis </td>

3077<td>

3078Considers exact age at breast and ovarian cancer diagnosis </td>

3079<td>

3080Also includes reproductive factors and body mass index to estimate breast cancer risk </td>

3081</tr>

3082<tr>

3083<td>

3084Considers breast cancer in &#8805;1 affected relative only if diagnosed &lt;50 y </td>

3086Considers prior genetic testing in family (i.e., <em class="gene-name">

3087BRCA1/BRCA</em>

30882 pathogenic variant&#8211;negative relatives) </td>

3089<td>

3090Includes all <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=536514&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000536514&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3091FDR</a>

3092 and <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=485396&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000485396&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3093SDR</a>

3094 with and without cancer </td>

3095<td>

3096&#160;</td>

3097</tr>

3098<tr>

3099<td>

3100Considers ovarian cancer in &#8805;1 relative at any age </td>

3101<td>

3102Considers oophorectomy status </td>

3103<td>

3104Includes AJ ancestry </td>

3105<td>

3106&#160;</td>

3107</tr>

3108<tr>

3109<td>

3110Includes AJ ancestry </td>

3111<td>

3112Includes all FDR and SDR with and without cancer </td>

3113<td>

3114&#160;</td>

3115<td>

3116&#160;</td>

3117</tr>

3118<tr>

3119<td>

3120Very easy to use </td>

3121<td>

3122Includes AJ ancestry </td>

3123<td>

3124&#160;</td>

3125<td>

3126&#160;</td>

3127</tr>

3128<tr>

3129<td rowspan="5">

3130<strong>

3131Limitations</strong>

3132</td>

3133<td rowspan="3">

3134Simplified/limited consideration of family structure</td>

3135<td>

3136Requires computer software and time-consuming

3137data entry </td>

3138<td rowspan="3">

3139Requires computer software and time-consuming data entry</td>

3140<td rowspan="5">

3141Designed for individuals unaffected with breast cancer </td>

3142</tr>

3143<tr>

3144<td>

3145Incorporates only FDR and SDR; may need to change proband to best capture risk and to account for disease in the paternal lineage </td>

3146</tr>

3147<tr>

3148<td>

3149May overestimate risk in bilateral breast cancer [<a href="#cit/section_2.196">

3150196</a>

3151] </td>

3152</tr>

3153<tr>

3154<td rowspan="2">

3155Early age of breast cancer onset </td>

3156<td>

3157May perform better in White populations than in racial and ethnic minority populations [<a href="#cit/section_2.187">

3158187</a>

3159,<a href="#cit/section_2.197">

3160197</a>

3161]

3162

3163</td>

3164<td rowspan="2">

3165Incorporates only FDR and SDR; may need to change proband to best capture risk </td>

3166</tr>

3167<tr>

3168<td>

3169May underestimate risk of <em class="gene-name">

3170BRCA</em>

3171 pathogenic variant in high-grade serous ovarian cancers but overestimate the risk for other histologies [<a href="#cit/section_2.198">

3172198</a>

3173]</td>

3174</tr>

3175</tbody>

3176</table>

3177<p id="_3801" tabindex="-1">

3178Genetic testing for <em class="gene-name">

3179BRCA1</em>

3180 and <em class="gene-name">

3181BRCA2</em>

3182 pathogenic variants has been available to the public since 1996. As more individuals have undergone testing, risk assessment models have improved. This, in turn, gives providers better data to estimate an individual patient&#8217;s risk of carrying a pathogenic variant, but risk assessment continues to be an art. There are factors that might limit the ability to provide an accurate risk assessment (i.e., small family size, paucity of women, or ethnicity) including the specific circumstances of the individual patient (such as history of disease or risk-reducing surgeries).</p>

3183</section>

3184<section id="_3078">

3185<h3 id="_3078_toc">

3186Considerations When Conducting Genetic Testing</h3>

3187<section id="_3079">

3188<h4 id="_3079_toc">

3189Indications for hereditary breast and gynecologic cancers genetic testing </h4>

3190<p id="_3145" tabindex="-1">

3191Several professional organizations and expert panels&#8212;including the American Society of Clinical Oncology,[<a href="#cit/section_2.199">

3192199</a>

3193] the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN),[<a href="#cit/section_2.200">

3194200</a>

3195] the American Society of Human Genetics,[<a href="#cit/section_2.201">

3196201</a>

3197] the American College of Medical Genetics and Genomics,[<a href="#cit/section_2.202">

3198202</a>

3199] the National Society of Genetic Counselors,[<a href="#cit/section_2.202">

3200202</a>

3201] the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force,[<a href="#cit/section_2.203">

3202203</a>

3203] and the Society of Gynecologic Oncologists [<a href="#cit/section_2.204">

3204204</a>

3205] &#8212;have developed clinical criteria and practice guidelines that can be helpful to health care providers in identifying individuals who may have a <em class="gene-name">

3206BRCA1</em>

3207 or <em class="gene-name">

3208BRCA2</em>

3209 pathogenic variant.</p>

3210<p id="_3345" tabindex="-1">

3211In 2019, the American Society of Breast Surgeons published a recommendation to make genetic testing for &#8220;<em class="gene-name">

3212BRCA1</em>

3213/<em class="gene-name">

3214BRCA2</em>

3215, and <em class="gene-name">

3216PALB2</em>

3217, with other genes as appropriate for the clinical scenario and family history&#8221; available to all breast cancer patients.[<a href="#cit/section_2.205">

3218205</a>

3219] This recommendation was based on a study that suggested similar pathogenic variant rates identified through an extended multigene panel in patients with breast cancer who did or did not meet the NCCN guidelines for genetic testing.[<a href="#cit/section_2.206">

3220206</a>

3221] This study had important methodologic challenges that need to be considered, including exclusion of participants previously tested, uncertain accuracy of the reported risk criteria for study participants, inclusion of genes with uncertain management guidelines, and difference in the specific genes in which pathogenic or likely pathogenic variants were identified across the two groups. For example, there was a statistically significant difference between participants who met and who did not meet NCCN criteria in the detection of <em class="gene-name">

3222BRCA1</em>

3223/<em class="gene-name">

3224BRCA2</em>

3225 variants.</p>

3226<p id="_3346" tabindex="-1">

3227Other studies have also found that the NCCN criteria have good sensitivity when predicting <em class="gene-name">

3228BRCA1</em>

3229/<em class="gene-name">

3230BRCA2</em>

3231 variants; however, less is known about many other genes. For example, one study showed that the NCCN criteria were able to detect 88.9% of the <em class="gene-name">

3232BRCA1</em>

3233/<em class="gene-name">

3234BRCA2</em>

3235 pathogenic variant carriers [<a href="#cit/section_2.207">

3236207</a>

3237] and others have found that, if more than one NCCN criterion is met, then the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460206&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460206&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3238positive predictive value</a>

3239 does pass the 10% threshold (e.g., 12% for more than two NCCN criteria).[<a href="#cit/section_2.208">

3240208</a>

3241]</p>

3242<p id="_3347" tabindex="-1">

3243As the cost of genetic testing continues to decrease, there is a need for unbiased evidence to guide indications for testing, including the cost-benefit impact on screening, prevention, and treatment. Efforts to generate less biased evidence include a single institution study of 3,907 unselected women with breast cancer tested for nine breast cancer genes, including <em class="gene-name">

3244BRCA1</em>

3245/<em class="gene-name">

3246BRCA2</em>

3247, <em class="gene-name">

3248ATM</em>

3249, <em class="gene-name">

3250CDH1</em>

3251, <em class="gene-name">

3252CHEK2</em>

3253, <em class="gene-name">

3254NF1</em>

3255, <em class="gene-name">

3256PALB2</em>

3257, <em class="gene-name">

3258PTEN</em>

3259, and <em class="gene-name">

3260TP53</em>

3261.[<a href="#cit/section_2.209">

3262209</a>

3263] The study assessed the relative performance of NCCN genetic testing criteria as compared with the American Society of Breast Surgeons' recommendation to test all women aged 65 years or younger with breast cancer. The sensitivity of the criteria was defined as the proportion of individuals who met testing criteria and tested positive for a pathogenic or likely pathogenic variant of the total population of pathogenic or likely pathogenic variant carriers in the study, while the specificity was defined as the proportion of individuals who did not meet testing criteria and tested negative for a pathogenic or likely pathogenic variant of the total population of noncarriers in the study. High sensitivity and specificity are both important considerations; however, higher sensitivity leads to lower specificity, so it is important to balance these two factors.

3264Detection of <em class="gene-name">

3265BRCA1</em>

3266/<em class="gene-name">

3267BRCA2</em>

3268 pathogenic or likely pathogenic variants based on NCCN criteria had a sensitivity of 87% with a specificity of 53.5%; when expanded to the nine genes included in the study, sensitivity was 70% and specificity was 53.2%. When including all women diagnosed with breast cancer at age 65 or younger, the sensitivity to detect <em class="gene-name">

3269BRCA1</em>

3270/<em class="gene-name">

3271BRCA2</em>

3272 pathogenic or likely pathogenic variants increased to 98%, while the specificity dropped to 22%. Among those who did not meet NCCN criteria, 0.7% had pathogenic or likely pathogenic <em class="gene-name">

3273BRCA1</em>

3274/<em class="gene-name">

3275BRCA2</em>

3276 variants. </p>

3277<p id="_3348" tabindex="-1">

3278Another study to assess frequency of pathogenic or likely pathogenic variants among breast cancer patients included a nested case-control study conducted through the WHI cohort among women with (cases) and without (controls) invasive breast cancer. Participants were tested for pathogenic or likely pathogenic variants in ten breast cancer&#8211;associated genes, including <em class="gene-name">

3279BRCA1</em>

3280/<em class="gene-name">

3281BRCA2</em>

3282.[<a href="#cit/section_2.210">

3283210</a>

3284] The prevalence of pathogenic or likely pathogenic <em class="gene-name">

3285BRCA1</em>

3286/<em class="gene-name">

3287BRCA2</em>

3288 variants among those diagnosed with invasive breast cancer before age 65 years was 2.21%, compared with 1.09% among those diagnosed at age 65 years or older. In comparison, the frequency of pathogenic or likely pathogenic <em class="gene-name">

3289BRCA1</em>

3290/<em class="gene-name">

3291BRCA2</em>

3292 variants was 0.22% in the control group. Current genetic testing criteria detect <em class="gene-name">

3293BRCA</em>

3294 pathogenic variants. Although higher sensitivity is always desired, it is at the expense of specificity. Lower specificity leads to higher costs to achieve one positive genetic test.</p>

3295</section>

3296<section id="_3080">

3297<h4 id="_3080_toc">

3298Benefits of offering genetic testing at the time of cancer diagnosis</h4>

3299<p id="_3081" tabindex="-1">

3300At the time of a new cancer diagnosis, genetic testing for inherited cancer predisposition may guide patient care including decisions about surgery, chemotherapy and other biologics, and radiation treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_2.211">

3301211</a>

3302,<a href="#cit/section_2.212">

3303212</a>

3304] Among high-risk patients, the option of genetic testing is an important part of the shared decision-making process regarding cancer treatments at the time of diagnosis. Tools are available to facilitate decision making about genetic testing in this context.[<a href="#cit/section_2.213">

3305213</a>

3306]</p>

3307<section id="_3085">

3308<h5 id="_3085_toc">

3309Breast cancer diagnosis</h5>

3310<p id="_3086" tabindex="-1">

3311Benefits of offering genetic testing at the time of breast cancer diagnosis include, but are not limited to, the following:</p>

3312<div class="pdq-content-list">

3313<ol id="_3082">

3314<li>

3315<strong>

3316Surgery</strong>

3317: The identification of inherited susceptibility to breast cancer may influence surgical treatment decisions. As an example, the high risk of a second primary breast cancer among <em class="gene-name">

3318BRCA</em>

3319 pathogenic variant carriers, particularly those diagnosed at an early age, may influence their decision to choose a bilateral mastectomy (versus a lumpectomy or unilateral/subtotal mastectomy) for surgical treatment of their breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.214">

3320214</a>

3321] Discussion of RRSO is indicated,[<a href="#cit/section_2.215">

3322215</a>

3323] and referral to a gynecologic provider may be considered.</li>

3324<li>

3325<strong>

3326Chemotherapy and other biologics</strong>

3327: Medical treatments may be guided by the identification of a pathogenic variant in an inherited cancer predisposing gene. As an example, among <em class="gene-name">

3328BRCA</em>

3329 pathogenic variant carriers, breast cancer treatment may include the use of platinum-based agents.[<a href="#cit/section_2.216">

3330216</a>

3331] Furthermore, novel agents such as PARP inhibitors may be used in the treatment of metastatic breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.217">

3332217</a>

3333]</li>

3334<li>

3335<strong>

3336Radiation therapy</strong>

3337: Decisions about the use of radiation treatment may be guided by the presence of a pathogenic variant in an inherited breast cancer <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460209&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460209&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3338susceptibility gene</a>

3339. In particular, the poorer wound healing in irradiated breasts is an important consideration for those who may consider risk-reducing mastectomy with reconstruction. As an example, individuals with a pathogenic variant in <em class="gene-name">

3340TP53</em>

3341 may experience higher risks from radiation, including increased risks for subsequent new cancers.[<a href="#cit/section_2.218">

3342218</a>

3343,<a href="#cit/section_2.219">

3344219</a>

3345] Thus, identification of <em class="gene-name">

3346TP53</em>

3347 carriers in the context of an active breast cancer diagnosis may influence radiation treatment decisions and reconstruction options. </li>

3348</ol>

3349</div>

3350</section>

3351<section id="_3087">

3352<h5 id="_3087_toc">

3353Ovarian cancer diagnosis</h5>

3354<p id="_3164" tabindex="-1">

3355Benefits of offering genetic testing at the time of ovarian cancer diagnosis include, but are not limited to, the following:</p>

3356<div class="pdq-content-list">

3357<ol id="_3184">

3358<li>

3359<strong>

3360Surgery</strong>

3361: In most cases, the decision for ovarian cancer surgery is made on the basis of an adnexal mass or abdominal symptoms. When possible, considering the likelihood of a heritable genetic variant at the time of diagnosis may add value to surgical decision-making. The identification of inherited susceptibility to ovarian/fallopian tube cancer may influence surgical treatment decisions. For a questionable adnexal mass in a younger woman who is at risk of carrying a pathogenic variant of a highly penetrant ovarian cancer gene, knowledge of this information may help guide a decision for risk-reducing or therapeutic surgery.[<a href="#cit/section_2.220">

3362220</a>

3363,<a href="#cit/section_2.221">

3364221</a>

3365] For women who may be considering fertility preservation surgery, genetic knowledge may motivate consideration of bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and in the case of carriers of <em class="gene-name">

3366BRCA1</em>

3367 pathogenic variants, a more detailed discussion regarding aggressive uterine cancer risk.</li>

3368<li>

3369<strong>

3370Chemotherapy and other biologics</strong>

3371: First-line chemotherapy for ovarian cancer still relies on a backbone of platinum and taxane chemotherapy. Current treatment options for optimally resected stage III ovarian carcinoma include intravenous (IV) chemotherapy, dose-dense IV chemotherapy, and a combination of IV paclitaxel plus intraperitoneal (IP) cisplatin, followed by IP paclitaxel 1 week later. Carriers of <em class="gene-name">

3372BRCA1</em>

3373 and <em class="gene-name">

3374BRCA2</em>

3375 pathogenic variants are considered more platinum sensitive, with longer progression-free survival times compared with <em class="gene-name">

3376BRCA1</em>

3377 and <em class="gene-name">

3378BRCA2</em>

3379 wild-type patients,[<a href="#cit/section_2.222">

3380222</a>

3381,<a href="#cit/section_2.223">

3382223</a>

3383] so it is unclear whether a particular treatment strategy is driven more by antiangiogenesis effects, peritoneal dose intensity, or platinum dose intensity. The advent of PARP as a biologic target (in combination with chemotherapy or as maintenance) may also increase the armory of first-line treatment of ovarian cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.224">

3384224</a>

3385] (Refer to the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq#_3506">

3386Ovarian Cancer Treatment Strategies</a>

3387 section in <em class="gene-name">

3388BRCA1</em>

3389 and <em class="gene-name">

3390BRCA2</em>

3391: Cancer Risks and Management for more information about PARP inhibitors in ovarian cancer treatment.)</li>

3392</ol>

3393</div>

3394</section>

3395<section id="_3088">

3396<h5 id="_3088_toc">

3397Endometrial cancer diagnosis</h5>

3398<p id="_3200" tabindex="-1">

3399Benefits of offering genetic testing at the time of endometrial cancer diagnosis include, but are not limited to, the following:</p>

3400<div class="pdq-content-list">

3401<ol id="_3201">

3402<li>

3403<strong>

3404Surgery</strong>

3405: The most common treatment for a newly diagnosed endometrial cancer includes hysterectomy with removal of the ovaries and fallopian tubes, as well as assessment of lymph nodes.[<a href="#cit/section_2.225">

3406225</a>

3407] An exception to this practice might apply to a younger woman who wishes to retain fertility or retain her adnexa. IHC of endometrial sampling may allow for an assessment of the likelihood of a heritable genetic variant at the time of diagnosis, which may add value to the surgical decision-making process. For a young woman who is found to have Lynch syndrome, knowledge of this information may help guide a decision for hormonal management of endometrial cancer to allow future childbearing, or RRSO if her risk of ovarian cancer is deemed high enough on the basis of a specific genetic variant. For a young woman who is found to carry a pathogenic variant in <em class="gene-name">

3408BRCA1</em>

3409/<em class="gene-name">

3410BRCA2</em>

3411, or one of the other homologous recombination deficiencies increasing ovarian cancer risk, she may wish to decide between salpingo-oophorectomy or, at least, salpingectomy.</li>

3412<li>

3413 <strong>

3414Chemotherapy and other biologics</strong>

3415: Immune checkpoint inhibitors are now approved for use in endometrial cancers that have MSI or MMR deficiency.[<a href="#cit/section_2.226">

3416226</a>

3417] While MSI and MMR status can be assessed at either the time of diagnosis or recurrent disease, it may be beneficial to perform tumor testing at diagnosis with the primary pathology processing, usually at the time of hysterectomy.</li>

3418</ol>

3419</div>

3420</section>

3421</section>

3422<section id="_3083">

3423<h4 id="_3083_toc">

3424Multigene (panel) testing</h4>

3425<p id="_3170" tabindex="-1">

3426Since the availability of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=763024&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000763024&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3427next-generation sequencing</a>

3428 and the Supreme Court of the United States ruling that human genes cannot be patented, several clinical laboratories now offer genetic testing through multigene panels at a cost comparable to that of single-gene testing. Even testing for <em class="gene-name">

3429BRCA1</em>

3430 and <em class="gene-name">

3431BRCA2</em>

3432 is a limited panel test of two genes. Approximately 25% of all ovarian/fallopian tube/peritoneal cancers are caused by a heritable genetic condition. Of these, about one-quarter (6% of all ovarian/fallopian tube/peritoneal cancers) are caused by genes other than <em class="gene-name">

3433BRCA1</em>

3434 and <em class="gene-name">

3435BRCA2</em>

3436, including many genes associated with the Fanconi anemia pathway or otherwise involved with homologous recombination.[<a href="#cit/section_2.227">

3437227</a>

3438]

3439

3440 In a population of ovarian cancer patients who test negative for <em class="gene-name">

3441BRCA1</em>

3442 and <em class="gene-name">

3443BRCA2</em>

3444 pathogenic variants, multigene panel testing can reveal actionable pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_2.228">

3445228</a>

3446-<a href="#cit/section_2.230">

3447230</a>

3448] </p>

3449<p id="_2948" tabindex="-1">

3450In general, multigene panel testing increases the yield of non-<em class="gene-name">

3451BRCA</em>

3452 pathogenic variants across a variety of populations.[<a href="#cit/section_2.212">

3453212</a>

3454,<a href="#cit/section_2.231">

3455231</a>

3456-<a href="#cit/section_2.233">

3457233</a>

3458] In an unselected population of breast cancer patients, the prevalence of <em class="gene-name">

3459BRCA1</em>

3460 and <em class="gene-name">

3461BRCA2</em>

3462 pathogenic variants was 6.1%, while the prevalence of pathogenic variants in other breast/ovarian cancer&#8211;predisposing genes was 4.6%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.234">

3463234</a>

3464] In an unselected population of endometrial cancer patients, the prevalence of Lynch syndrome pathogenic variants (<em class="gene-name">

3465MLH1</em>

3466, <em class="gene-name">

3467MSH2</em>

3468, <em class="gene-name">

3469EPCAM-MSH2</em>

3470, <em class="gene-name">

3471MSH6</em>

3472, and <em class="gene-name">

3473PMS2</em>

3474) was 5.8%; the prevalence of pathogenic variants in other actionable genes was 3.4%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.108">

3475108</a>

3476] Similarly, in a study of 35,409 women with breast cancer tested with the Myriad 25-gene panel, a pathogenic variant was found in 9.3% of women.[<a href="#cit/section_2.235">

3477235</a>

3478] Among that 9.3%, 48.5% of the women carried a pathogenic variant in <em class="gene-name">

3479BRCA1</em>

3480 or <em class="gene-name">

3481BRCA2</em>

3482. The majority of other breast cancer genes with pathogenic variants identified included <em class="gene-name">

3483CHEK2</em>

3484 (11.7%), <em class="gene-name">

3485ATM</em>

3486 (9.7%), and <em class="gene-name">

3487PALB2</em>

3488 (9.3%). The prevalence of pathogenic variants in the other breast cancer genes on the panel ranged from 0.05% to 0.31%. Pathogenic variants in Lynch syndrome genes accounted for 7.0% of variants identified; 3.7% were found in other genes included in the panel. The rate of pathogenic variants was higher in women with TNBC diagnosed before age 40 years. A similar trend of identifying pathogenic variants in non-<em class="gene-name">

3489BRCA</em>

3490 susceptibility genes in male breast cancer patients has also been described.[<a href="#cit/section_2.236">

3491236</a>

3492] In two studies of women who had previously tested negative for <em class="gene-name">

3493BRCA1</em>

3494/<em class="gene-name">

3495BRCA2</em>

3496, reflex testing with a multigene panel identified pathogenic variants in additional genes among 8% to 11% of cases.[<a href="#cit/section_2.237">

3497237</a>

3498,<a href="#cit/section_2.238">

3499238</a>

3500] In a study of 77,085 patients with breast cancer and 6,001 patients with ovarian cancer, 24.1% and 30.9% had genetic testing, respectively. Of those tested, pathogenic or likely pathogenic variants were identified in 7.8% of patients with breast cancer and 14.5% of patients with ovarian cancer. Prevalent non-<em class="gene-name">

3501BRCA</em>

3502 pathogenic variants identified in patients with breast cancer included <em class="gene-name">

3503CHEK2</em>

3504 (1.6%), <em class="gene-name">

3505PALB2</em>

3506 (1.0%), <em class="gene-name">

3507ATM</em>

3508 (0.7%), and <em class="gene-name">

3509NBN</em>

3510 (0.4%). In patients with ovarian cancer, non-<em class="gene-name">

3511BRCA</em>

3512 pathogenic variants included <em class="gene-name">

3513CHEK2</em>

3514 (1.4%), <em class="gene-name">

3515BRIP1</em>

3516 (0.9%), <em class="gene-name">

3517MSH2</em>

3518 (0.8%), and <em class="gene-name">

3519ATM</em>

3520 (0.6%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.239">

3521239</a>

3522] The potential utility of genetic testing in patients with ovarian tumors of all histologies was suggested in a study using a 32-gene panel that found 13.2% of 4,439 tumors harbored a pathogenic variant. Rates were highest among those with serous ovarian carcinoma (14.7%), although likely pathogenic variants were also seen in those with other histologies (borderline, germ cell, and sex cord stromal tumors), the significance of which is unclear to clinical management or etiology of disease.[<a href="#cit/section_2.240">

3523240</a>

3524]</p>

3525<p id="_3426" tabindex="-1">

3526Multi-gene panel testing was conducted as part of two large efforts led by the worldwide Breast Cancer Association Consortium (BCAC) [<a href="#cit/section_2.241">

3527241</a>

3528] and the United States&#8211;based CARRIERS consortium.[<a href="#cit/section_2.242">

3529242</a>

3530] The BCAC study tested 113,927 women for 34 inherited cancer genes, while the CARRIERS study tested 64,791 women for 28 hereditary cancer genes. In both studies, significant associations were reported between eight genes and breast cancer development (<em class="gene-name">

3531BRCA1</em>

3532, <em class="gene-name">

3533BRCA2</em>

3534, <em class="gene-name">

3535PALB2</em>

3536, <em class="gene-name">

3537BARD1</em>

3538, <em class="gene-name">

3539RAD51C</em>

3540, <em class="gene-name">

3541RAD51D</em>

3542, <em class="gene-name">

3543ATM</em>

3544, and <em class="gene-name">

3545CHEK2</em>

3546). Associations were only reported between <em class="gene-name">

3547MSH6</em>

3548 and breast cancer development in the BCAC study. Similarly, associations were only reported between <em class="gene-name">

3549CDH1</em>

3550 and breast cancer development in the CARRIERS study. Both <em class="gene-name">

3551TP53</em>

3552 and <em class="gene-name">

3553PTEN</em>

3554 (which are established breast cancer risk genes that are linked to early-onset disease) were not significantly associated with breast cancer development in these studies. This is presumably because <em class="gene-name">

3555TP53</em>

3556 and <em class="gene-name">

3557PTEN</em>

3558 pathogenic variants are very rare.</p>

3559<p id="_3290" tabindex="-1">

3560NCCN recommends that women diagnosed with TNBC undergo <em class="gene-name">

3561BRCA1</em>

3562/<em class="gene-name">

3563BRCA2</em>

3564, <em class="gene-name">

3565CDH1</em>

3566, <em class="gene-name">

3567PALB2</em>

3568, <em class="gene-name">

3569PTEN</em>

3570, and <em class="gene-name">

3571TP53</em>

3572 testing to guide treatment decisions at any age.[<a href="#cit/section_2.200">

3573200</a>

3574] A large study utilizing multigene (panel) testing comprising two separate cohorts reported that, in addition to <em class="gene-name">

3575BRCA1</em>

3576/<em class="gene-name">

3577BRCA2</em>

3578 genes, six other breast cancer susceptibility genes were also related to a higher risk of TNBC. Specifically, pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

3579BARD1</em>

3580, <em class="gene-name">

3581PALB2</em>

3582, and <em class="gene-name">

3583RAD51D</em>

3584, in addition to <em class="gene-name">

3585BRCA1</em>

3586 and <em class="gene-name">

3587BRCA2</em>

3588, were each associated with more than a fivefold increase in breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.243">

3589243</a>

3590] Pathogenic variants in three other genes &#8212;<em class="gene-name">

3591BRIP1</em>

3592, <em class="gene-name">

3593RAD51C</em>

3594, and <em class="gene-name">

3595TP53</em>

3596&#8212; were each associated with an increased TNBC risk of more than twofold. Pathogenic variants in these eight genes were reported in 12% of the TNBC cases (8.3% <em class="gene-name">

3597BRCA1</em>

3598/<em class="gene-name">

3599BRCA2</em>

3600, 3.7% non-<em class="gene-name">

3601BRCA1</em>

3602/<em class="gene-name">

3603BRCA2</em>

3604). The study was conducted in a clinical testing cohort of 140,449 individuals (8,753 TNBC cases) who received genetic testing using a 21-gene panel (sample A). In addition, a second sample (sample B) examined gene frequency rates in a pooled consortium of 2,143 individuals using a 17-gene panel. The overall frequency of pathogenic variants in the 21 genes examined in sample A was 14.4% (8.4% <em class="gene-name">

3605BRCA1</em>

3606/<em class="gene-name">

3607BRCA2</em>

3608, 6.0% non-<em class="gene-name">

3609BRCA1</em>

3610/<em class="gene-name">

3611BRCA2</em>

3612). The two samples had very consistent findings with respect to the risk estimates despite differences in age, race, ethnicity, and family history of cancer with sample A being younger, more racially and ethnically diverse, and more likely to have a family history of cancer. The pathogenic variant frequency detection in these 21 genes was also similar for White individuals (14% overall, 7.8% <em class="gene-name">

3613BRCA1</em>

3614/<em class="gene-name">

3615BRCA2</em>

3616, 6.2% non-<em class="gene-name">

3617BRCA1</em>

3618/<em class="gene-name">

3619BRCA2</em>

3620) and African American individuals (14.6% overall, 9.0% <em class="gene-name">

3621BRCA1</em>

3622/<em class="gene-name">

3623BRCA2</em>

3624, 5.6% non-<em class="gene-name">

3625BRCA1</em>

3626/<em class="gene-name">

3627BRCA2</em>

3628).</p>

3629<p id="_3428" tabindex="-1">

3630Multi-gene panel testing studies were conducted in women from the United States who had African ancestry, and results showed that certain genes were associated with increased breast cancer risk in this population. These genes were similar to the breast cancer risk genes found in individuals from the United States with European ancestry. A case-control study of 10,047 women with African ancestry found a pathogenic variant frequency of 10.3% in those with ER-negative breast cancer, 5.2% in those with ER-positive breast cancer, and 2.3% in those without breast cancer. <em class="gene-name">

3631BRCA1 </em>

3632(OR, 47), <em class="gene-name">

3633BRCA2</em>

3634 (OR, 7.25) and <em class="gene-name">

3635PALB2</em>

3636 (OR, 8.54) were associated with the highest breast cancer risks.[<a href="#cit/section_2.244">

3637244</a>

3638] High ER-negative breast cancer risk was reported in individuals with pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

3639RAD51D</em>

3640 (OR, 7.82), while moderate ER-positive breast cancer risk was reported in individuals with pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

3641CHEK2</em>

3642, <em class="gene-name">

3643ATM</em>

3644, <em class="gene-name">

3645ERCC3</em>

3646, and <em class="gene-name">

3647FANCC</em>

3648. Similarly, a case-control study of 3,286 women with African ancestry found significant associations between breast cancer risk and pathogenic variants in the following genes: <em class="gene-name">

3649BRCA1</em>

3650, <em class="gene-name">

3651BRCA2</em>

3652, <em class="gene-name">

3653PALB2</em>

3654, <em class="gene-name">

3655ATM</em>

3656, <em class="gene-name">

3657CHEK2</em>

3658, <em class="gene-name">

3659TP53</em>

3660, <em class="gene-name">

3661NF1</em>

3662, <em class="gene-name">

3663RAD51C</em>

3664, and <em class="gene-name">

3665RAD51D</em>

3666.[<a href="#cit/section_2.245">

3667245</a>

3668]</p>

3669<p id="_3171" tabindex="-1">

3670There are caveats of multigene testing. Genes identified as part of multigene panel testing can be associated with varied breast cancer risk or confer no known risk.[<a href="#cit/section_2.230">

3671230</a>

3672] There is also the possibility of finding a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=556495&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000556495&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3673variant of uncertain significance</a>

3674 (VUS). Even within a given gene, there may be differential risks on the basis of specific pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_2.246">

3675246</a>

3676] A large population-based retrospective study using Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) program data from Georgia and Los Angeles, California, found that multigene testing led to a twofold increase in the detection of pathogenic variants compared with <em class="gene-name">

3677BRCA</em>

3678-only testing in women with breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_2.247">

3679247</a>

3680] VUS rates, however, were tenfold higher in the multigene panels, especially in African American women (44.5%) and Asian women (50.9%). Many centers now offer a multigene panel test instead of just <em class="gene-name">

3681BRCA1</em>

3682 and <em class="gene-name">

3683BRCA2</em>

3684 testing if there is a concerning family history of syndromes other than hereditary breast and ovarian cancer, or more importantly, to gain as much genetic information as possible with one test, particularly if there may be insurance limitations.</p>

3685<p id="_2949" tabindex="-1">

3686(Refer to the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/risk-assessment-pdq#_1320">

3687Multigene [panel] testing</a>

3688 section in Cancer Genetics Risk Assessment and Counseling for more information about multigene testing, including genetic education and counseling considerations and research examining the use of multigene testing.)</p>

3689</section>

3690</section>

3691<h6 do-not-show="toc">

3692References</h6>

3693<ol>

3694<li id="section_2.1">

3695American Cancer Society: Cancer Facts and Figures 2022. American Cancer Society, 2022. <a href="https://www.cancer.org/content/dam/cancer-org/research/cancer-facts-and-statistics/annual-cancer-facts-and-figures/2022/2022-cancer-facts-and-figures.pdf" title="https://www.cancer.org/content/dam/cancer-org/research/cancer-facts-and-statistics/annual-cancer-facts-and-figures/2022/2022-cancer-facts-and-figures.pdf">

3696Available online</a>

3697. Last accessed October 7, 2022.</li>

3698<li id="section_2.2">

3699Ravdin PM, Cronin KA, Howlader N, et al.: The decrease in breast-cancer incidence in 2003 in the United States. N Engl J Med 356 (16): 1670-4, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17442911&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17442911&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3700[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3701</li>
