J Med Genet 53 (12): 800-811, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27595995&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27595995&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4676[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4677</li>

4678<li id="section_2.247">

4679Kurian AW, Ward KC, Hamilton AS, et al.: Uptake, Results, and Outcomes of Germline Multiple-Gene Sequencing After Diagnosis of Breast Cancer. JAMA Oncol 4 (8): 1066-1072, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29801090&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29801090&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4680[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4681</li>

4682</ol>

4683</div>

4684

4685 </section>

4686

4687

4688

4689 <section id="_2730">

4690

4691 <h2>

4692Penetrance of Inherited Susceptibility to Hereditary Breast and/or Gynecologic Cancers</h2>

4693

4694 <div id="_section_2730" class="pdq-sections">

4695<p id="_2862" tabindex="-1">

4696The proportion of individuals carrying a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4697pathogenic variant</a>

4698 who will manifest a certain disease is referred to as <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339344&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339344&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4699penetrance</a>

4700. In general, common <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=776887&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000776887&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4701genetic variants</a>

4702 that are associated with cancer susceptibility have a lower penetrance than rare genetic variants. This is depicted in <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2731">

4703Figure 4</a>

4704. For adult-onset diseases, penetrance is usually described by the individual <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460132&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460132&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4705carrier's</a>

4706 age, sex, and organ site. For example, the penetrance for breast cancer in female carriers of <em class="gene-name">

4707BRCA1 </em>

4708pathogenic variants is often quoted by age 50 years and by age 70 years. Of the numerous methods for estimating penetrance, none are without potential biases, and determining an individual carrier's risk of cancer involves some level of imprecision.</p>

4709<figure id="figure_2731" class="image-center">

4710<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/746226.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

4711Enlarge</a>

4712<img id="_2731" alt="Graph shows relative risk on the x-axis and allele frequency on the y-axis. A line depicts the general finding of a low relative risk associated with common, low-penetrance genetic variants and a higher relative risk associated with rare, high-penetrance genetic variants." title="Graph shows relative risk on the x-axis and allele frequency on the y-axis. A line depicts the general finding of a low relative risk associated with common, low-penetrance genetic variants and a higher relative risk associated with rare, high-penetrance genetic variants." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/746226-750.jpg">

4713<figcaption class="caption-container">

4714Figure 4. Genetic architecture of cancer risk. This graph depicts the general finding of a low relative risk associated with common, low-penetrance genetic variants, such as single-nucleotide polymorphisms identified in genome-wide association studies, and a higher relative risk associated with rare, high-penetrance genetic variants, such as pathogenic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

4715BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

4716 genes associated with hereditary breast and ovarian cancer and the mismatch repair genes associated with Lynch syndrome.</figcaption>

4717</figure>

4718<p id="_2759" tabindex="-1">

4719Throughout this summary, we discuss studies that report on relative and absolute risks (ARs). These are two important but different concepts. Relative risk (RR) refers to an estimate of risk relative to another group (e.g., risk of an outcome like breast cancer for women who are exposed to a risk factor <em>

4720relative</em>

4721 to the risk of breast cancer for women who are unexposed to the same risk factor). RR measures that are greater than 1 mean that the risk for those captured in the numerator (i.e., the exposed) is higher than the risk for those captured in the denominator (i.e., the unexposed). RR measures that are less than 1 mean that the risk for those captured in the numerator (i.e., the exposed) is lower than the risk for those captured in the denominator (i.e., the unexposed). Measures with similar relative interpretations include the odds ratio (OR), hazard ratio, and risk ratio.</p>

4722<p id="_2760" tabindex="-1">

4723AR measures consider the number of people who have a particular outcome, the number of people in a population who could have the outcome, and person-time (the period of time during which an individual was at risk of having the outcome). AR measures also reflect the absolute burden of an outcome in a population. Absolute measures include risks and rates and can be expressed over a specific time frame (e.g., 1 year, 5 years) or overall lifetime. Cumulative risk is a measure of risk that occurs over a defined time period. For example, overall lifetime risk is a type of cumulative risk that is usually calculated on the basis of a given life expectancy (e.g., 80 or 90 years). Cumulative risk can also be presented over other time frames (e.g., up to age 50 years).</p>

4724<p id="_2761" tabindex="-1">

4725Large RR measures do not mean that there will be large effects in the actual number of individuals at a population level because the disease outcome may be quite rare. For example, the RR for smoking is much higher for lung cancer than for heart disease, but the absolute difference between smokers and nonsmokers is greater for heart disease, the more-common outcome, than for lung cancer, the more-rare outcome.</p>

4726<p id="_2762" tabindex="-1">

4727Therefore, in evaluating the effect of exposures and biological markers on disease prevention across the continuum, it is important to recognize the differences between relative and absolute effects in weighing the overall impact of a given risk factor. For example, the magnitude is in the range of 30% (e.g., ORs or RRs of 1.3) for many breast cancer risk factors, which means that women with a risk factor (e.g., alcohol consumption, late age at first birth, oral contraceptive use, postmenopausal body size) have a 30% relative increase in breast cancer in comparison with what they would have if they did not have that risk factor. But the absolute increase in risk is based on the underlying AR of disease. <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2922">

4728Figure 5</a>

4729 and <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2822">

4730Table 3</a>

4731 show the impact of a RR factor in the range of 1.3 on AR. (Refer to the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/risk-assessment-pdq#_1237">

4732Standard Pedigree Nomenclature</a>

4733 figure in Cancer Genetics Risk Assessment and Counseling for definitions of the standard symbols used in these <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44868&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044868&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4734pedigrees</a>

4735.) As shown, women with a family history of breast cancer have a much higher benefit from risk factor reduction on an absolute scale.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

47361</a>

4737]</p>

4738<figure id="figure_2922" class="image-center">

4739<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/779042.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

4740Enlarge</a>

4741<img id="_2922" alt="Five pedigrees are shown depicting probands with varying degrees of family history of breast cancer ranging from no affected first-degree relatives and no known BRCA mutation in the family (family 1) to three affected first-degree relatives, including one relative with bilateral breast cancer, and a known BRCA1 mutation in the family (family 5)." title="Five pedigrees are shown depicting probands with varying degrees of family history of breast cancer ranging from no affected first-degree relatives and no known BRCA mutation in the family (family 1) to three affected first-degree relatives, including one relative with bilateral breast cancer, and a known BRCA1 mutation in the family (family 5)." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/779042-750.jpg">

4742<figcaption class="caption-container">

4743Figure 5. These five pedigrees depict probands with varying degrees of family history. <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2822">

4744Table 3</a>

4745 accompanies this figure.</figcaption>

4746</figure>

4747<table id="_2822" class="table-default expandable-container">

4748<caption>

4847</table>

4848<p id="_2993" tabindex="-1">

4849With the increasing use of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=763019&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000763019&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4850multigene panel tests</a>

4851, a framework for cancer risk management among individuals with pathogenic variants detected in novel <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4852genes</a>

4853 has been described [<a href="#cit/section_3.2">

48542</a>

4855] that incorporates data on age-specific, lifetime, and absolute cancer risks. The framework suggests initiating screening in these individuals at the age when their 5-year cancer risk approaches that at which screening is routinely initiated for women in the general population (approximately 1% for breast cancer in the United States). As a result, the age at which to begin screening will vary depending on the gene. (Refer to the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_3083">

4856Multigene [panel] testing</a>

4857 section of this summary for more information on multigene panel tests.)</p>

4858<h6 do-not-show="toc">

4859References</h6>

4860<ol>

4876 <section id="_3165">

4877

4878 <h2>

4879Genes Associated With Breast and/or Gynecologic Cancer Susceptibility</h2>

4880

4881 <div id="_section_3165" class="pdq-sections">

4882<p id="_3166" tabindex="-1">

4883Several <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4884genes</a>

4885 are found to be associated with the development of breast and/or gynecologic cancers. These genes are categorized as high-<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339344&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339344&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4886penetrance</a>

4887, moderate-penetrance, and low-penetrance in this summary. The high- and moderate-penetrance genes are summarized in <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_3169">

4888Table 4</a>

4889. Low-penetrance genes and <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460162&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460162&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4890loci</a>

4891 primarily include <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44805&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044805&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4892polymorphisms</a>

4893 that have been associated with cancer <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=256553&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000256553&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4894susceptibility</a>

4895. (Refer to the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_88">

4896High-Penetrance Breast and/or Gynecologic Cancer Susceptibility Genes</a>

4897, <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_156">

4898Moderate-Penetrance Genes Associated With Breast and/or Gynecologic Cancer</a>

4899, and <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2857">

4900Single Nucleotide Variant&#8211;Associated Cancer Risks</a>

4901 sections of this summary for more information.)</p>

5036

5037 <section id="_88">

5038

5039 <h2>

5040High-Penetrance Breast and/or Gynecologic Cancer Susceptibility Genes</h2>

5041

5042 <div id="_section_88" class="pdq-sections">

5043<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

5044<h6>

5045In This Section</h6>

5046<ul>

5047<li>

5048<a href="#_3826_toc">

5049<em class="gene-name">

5050BRCA1</em>

5051 and <em class="gene-name">

5052BRCA2</em>

5053</a>

5054</li>

5055<li>

5056<a href="#_3750_toc">

5057Lynch Syndrome</a>

5058</li>

5059<li>

5060<a href="#_3755_toc">

5061Li-Fraumeni Syndrome (LFS)<ul>

5062<li>

5063<a href="#_3759_toc">

5064Historical criteria for defining LFS</a>

5065</li>

5066<li>

5067<a href="#_3770_toc">

5068Clinical characteristics of LFS</a>

5069</li>

5070</ul>

5071</a>

5072</li>

5073<li>

5074<a href="#_3778_toc">

5075<em class="gene-name">

5076PTEN</em>

5077 Hamartoma Tumor Syndromes (Including Cowden Syndrome)</a>

5078</li>

5079<li>

5080<a href="#_3780_toc">

5081Diffuse Gastric and Lobular Breast Cancer Syndrome</a>

5082</li>

5083<li>

5084<a href="#_3783_toc">

5085Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome (PJS)</a>

5086</li>

5087<li>

5088<a href="#_3784_toc">

5089<em class="gene-name">

5090PALB2</em>

5091</a>

5092</li>

5093<li>

5094<a href="#_2591_toc">

5095De Novo Pathogenic Variant Rate</a>

5096</li>

5097</ul>

5098</nav>

5099<section id="_3826">

5100<h3 id="_3826_toc">

5101<em class="gene-name">

5102BRCA1</em>

5103 and <em class="gene-name">

5104BRCA2</em>

5105</h3>

5106<p id="_3825" tabindex="-1">

5107For more information about <em class="gene-name">

5108BRCA1</em>

5109 and <em class="gene-name">

5110BRCA2</em>

5111 pathogenic variants and <em class="gene-name">

5112BRCA</em>

5113-associated cancer risks, see <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq">

5114BRCA1 and BRCA2: Cancer Risks and Management</a>

5115.</p>

5116</section>

5117<section id="_3750">

5118<h3 id="_3750_toc">

5119Lynch Syndrome</h3>

5120<p id="_3824" tabindex="-1">

5121Lynch syndrome is characterized by autosomal dominant inheritance of susceptibility to predominantly right-sided colon cancer, endometrial cancer, ovarian cancer, and other extracolonic cancers (including cancer of the renal pelvis, ureter, small bowel, and pancreas), multiple primary cancers, and a young age of onset of cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_5.1">

51221</a>

5123] The condition is caused by germline variants in the mismatch repair (MMR) genes, which are involved in repair of DNA mismatch variants.[<a href="#cit/section_5.2">

51242</a>

5125] The <em class="gene-name">

5126MLH1</em>

5127 and <em class="gene-name">

5128MSH2</em>

5129 genes are the most common susceptibility genes for Lynch syndrome, accounting for 80% to 90% of observed pathogenic variants,[<a href="#cit/section_5.3">

51303</a>

5131,<a href="#cit/section_5.4">

51324</a>

5133] followed by <em class="gene-name">

5134MSH6</em>

5135 and <em class="gene-name">

5136PMS2</em>

5137.[<a href="#cit/section_5.5">

51385</a>

5139-<a href="#cit/section_5.10">

514010</a>

5141] (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2986">

5142Lynch Syndrome</a>

5143 section in Genetics of Colorectal Cancer for more information about this syndrome.)</p>

5144<p id="_3752" tabindex="-1">

5145After colorectal cancer, endometrial cancer is the second hallmark cancer of a family with Lynch syndrome. Even in the original Family G, described by Dr. Aldred Scott Warthin, numerous family members were noted to have extracolonic cancers including endometrial cancer. Although the first version of the Amsterdam criteria did not include endometrial cancer,[<a href="#cit/section_5.11">

514611</a>

5147] in 1999, the Amsterdam criteria were revised to include endometrial cancer as extracolonic tumors associated with Lynch syndrome to identify families at risk.[<a href="#cit/section_5.12">

514812</a>

5149] In addition, the Bethesda guidelines in 1997 (revised in 2004) did include endometrial and ovarian cancers as Lynch syndrome&#8211;related cancers to prompt tumor testing for Lynch syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_5.13">

515013</a>

5151,<a href="#cit/section_5.14">

515214</a>

5153]</p>

5154<p id="_3753" tabindex="-1">

5155The lifetime risk of ovarian carcinoma in females with Lynch syndrome is estimated to be as high as 12%, and the reported relative risk (RR) of ovarian cancer has ranged from 3.6 to 13, based on families ascertained from high-risk clinics with known or suspected Lynch syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_5.15">

515615</a>

5157-<a href="#cit/section_5.20">

515820</a>

5159] There may be differences in ovarian cancer risk depending on the Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated pathogenic variant. In <em class="gene-name">

5160PMS2</em>

5161-associated Lynch syndrome, one study of 284 families was unable to identify an increased risk of ovarian cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_5.21">

516221</a>

5163] Another prospective registry of 3,119 Lynch syndrome&#8211;pathogenic variant carriers described the cumulative risk of ovarian cancer to range from 10% to 17% in <em class="gene-name">

5164MLH1</em>

5165, <em class="gene-name">

5166MSH2</em>

5167, and <em class="gene-name">

5168MSH6</em>

5169 carriers. In contrast, 0 of 67 women with a pathogenic variant in <em class="gene-name">

5170PMS2</em>

5171 developed ovarian cancer in 303 follow-up years.[<a href="#cit/section_5.22">

517222</a>

5173] Overall, there are too few cases of <em class="gene-name">

5174PMS2</em>

5175 pathogenic variant carriers to make definitive recommendations for ovarian cancer management. Characteristics of Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated ovarian cancers may include overrepresentation of the International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics stages I and II at diagnosis (reported as 81.5%), underrepresentation of serous subtypes (reported as 22.9%), and a better 10-year survival (reported as 80.6%) than reported both in population-based series and in carriers of <em class="gene-name">

5176BRCA</em>

5177 pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_5.23">

517823</a>

5179,<a href="#cit/section_5.24">

518024</a>

5181] </p>

5182<section id="_sm_CDR0000743132_1">

5183<p id="_sm_CDR0000743132_2" tabindex="-1">

5184The issue of breast cancer risk in Lynch syndrome has been controversial.</p>

5185<p id="_sm_CDR0000743132_2" tabindex="-1">

5186 Retrospective studies have been inconsistent, but several have demonstrated microsatellite instability in a proportion of breast cancers from individuals with Lynch syndrome;[<a href="#cit/section_5.25">

518725</a>

5188-<a href="#cit/section_5.28">

518928</a>

5190] one of these studies evaluated breast cancer risk in individuals with Lynch syndrome and found that it is not elevated.[<a href="#cit/section_5.28">

519128</a>

5192] However, the largest prospective study to date of 446 unaffected carriers of pathogenic variants from the Colon Cancer Family Registry [<a href="#cit/section_5.29">

519329</a>

5194] who were followed for up to 10 years reported an elevated SIR of 3.95 for breast cancer (95% CI, 1.59&#8211;8.13; <em>

5195P</em>

5196 = .001).[<a href="#cit/section_5.29">

519729</a>

5198] The same group subsequently analyzed data on 764 carriers of MMR gene pathogenic variants with a prior diagnosis of colorectal cancer. Results showed that the 10-year risk of breast cancer following colorectal cancer was 2% (95% CI, 1%&#8211;4%) and that the SIR was 1.76 (95% CI, 1.07&#8211;2.59).[<a href="#cit/section_5.30">

519930</a>

5200] A series from the United Kingdom composed of clinically referred Lynch syndrome kindreds, with efforts to correct for ascertainment, showed a twofold increased risk of breast cancer in 157 <em class="gene-name">

5201MLH1</em>

5202 carriers but not in carriers of other MMR variants.[<a href="#cit/section_5.31">

520331</a>

5204] Results from a meta-analysis of breast cancer risk in Lynch syndrome among 15 studies with molecular tumor testing results revealed that 62 of 122 breast cancers (51%; 95% CI, 42%&#8211;60%) in MMR pathogenic variant carriers were MMR-deficient. In addition, breast cancer risk estimates among a total of 21 studies showed an increased risk of twofold to 18-fold in eight studies that compared MMR variant carriers with noncarriers, while 13 studies did not observe statistical evidence for an association of breast cancer risk with Lynch syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_5.32">

520532</a>

5206]</p>

5207<p id="_sm_CDR0000743132_8" tabindex="-1">

5208A number of subsequent studies have suggested the presence of higher breast cancer risks than previously published,[<a href="#cit/section_5.33">

520933</a>

5210-<a href="#cit/section_5.36">

521136</a>

5212] although this has not been consistently observed.[<a href="#cit/section_5.37">

521337</a>

5214] Through a study of 325 Canadian families with Lynch syndrome, primarily encompassing <em class="gene-name">

5215MLH1</em>

5216 and <em class="gene-name">

5217MSH2</em>

5218 carriers, the lifetime cumulative risk for breast cancer among <em class="gene-name">

5219MSH2</em>

5220 carriers was reported to be 22%.[<a href="#cit/section_5.33">

522133</a>

5222] Similarly, breast cancer risks were elevated in a study of 423 women with Lynch syndrome, with substantially higher risks among those with <em class="gene-name">

5223MSH6</em>

5224 and <em class="gene-name">

5225PMS2</em>

5226 pathogenic variants, compared with <em class="gene-name">

5227MLH1</em>

5228 and <em class="gene-name">

5229MSH2</em>

5230 pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_5.34">

523134</a>

5232] In fact, breast cancer risk to age 60 years was 37.7% for <em class="gene-name">

5233PMS2</em>

5234, 31.1% for <em class="gene-name">

5235MSH6</em>

5236, 16.1% for <em class="gene-name">

5237MSH2</em>

5238, and 15.5% for <em class="gene-name">

5239MLH1</em>

5240. These findings are consistent with another study of 528 patients with Lynch syndrome&#8211;associated pathogenic variants (including <em class="gene-name">

5241MLH1</em>

5242, <em class="gene-name">

5243MSH2</em>

5244, <em class="gene-name">

5245MSH6</em>

5246, <em class="gene-name">

5247PMS2</em>

5248, and <em class="gene-name">

5249EPCAM</em>

5250) in which <em class="gene-name">

5251PMS2</em>

5252 and <em class="gene-name">

5253MSH6</em>

5254 variants were much more frequent among patients with only breast cancer, compared with those with only colorectal cancer (<em>

5255P</em>

5256 = 2.3 x 10<span class="sup">

5257-5</span>

5258).[<a href="#cit/section_5.35">

525935</a>

5260]

5261Additional data to support an association of <em class="gene-name">

5262MSH6</em>

5263 with breast cancer were provided through a study of over 10,000 cancer patients across the United States who had genetic testing.[<a href="#cit/section_5.36">

526436</a>

5265] Findings indicated that <em class="gene-name">

5266MSH6</em>

5267 was associated with breast cancer with an odds ratio (OR) of 2.59 (95% CI, 1.35&#8211;5.44). Taken together, these studies highlight how the risk profile among patients with Lynch syndrome is continuing to evolve as more individuals are tested through multigene panel testing, with representation of larger numbers of individuals with <em class="gene-name">

5268PMS2</em>

5269 and <em class="gene-name">

5270MSH6</em>

5271 pathogenic variants compared with prior studies.

5272In the absence of definitive risk estimates, individuals with Lynch syndrome are screened for breast cancer on the basis of family history.[<a href="#cit/section_5.38">

527338</a>

5274]</p>

5275</section>

5276<p id="_3754" tabindex="-1">

5277Refer to the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2743">

5278Lynch Syndrome</a>

5279 section of the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2742">

5280Clinical Management of Other Hereditary Breast and/or Gynecologic Cancer Syndromes</a>

5281 section of this summary for information about clinical management of Lynch syndrome.</p>

5282</section>

5283<section id="_3755">

5284<h3 id="_3755_toc">

5285Li-Fraumeni Syndrome (LFS)</h3>

5286<p id="_3756" tabindex="-1">

5287Breast cancer is also a component of the rare LFS, in

5288which germline variants of the <em class="gene-name">

5289TP53</em>

5290 gene on chromosome 17p have been

5291documented. Located on chromosome 17p, <em class="gene-name">

5292TP53</em>

5293 encodes a 53kd nuclear phosphoprotein that binds

5294DNA sequences and functions as a negative regulator of cell growth and

5295proliferation in the setting of DNA damage. It is also an

5296active component of programmed cell death.[<a href="#cit/section_5.39">

529739</a>

5298] Inactivation of the <em class="gene-name">

5299TP53</em>

5300 gene

5301or disruption of the protein product is thought to allow the persistence of

5302damaged DNA and the possible development of malignant cells.[<a href="#cit/section_5.40">

530340</a>

5304,<a href="#cit/section_5.41">

530541</a>

5306] Widely used clinical diagnostic criteria for LFS were originally developed by Chompret et al. in 2001 (called the <em>

5307Chompret Criteria</em>

5308) [<a href="#cit/section_5.42">

530942</a>

5310] and revised in 2009 based on additional emerging data.[<a href="#cit/section_5.43">

531143</a>

5312]

5313</p>

5314<p id="_3757" tabindex="-1">

5315LFS is characterized by premenopausal breast cancer

5316in combination with childhood sarcoma, brain tumors, leukemia, and

5317adrenocortical carcinoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.40">

531840</a>

5319,<a href="#cit/section_5.44">

532044</a>

5321,<a href="#cit/section_5.45">

532245</a>

5323]</p>

5324<p id="_3758" tabindex="-1">

5325Germline variants in <em class="gene-name">

5326TP53</em>

5327 are thought to account for fewer than 1% of breast cancer cases.[<a href="#cit/section_5.46">

532846</a>

5329] <em class="gene-name">

5330TP53</em>

5331-associated breast cancer is often human epidermal growth factor receptor two (HER2/neu)&#8211;positive, in addition to being estrogen receptor (ER)&#8211;positive, progesterone receptor (PR)&#8211;positive, or both.[<a href="#cit/section_5.47">

533247</a>

5333-<a href="#cit/section_5.49">

533449</a>

5335] Evidence

5336also exists that patients treated for a <em class="gene-name">

5337TP53</em>

5338-related tumor with chemotherapy or

5339radiation therapy may be at risk of a treatment-related second malignancy.</p>

5340<section id="_3759">

5341<h4 id="_3759_toc">

5342Historical criteria for defining LFS</h4>

5343<p id="_3760" tabindex="-1">

5344The term LFS was used for the first time in 1982,[<a href="#cit/section_5.50">

534550</a>

5346] and the following criteria, which subsequently became the classical definition of the syndrome, were proposed by Li and Fraumeni in 1988 [<a href="#cit/section_5.51">

534751</a>

5348]:</p>

5349<div class="pdq-content-list">

5350<ol id="_3761">

5351<li>

5352Sarcoma before age 45 years;</li>

5353<li>

5354A first-degree relative (FDR) with cancer before age 45 years; AND</li>

5355<li>

5356Another close relative (FDR or second-degree relative [SDR]) with either cancer before age 45 years or a sarcoma at any age.</li>

5357</ol>

5358</div>

5359<p id="_3762" tabindex="-1">

5360Subsequently in 2001, Chompret et al. [<a href="#cit/section_5.42">

536142</a>

5362] systematically developed clinical criteria for recommending <em class="gene-name">

5363TP53</em>

5364 genetic testing, with the narrow LFS tumor spectrum defined as sarcoma, brain tumors, breast cancer, and adrenocortical carcinoma. The criteria were as follows:</p>

5365<div class="pdq-content-list">

5366<ol id="_3763">

5367<li>

5368A proband affected by a narrow-spectrum tumor before age 36 years AND at least one FDR or SDR affected by a narrow-spectrum tumor (other than breast cancer if the proband is affected by breast cancer) before age 46 years or multiple primary tumors; OR</li>

5369<li>

5370A proband with multiple primary tumors, two of which belong to the narrow spectrum and the first of which occurred before age 36 years, irrespective of family history; OR</li>

5371<li>

5372A proband with adrenocortical carcinoma irrespective of the age at onset and family history.</li>

5373</ol>

5374</div>

5375<p id="_3764" tabindex="-1">

5376These criteria were revised in 2009 [<a href="#cit/section_5.43">

537743</a>

5378] based on additional emerging data [<a href="#cit/section_5.41">

537941</a>

5380,<a href="#cit/section_5.52">

538152</a>

5382] as follows:</p>

5383<div class="pdq-content-list">

5384<ol id="_3765">

5385<li>

5386A proband with a tumor belonging to the LFS tumor spectrum* before age 46 years AND at least one FDR or SDR with an LFS tumor (except breast cancer if proband has breast cancer) before age 56 years or with multiple tumors; OR</li>

5387<li>

5388A proband with multiple tumors (except multiple breast tumors), two of which belong to the LFS tumor spectrum and the first of which occurred before age 46 years; OR</li>

5389<li>

5390A patient with adrenocortical carcinoma or choroid plexus, irrespective of family history.</li>

5391</ol>

5392</div>

5393<p id="_3766" tabindex="-1">

5394*The 2009 Chompret criteria defined the LFS tumor spectrum as including the following cancers: soft tissue sarcoma, osteosarcoma, brain tumor, premenopausal breast cancer, adrenocortical carcinoma, leukemia, and lung bronchoalveolar cancer.</p>

5395<p id="_3767" tabindex="-1">

5396In 2015, Bougeard et al. [<a href="#cit/section_5.45">

539745</a>

5398] revised the criteria based on data from 415 carriers of pathogenic variants, to include the presence of childhood anaplastic rhabdomyosarcoma and breast cancer before age 31 years as an indication for testing, similar to what is recommended for choroid plexus carcinoma and adrenocortical carcinoma. The criteria were revised as follows:</p>

5399<div class="pdq-content-list">

5400<ol id="_3768">

5401<li>

5402A proband with a tumor belonging to the LFS tumor spectrum** before age 46 years AND at least one FDR or SDR with LFS tumor (except breast cancer if proband has breast cancer) before age 56 years or with multiple tumors; OR</li>

5403<li>

5404A proband with multiple tumors (except multiple breast tumors), two of which belong to the LFS tumor spectrum and the first of which occurred before age 46 years; OR</li>

5405<li>

5406A patient with adrenocortical carcinoma, choroid plexus tumor, or rhabdomyosarcoma of embryonal anaplastic subtype, irrespective of family history; OR</li>

5407<li>

5408Breast cancer before age 31 years.</li>

5409</ol>

5410</div>

5411<p id="_3769" tabindex="-1">

5412**The 2015 Chompret criteria defined the LFS tumor spectrum as including the following cancers: premenopausal breast cancer, soft tissue sarcoma, osteosarcoma, central nervous system (CNS) tumor, and adrenocortical carcinoma. </p>

5413</section>

5414<section id="_3770">

5415<h4 id="_3770_toc">

5416Clinical characteristics of LFS</h4>

5417<p id="_3771" tabindex="-1">

5418Germline <em class="gene-name">

5419TP53</em>

5420 pathogenic variants were identified in 17% (n = 91) of 525 samples submitted to City of Hope laboratories for clinical <em class="gene-name">

5421TP53</em>

5422 testing.[<a href="#cit/section_5.41">

542341</a>

5424] All families with a <em class="gene-name">

5425TP53</em>

5426 pathogenic variant had at least one family member with a sarcoma, breast cancer, brain cancer, or adrenocortical cancer (core cancers). In addition, all eight individuals with a choroid plexus tumor had a <em class="gene-name">

5427TP53</em>

5428 pathogenic variant, as did 14 of the 21 individuals with childhood adrenocortical cancer. In women aged 30 to 49 years who had breast cancer but no family history of other core cancers, no <em class="gene-name">

5429TP53</em>

5430 variants were found.</p>

5431<p id="_3772" tabindex="-1">

5432Subsequently, a large clinical series of patients from France who were tested primarily based on the 2009 version of the Chompret criteria [<a href="#cit/section_5.43">

543343</a>

5434]

5435

5436 included 415 carriers of pathogenic variants from 214 families.[<a href="#cit/section_5.45">

543745</a>

5438] In this study, 43% of carriers had multiple malignancies, and the mean age at first tumor onset was 24.9 years. The childhood tumor spectrum was characterized by osteosarcomas, adrenocortical carcinomas, CNS tumors, and soft tissue sarcomas (present in 23%&#8211;30% collectively), whereas the adult tumor spectrum primarily encompassed breast cancer (79% of females) and soft tissue sarcomas (27% of carriers). The <em class="gene-name">

5439TP53</em>

5440 pathogenic variant detection rate was 6% among females younger than 31 years with breast cancer and no additional features suggestive of LFS. Evaluation of genotype-phenotype correlations indicated a gradient of clinical severity, with a significantly lower mean age at onset among those with dominant-negative missense variants (21.3 years), compared with those with all types of loss-of-function variants (28.5 years) or genomic rearrangements (35.8 years). With the exception of adrenocortical carcinoma, affected children mostly harbored dominant-negative missense pathogenic variants. Among 127 female carriers of pathogenic variants with breast cancer, 31% developed contralateral breast cancer (CBC). Receptor status information was available for 40 tumors, which indicated 55% were HER2-positive, and 37% were triple-positive (i.e., ER-positive, PR-positive, and HER2-positive). There was an exceptionally high rate of multiple malignancies (43%) among carriers of pathogenic variants, of which 83% were metachronous. Treatment records were available for 64 carriers who received radiation therapy for treatment of their first tumor; of these, 19 (30%) developed 26 secondary tumors within a radiation field, with a latency of 2 to 26 years (mean, 10.7 y).</p>

5441<p id="_3773" tabindex="-1">

5442Similarly, results of 286 <em class="gene-name">

5443TP53</em>

5444 pathogenic variant&#8211;positive individuals in the National Cancer Institute&#8217;s LFS Study indicated a cumulative cancer incidence of almost 100% by age 70 years for both males and females.[<a href="#cit/section_5.53">

544553</a>

5446] They reported substantial variations by sex, age, and cancer type. Specifically, cumulative cancer incidence reached 50% by age 31 years in females and age 46 years in males, although male risks were higher in childhood and late adulthood. Cumulative cancer incidence by sex for the top four cancers is included in <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_3774">

5447Table 5</a>

5448. Of those with one cancer, 49% developed at least one additional cancer after a median of 10 years. Age-specific risks for developing first and second cancers were comparable.</p>

5449<table id="_3774" class="table-default expandable-container">

5450<caption>

5451Table 5. Cumulative Cancer Risks for the Most Common Li-Fraumeni Syndrome (LFS)-Associated Cancers<span class="sup">

5452a,b</span>

5453</caption>

5454<colgroup>

5455<col width="33.33%">

5456<col width="33.33%">

5457<col width="33.33%">

5458</colgroup>

5459<THead>

5460<tr>

5461<th>

5462&#160;</th>

5463<th colspan="2">

5464Cumulative Cancer Risk by Age 70 Years</th>

5465</tr>

5466</THead>

5467<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

5468<tr>

5469<td colspan="3">

5470<span class="sup">

5471a</span>

5472Adapted from Mai et al.[<a href="#cit/section_5.53">

547353</a>

5474]</td>

5475</tr>

5476<tr>

5477<td colspan="3">

5478<span class="sup">

5479b</span>

5480Other cancers, such as adrenocortical carcinoma, leukemia, and lung bronchoalveolar cancer, have been considered part of the LFS cancer spectrum.[<a href="#cit/section_5.43">

548143</a>

5482,<a href="#cit/section_5.45">

548345</a>

5484]</td>

5485</tr>

5486</TFoot>

5487<tbody>

5488<tr>

5489<td>

5490<strong>

5491Cancer Type</strong>

5492</td>

5493<td>

5494<strong>

5495Females</strong>

5496 <strong>

5497(%)</strong>

5498</td>

5499<td>

5500<strong>

5501Males</strong>

5502<strong>

5503 (%)</strong>

5504</td>

5505</tr>

5506<tr>

5507<td>

5508Breast cancer</td>

5509<td>

551054</td>

5511<td>

5512&#8211;</td>

5513</tr>

5514<tr>

5515<td>

5516Soft tissue sarcoma</td>

5517<td>

551815</td>

5519<td>

552022</td>

5521</tr>

5522<tr>

5523<td>

5524Brain cancer</td>

5525<td>

55266</td>

5527<td>

552819</td>

5529</tr>

5530<tr>

5531<td>

5532Osteosarcoma</td>

5533<td>

55345</td>

5535<td>

553611</td>

5537</tr>

5538</tbody>

5539</table>

5540<p id="_3775" tabindex="-1">

5541With the increasing use of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=775581&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000775581&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5542multigene (panel) tests</a>

5543, it is important to recognize that pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

5544TP53</em>

5545 are unexpectedly being identified in individuals without a family history characteristic of LFS.[<a href="#cit/section_5.54">

554654</a>

5547] The clinical significance of finding an isolated <em class="gene-name">

5548TP53</em>

5549 pathogenic variant in an individual or family who does not meet the Chompret criteria is uncertain. Consequently, it remains important to interpret cancer risks and determine optimal management strategies for individuals who are unexpectedly found to have a germline <em class="gene-name">

5550TP53</em>

5551 pathogenic variant, while considering their personal and family histories. </p>

5552</section>

5553<p id="_3776" tabindex="-1">

5554One cohort study evaluated 116 individuals with a germline <em class="gene-name">

5555TP53</em>

5556 pathogenic variant yearly at the National Institutes of Health Clinical Center using multimodality screening with and without gadolinium. Baseline screening identified a cancer in eight patients (6.9%) with a false-positive rate of 34.5% for MRI (n = 40).[<a href="#cit/section_5.55">

555755</a>

5558] Screening for breast cancer with annual breast MRI is recommended;[<a href="#cit/section_5.56">

555956</a>

5560] additional screening for other cancers has been studied and is evolving.[<a href="#cit/section_5.57">

556157</a>

5562,<a href="#cit/section_5.58">

556358</a>

5564] </p>

5565</section>

5566<section id="_3778">

5567<h3 id="_3778_toc">

5568<em class="gene-name">

5569PTEN</em>

5570 Hamartoma Tumor Syndromes (Including Cowden Syndrome)</h3>

5571<section id="_sm_CDR0000766497_2721">

5572<p id="_sm_CDR0000766497_2560" tabindex="-1">

5573Cowden syndrome and Bannayan-Riley-Ruvalcaba syndrome (BRRS) are part of a spectrum of conditions known collectively as <em class="gene-name">

5574PTEN</em>

5575 hamartoma tumor syndromes (PHTS). Approximately 85% of patients diagnosed with Cowden syndrome, and approximately 60% of patients with BRRS have an identifiable <em class="gene-name">

5576PTEN</em>

5577 pathogenic variant.[<a href="#cit/section_5.59">

557859</a>

5579] In addition, <em class="gene-name">

5580PTEN</em>

5581 pathogenic variants have been identified in patients with very diverse clinical phenotypes.[<a href="#cit/section_5.60">

558260</a>

5583] The term PHTS refers to any patient with a <em class="gene-name">

5584PTEN</em>

5585 pathogenic variant, irrespective of clinical presentation.</p>

5586<p id="_sm_CDR0000766497_2561" tabindex="-1">

5587<em class="gene-name">

5588PTEN</em>

5589 functions as a dual-specificity phosphatase that removes phosphate groups from tyrosine, serine, and threonine. <em class="gene-name">

5590PTEN</em>

5591 pathogenic variants are diverse and can present as <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783965&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783965&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5592nonsense</a>

5593, missense, <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783963&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783963&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5594frameshift</a>

5595, or <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783968&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783968&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5596splice-site variants</a>

5597. Approximately 40% of variants are found in exon 5, which encodes the phosphatase core motif; several recurrent pathogenic variants have been observed at this location.[<a href="#cit/section_5.61">

559861</a>

5599] Pathogenic variants in the 5&#8217; end of <em class="gene-name">

5600PTEN </em>

5601or within the phosphatase core of <em class="gene-name">

5602PTEN</em>

5603 tend to affect more organ systems.[<a href="#cit/section_5.62">

560462</a>

5605]</p>

5606<p id="_sm_CDR0000766497_2605" tabindex="-1">

5607Operational criteria for the diagnosis of Cowden syndrome have been published and subsequently updated.[<a href="#cit/section_5.63">

560863</a>

5609,<a href="#cit/section_5.64">

561064</a>

5611] These include major, minor, and <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=454769&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000454769&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5612pathognomonic</a>

5613 criteria that consist of certain mucocutaneous manifestations and adult-onset dysplastic gangliocytoma of the cerebellum (Lhermitte-Duclos disease). An updated set of criteria based on a systematic literature review has been suggested [<a href="#cit/section_5.65">

561465</a>

5615] and is currently utilized in the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) guidelines.[<a href="#cit/section_5.66">

561666</a>

5617] Contrary to previous criteria, the authors concluded that there was insufficient evidence for any features to be classified as pathognomonic. Increased genetic testing (especially <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=763019&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000763019&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5618multigene panels</a>

5619) has identified individuals with germline <em class="gene-name">

5620PTEN</em>

5621 pathogenic variants who do not meet diagnostic criteria for PHTS. Diagnostic criteria will need to be reconciled with these recently discovered phenotypes. Hence, it is unclear whether PHTS diagnoses should be based on clinical features or a positive <em class="gene-name">

5622PTEN</em>

5623 genetic test result. The American College of Medical Genetics and Genomics (ACMG) suggests that referral for genetics consultation be considered for individuals with a personal history of or a first-degree relative with the following: 1) adult-onset Lhermitte-Duclos disease or 2) any three of the major or minor criteria that have been established for the diagnosis of Cowden syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_5.67">

562467</a>

5625] Detailed recommendations, including <a href="https://www.nature.com/articles/gim2014147/tables/4" title="https://www.nature.com/articles/gim2014147/tables/4">

5626diagnostic criteria</a>

5627 for Cowden syndrome, can be found in the NCCN and ACMG guidelines.[<a href="#cit/section_5.66">

562866</a>

5629,<a href="#cit/section_5.67">

563067</a>

5631] Additionally, a predictive <a href="http://www.lerner.ccf.org/gmi/ccscore/" title="http://www.lerner.ccf.org/gmi/ccscore/">

5632model</a>

5633 that uses clinical criteria to estimate the probability of a <em class="gene-name">

5634PTEN</em>

5635 pathogenic variant is available; a cost-effectiveness analysis suggests that germline <em class="gene-name">

5636PTEN</em>

5637 testing is cost effective if the probability of a variant is greater than 10%.[<a href="#cit/section_5.68">

563868</a>

5639]</p>

5640<p id="_sm_CDR0000766497_2720" tabindex="-1">

5641Over a 10-year period, the International Cowden Consortium (ICC) prospectively recruited a consecutive series of adult and pediatric patients meeting relaxed ICC criteria for <em class="gene-name">

5642PTEN</em>

5643 testing in the United States, Europe, and Asia.[<a href="#cit/section_5.69">

564469</a>

5645] Most individuals did not meet the clinical criteria for a diagnosis of Cowden syndrome or BRRS. Of the 3,399 individuals recruited and tested, 295 probands (8.8%) and an additional 73 family members carried a germline <em class="gene-name">

5646PTEN</em>

5647 pathogenic variant. The authors concluded that melanoma, kidney cancer, and colorectal cancer should be added to the spectrum of cancers associated with <em class="gene-name">

5648PTEN</em>

5649 germline pathogenic variants (in addition to breast cancer, thyroid cancer, and endometrial cancer). This conclusion was based on the high melanoma, kidney, and colorectal cancer lifetime risk estimates found in individuals with <em class="gene-name">

5650PTEN</em>

5651 pathogenic variants. A second study of approximately 100 patients with a germline <em class="gene-name">

5652PTEN</em>

5653 pathogenic variant confirmed these findings and suggested a cumulative cancer risk of 85% by age 70 years.[<a href="#cit/section_5.70">

565470</a>

5655]</p>

5656</section>

5657<p id="_3779" tabindex="-1">

5658Although <em class="gene-name">

5659PTEN</em>

5660 pathogenic variants, which are estimated to occur in 1 in 200,000 individuals,[<a href="#cit/section_5.63">

566163</a>

5662] account for a small fraction of hereditary

5663breast cancer, the characterization of PTEN function will provide valuable

5664insights into the signal pathway and the maintenance of normal cell

5665physiology.[<a href="#cit/section_5.63">

566663</a>

5667,<a href="#cit/section_5.71">

566871</a>

5669] Lifetime breast cancer risk is estimated to be between 25% and 50% among women with Cowden syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_5.72">

567072</a>

5671] Other studies have reported risks as high as 85%;[<a href="#cit/section_5.69">

567269</a>

5673,<a href="#cit/section_5.70">

567470</a>

5675,<a href="#cit/section_5.73">

567673</a>

5677,<a href="#cit/section_5.74">

567874</a>

5679] however, there are concerns regarding selection bias in these studies. As in

5680other forms of hereditary breast cancer, onset is often at a young age and may

5681be bilateral.[<a href="#cit/section_5.75">

568275</a>

5683] Lifetime risk of endometrial cancer is estimated to be between 19% and 28%, depending on the cohort studied, with an increased risk of premenopausal onset.[<a href="#cit/section_5.69">

568469</a>

5685,<a href="#cit/section_5.70">

568670</a>

5687,<a href="#cit/section_5.76">

568876</a>

5689] Because of the low prevalence of <em class="gene-name">

5690PTEN</em>

5691 pathogenic variants in the population, the proportion of endometrial cancer attributable to Cowden syndrome is small. There are no data that link <em class="gene-name">

5692PTEN</em>

5693 pathogenic variants to an increased risk of ovarian cancer. Skin manifestations include multiple trichilemmomas, oral

5694fibromas and papillomas, and acral, palmar, and plantar keratoses. History or

5695observation of the characteristic skin features raises a suspicion of Cowden

5696syndrome. CNS manifestations include macrocephaly, developmental delay, and dysplastic gangliocytomas of the cerebellum.[<a href="#cit/section_5.77">

569777</a>

5698,<a href="#cit/section_5.78">

569978</a>

5700] (Refer to the PDQ summaries on <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2559">

5701Genetics of Colorectal Cancer</a>

5702 and <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_1292">

5703Genetics of Skin Cancer</a>

5704 for more information about <em class="gene-name">

5705PTEN</em>

5706 hamartoma tumor syndromes [including Cowden syndrome].)</p>

5707</section>

5708<section id="_3780">

5709<h3 id="_3780_toc">

5710Diffuse Gastric and Lobular Breast Cancer Syndrome</h3>

5711<p id="_3781" tabindex="-1">

5712The E-cadherin gene <em class="gene-name">

5713CDH1</em>

5714 was first described in 1998 in three Maori families with multiple cases of diffuse gastric cancer (DGC), leading to the designation of hereditary diffuse gastric cancer (HDGC). There have been multiple subsequent reports of an excess of lobular breast cancer in HDGC families.[<a href="#cit/section_5.79">

571579</a>

5716] <em class="gene-name">

5717CDH1</em>

5718 is located on chromosome 16q22.1 and encodes the E-cadherin protein, a calcium-dependent homophilic adhesion molecule that plays a key role in cellular adhesion, cell polarity, cell signaling, and maintenance of cellular differentiation and tissue morphology.[<a href="#cit/section_5.80">

571980</a>

5720] E-cadherin binds to various catenins to stabilize the cytoplasmic cell adhesion complex and to maintain the E-cadherin interaction with actin filament.[<a href="#cit/section_5.81">

572181</a>

5722] Loss of <em class="gene-name">

5723CDH1</em>

5724 can occur as a result of somatic mutations, loss of heterozygosity (LOH), or hypermethylation. It can also result in dedifferentiation and invasiveness in human cancers.[<a href="#cit/section_5.82">

572582</a>

5726,<a href="#cit/section_5.83">

572783</a>

5728] Classic histopathologic findings in gastrectomy specimens include <em>

5729in situ</em>

5730 signet ring cells and/or pagetoid spread of signet ring cells. Of all gastric cancers, 1% to 3% are attributed to inherited gastric cancer syndromes.[<a href="#cit/section_5.84">

573184</a>

5732]</p>

5733<p id="_3782" tabindex="-1">

5734HDGC is an autosomal dominant syndrome associated with poorly differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma of the stomach presenting as <em>

5735linitis plastica</em>

5736. It is a highly penetrant and highly fatal syndrome, with a risk of clinical DGC ranging from 40% to 83%.[<a href="#cit/section_5.79">

573779</a>

5738] The risk of lobular breast cancer, which is characterized by small uniform cells that tend to invade in &#8220;single files,&#8221; is also increased in HDGC. Although invasive lobular breast cancer represents only 10% to 15% of all breast cancers, the lifetime risk of lobular breast cancer in carriers of <em class="gene-name">

5739CDH1</em>

5740 pathogenic variants ranges from 30% to 50%.[<a href="#cit/section_5.81">

574181</a>

5742,<a href="#cit/section_5.82">

574382</a>

5744] Guidelines for screening for <em class="gene-name">

5745CDH1</em>

5746 vary but include multiple cases of DGC in a family, early age of DGC, or lobular breast cancer in a family with DGC. Approximately 25% of families meeting these criteria are found to have a pathogenic variant in <em class="gene-name">

5747CDH1</em>

5748.[<a href="#cit/section_5.84">

574984</a>

5750] <em class="gene-name">

5751CDH1</em>

5752 pathogenic variants have been found in some families with lobular breast cancer but no gastric cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_5.85">

575385</a>

5754] The management of individuals with <em class="gene-name">

5755CDH1</em>

5756 pathogenic variants without a family history of gastric cancer is unclear.[<a href="#cit/section_5.85">

575785</a>

5758]</p>

5759</section>

5760<section id="_3783">

5761<h3 id="_3783_toc">

5762Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome (PJS)</h3>

5763<section id="_sm_CDR0000738176_1248">

5764<p id="_sm_CDR0000738176_1249" tabindex="-1">

5765PJS is an early-onset autosomal dominant disorder

5766characterized by melanocytic macules on the lips, the perioral region, and buccal region;

5767and multiple gastrointestinal polyps, both hamartomatous and

5768adenomatous.[<a href="#cit/section_5.86">

576986</a>

5770-<a href="#cit/section_5.88">

577188</a>

5772] Germline pathogenic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

5773STK11</em>

5774 gene at chromosome 19p13.3 have been identified in the vast majority of PJS families.[<a href="#cit/section_5.89">

577589</a>

5776-<a href="#cit/section_5.93">

577793</a>

5778] The most common cancers in PJS are gastrointestinal. However, other organs are at increased risk of developing malignancies. For example, the cumulative risks have been estimated to be 32% to 54% for breast cancer [<a href="#cit/section_5.94">

577994</a>

5780-<a href="#cit/section_5.96">

578196</a>

5782] and 21% for ovarian cancer (mainly ovarian sex-cord tumors).[<a href="#cit/section_5.94">

578394</a>

5784] The risk for pancreatic cancer has been estimated to be more than 100-fold higher than that in the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_5.94">

578594</a>

5786] A systematic review found a lifetime cumulative cancer risk, all sites combined, of up to 93% in patients with PJS.[<a href="#cit/section_5.94">

578794</a>

5788,<a href="#cit/section_5.97">

578997</a>

5790] <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_sm_CDR0000738176_1250">

5791Table 6</a>

5792 shows the cumulative risk of these tumors. </p>

5793<p id="_sm_CDR0000738176_1255" tabindex="-1">

5794Females with PJS are also predisposed to the development of cervical adenoma malignum, a rare and very aggressive adenocarcinoma of the cervix.[<a href="#cit/section_5.98">

579598</a>

5796] In addition, females with PJS commonly develop benign ovarian sex-cord tumors with annular tubules, whereas males with PJS are predisposed to development of Sertoli-cell testicular tumors;[<a href="#cit/section_5.99">

579799</a>

5798] although neither of these two tumor types is malignant, they can cause symptoms related to increased estrogen production. </p>

5799<p id="_sm_CDR0000738176_1247" tabindex="-1">

5800Although the risk of malignancy appears to be exceedingly high in individuals with PJS based on the published literature, the possibility that selection and referral biases have resulted in overestimates of these risks should be considered. </p>

5801<table id="_sm_CDR0000738176_1250" class="table-default expandable-container">

5802<caption>

5844P</em>

596894</a>

5990<td>

599165&#8211;70</td>

5992<td>

59937&#8211;17</td>

5994<td>

5995[<a href="#cit/section_5.94">

599694</a>

5997-<a href="#cit/section_5.96">

599896</a>

5999]</td>

6000</tr>

600732&#8211;54</td>

601094</a>

601296</a>

6013]</td>

6020<td>

602494</a>

6049[<a href="#cit/section_5.94">

605094</a>

6051]</td>

6054<td>

6055Testes<span class="sup">

6056e</span>

6057</td>

6058<td>

605965</td>

6060<td>

60619</td>

6062<td>

6063[<a href="#cit/section_5.94">

606494</a>

6065]</td>

6066</tr>

6067</tbody>

6068</table>

6069<section id="_sm_CDR0000738176_1251">

6070<h5 id="_sm_CDR0000738176_1251_toc">

6071Peutz-Jeghers gene(s)</h5>

6072<p id="_sm_CDR0000738176_1252" tabindex="-1">

6073PJS is caused by pathogenic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

6074STK11</em>

6075 (also called <em class="gene-name">

6076LKB1</em>

6077) tumor suppressor gene located on chromosome 19p13.[<a href="#cit/section_5.90">

607890</a>

6079,<a href="#cit/section_5.91">

608091</a>

6081] Unlike the adenomas seen in familial adenomatous polyposis, the polyps arising in PJS are hamartomas. Studies of the hamartomatous polyps and cancers of PJS show allelic imbalance (LOH) consistent with the two-hit hypothesis, demonstrating that <em class="gene-name">

6082STK11</em>

6083 is a tumor suppressor gene.[<a href="#cit/section_5.102">

6084102</a>

6085,<a href="#cit/section_5.103">

6086103</a>

6087] However, heterozygous <em class="gene-name">

6088STK11</em>

6089 knockout mice develop hamartomas without inactivation of the remaining wild-type allele, suggesting that <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=781846&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000781846&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

6090haploinsufficiency</a>

6091 may be sufficient for initial tumor development in PJS.[<a href="#cit/section_5.104">

6092104</a>

6093] Subsequently, the cancers that develop in <em class="gene-name">

6094STK11</em>

6095 +/- mice do show LOH;[<a href="#cit/section_5.105">

6096105</a>

6097] indeed, compound mutant mice heterozygous for pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

6098STK11</em>

6099 +/- and homozygous for pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

6100TP53</em>

6101 -/- have accelerated development of both hamartomas and cancers.[<a href="#cit/section_5.106">

6102106</a>

6103]</p>

6104<p id="_sm_CDR0000738176_1253" tabindex="-1">

6105Germline variants of the <em class="gene-name">

6106STK11</em>

6107 gene represent a spectrum of nonsense, frameshift, and missense variants, and splice-site variants and large deletions.[<a href="#cit/section_5.89">

610889</a>

6109,<a href="#cit/section_5.95">

611095</a>

6111] </p>

6112<p id="_sm_CDR0000738176_2855" tabindex="-1">

6113Approximately 85% of variants are localized to regions of the kinase domain of the expressed protein. No strong genotype-phenotype correlations have been identified.[<a href="#cit/section_5.95">

611495</a>

6115] Up to 30% of variants are large deletions involving one or more exons of <em class="gene-name">

6116STK11</em>

6117, underscoring the importance of deletion analysis in suspected cases of PJS.[<a href="#cit/section_5.89">

611889</a>

6119]</p>

6120<p id="_sm_CDR0000738176_1254" tabindex="-1">

6121<em class="gene-name">

6122STK11</em>

6123 has been unequivocally demonstrated to cause PJS. Although earlier estimates using direct DNA sequencing showed a 50% pathogenic variant detection rate in <em class="gene-name">

6124STK11</em>

6125, studies adding techniques to detect large deletions have found pathogenic variants in up to 94% of individuals meeting clinical criteria for PJS.[<a href="#cit/section_5.89">

612689</a>

6127,<a href="#cit/section_5.97">

612897</a>

6129,<a href="#cit/section_5.107">

6130107</a>

6131] Given the results of these studies, it is unlikely that other major genes cause PJS.</p>

6132</section>

6133<section id="_sm_CDR0000738176_2853">

6134<h5 id="_sm_CDR0000738176_2853_toc">

6135Clinical management</h5>

6136<p id="_sm_CDR0000738176_2854" tabindex="-1">

6137The high cumulative risk of cancers in PJS has led to the various screening recommendations summarized in the table of <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_873">

6138Published Recommendations for Diagnosis and Surveillance of Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome (PJS)</a>

6139 in the PDQ summary on <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq">

6140Genetics of Colorectal Cancer</a>

6141.</p>

6142</section>

6143</section>

6144</section>

6145<section id="_3784">

6146<h3 id="_3784_toc">

6147<em class="gene-name">

6148PALB2</em>

6149</h3>

6150<p id="_3785" tabindex="-1">

6151PALB2 (partner and localizer of BRCA2) interacts with the BRCA2 protein and plays a role in homologous recombination and double-stranded DNA repair. Similar to <em class="gene-name">

6152BRIP1</em>

6153 and <em class="gene-name">

6154BRCA2</em>

6155, <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=775789&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000775789&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

6156biallelic</a>

6157 pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

6158PALB2</em>

6159 have also been shown to cause Fanconi anemia.[<a href="#cit/section_5.108">

6160108</a>

6161] </p>

6162<p id="_3786" tabindex="-1">

6163<em class="gene-name">

6164 PALB2</em>

6165 pathogenic variants have been screened for in multiple small studies of familial and early-onset breast cancer in multiple populations.[<a href="#cit/section_5.109">

6166109</a>

6167-<a href="#cit/section_5.127">

6168127</a>

6169] Pathogenic variant prevalence has ranged from 0.4% to 3.9%. Similar to <em class="gene-name">

6170BRIP1</em>

6171 and <em class="gene-name">

6172CHEK2</em>

6173, there was incomplete segregation of <em class="gene-name">

6174PALB2</em>

6175 pathogenic variants in families with hereditary breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_5.110">

6176110</a>

6177] Among 559 cases with CBC and 565 matched controls with unilateral breast cancer, pathogenic (truncating) <em class="gene-name">

6178PALB2</em>

6179 pathogenic variants were identified in 0.9% of cases and in none of the controls (RR, 5.3; 95% CI, 1.8&#8211;13.2).[<a href="#cit/section_5.121">

6180121</a>

6181]</p>

6182<p id="_3787" tabindex="-1">

6183Data based on 154 families with loss-of-function <em class="gene-name">

6184PALB2</em>

6185 variants suggest that this gene may be an important cause of hereditary breast cancer, with risks that overlap with <em class="gene-name">

6186BRCA2</em>

6187.[<a href="#cit/section_5.128">

6188128</a>

6189] In this study, analysis of 362 family members from 154 families with <em class="gene-name">

6190PALB2</em>

6191 pathogenic variants indicated that the AR of female breast cancer by age 70 years ranged from 33% (95% CI, 24%&#8211;44%) for those with no family history of breast cancer to 58% (95% CI, 50%&#8211;66%) for those with two or more FDRs with early-onset breast cancer. Furthermore, among 63 breast cancer cases in which HER2 status was known, 30% had triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). An earlier Finnish study reported on a <em class="gene-name">

6192PALB2</em>

6193 founder pathogenic variant (c.1592delT) that confers a 40% risk of breast cancer to age 70 years [<a href="#cit/section_5.111">

6194111</a>

6195] and is associated with a high incidence (54%) of TNBC and lower survival.[<a href="#cit/section_5.112">

6196112</a>

6197] Pathogenic variants have been observed in early-onset and familial breast cancer in many populations.[<a href="#cit/section_5.113">

6198113</a>

6199,<a href="#cit/section_5.114">

6200114</a>

6201] A large report of 1,824 patients with TNBC unselected for family history, recruited through 12 studies, identified 1.2% with a <em class="gene-name">

6202PALB2</em>

6203 pathogenic variant.[<a href="#cit/section_5.129">

6204129</a>

6205] (Refer to the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq#_3598">

6206<em class="gene-name">

6207BRCA2</em>

6208-associated breast cancer pathology</a>

6209 section in <em class="gene-name">

6210BRCA1</em>

6211 and <em class="gene-name">

6212BRCA2</em>

6213: Cancer Risks and Management for more information about this study.)</p>

6214<p id="_3788" tabindex="-1">

6215In a later Polish study of more than 12,529 unselected women with breast cancer and 4,702 controls, <em class="gene-name">

6216PALB2</em>

6217 pathogenic variants were detected in 116 cases (0.93%; 95% CI, 0.76%&#8211;1.09%) and 10 controls (0.21%; 95% CI, 0.08%&#8211;0.34%), with an OR for breast cancer of 4.39 (95% CI, 2.30&#8211;8.37).[<a href="#cit/section_5.130">

6218130</a>

6219] The study findings confirm a substantially elevated risk of breast cancer (24%&#8211;40%) among women with a <em class="gene-name">

6220PALB2</em>

6221 pathogenic variant up to age 75 years. The 5-year cumulative incidence of CBC was 10% among those with a <em class="gene-name">

6222PALB2</em>

6223 pathogenic variant, compared with 17% among those with a <em class="gene-name">

6224BRCA1</em>

6225 pathogenic variant and 3% among those without a variant in either gene. Furthermore, the 10-year survival for women with a <em class="gene-name">

6226PALB2</em>

6227 pathogenic variant and breast cancer was 48% (95% CI, 36.5%&#8211;63.2%), compared with 72.0% among those with a <em class="gene-name">

6228BRCA1</em>

6229 pathogenic variant and 74.7% among those without a variant in either gene. Among <em class="gene-name">

6230PALB2</em>

6231 carriers, breast tumors 2 cm or larger had substantially worse outcomes (32.4% 10-year survival), compared with tumors smaller than 2 cm (82.4% 10-year survival). Approximately one-third of those with a <em class="gene-name">

6232PALB2</em>

6233 pathogenic variant had TNBC, and the average age at breast cancer diagnosis was 53.3 years.</p>

6234<p id="_3789" tabindex="-1">

6235A similar case-control study from China enrolled 16,501 unselected patients with breast cancer and 5,890 controls. These patients were screened for <em class="gene-name">

6236PALB2</em>

6237, <em class="gene-name">

6238BRCA1</em>

6239, and <em class="gene-name">

6240BRCA2</em>

6241 pathogenic variants. The prevalence of <em class="gene-name">

6242PALB2</em>

6243 pathogenic variants was 0.97% in the cases and 0.19% in the controls. The OR for breast cancer for carriers was 5.23 (95% CI, 2.84&#8211;9.65; <em>

6244P </em>

6245&gt; .0001). <em class="gene-name">

6246PALB2</em>

6247 carriers were more likely to be age 30 years or younger (6.88% vs. 3.56%; <em>

6248P</em>

6249 = .04). <em class="gene-name">

6250PALB2</em>

6251 carriers were also more likely to have TNBCs (22.83% vs. 13.56%; <em>

6252P </em>

6253= .004), larger tumors (tumor size &#8805;2 cm, 55.93% vs. 45.93%; <em>

6254P </em>

6255= .04), node-positive tumors (49.60% vs. 38.80%; <em>

6256P </em>

6257= .018), and CBCs (6.29% vs. 2.01%; <em>

6258P </em>

6259= .003). Additionally, <em class="gene-name">

6260PALB2 </em>

6261carriers were more likely to have a family history of breast and/or ovarian cancers (20.63% vs. 7.96%; <em>

6262P</em>

6263 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_5.131">

6264131</a>

6265]</p>

6266<p id="_3790" tabindex="-1">

6267In the largest study to date, 524 families with pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

6268PALB2</em>

6269 recruited through an international effort, the RR of breast cancer in women was reported to be 7.18 (95% CI, 5.82&#8211;8.85), with a 53% risk (95% CI, 44%&#8211;63%) of breast cancer to age 80 years.[<a href="#cit/section_5.132">

6270132</a>

6271] Additional elevated risks reported included ovarian cancer (RR, 2.91; 95% CI, 1.40&#8211;6.04) with a lifetime risk of 5% (95% CI, 2%&#8211;10%), pancreatic cancer (RR, 2.37; 95% CI, 1.24&#8211;4.50) with a lifetime risk of 2% to 3% (95% CI for women, 1%&#8211;4%; 95% CI for men, 2%&#8211;5%), and male breast cancer (RR, 7.34; 95% CI, 1.28&#8211;42.18) with a lifetime risk of 1% (95% CI, 0.2%&#8211;5%). These findings confirm the role of <em class="gene-name">

6272PALB2</em>

6273 as an inherited breast cancer gene in women, while firmly establishing an association with ovarian, pancreatic, and male breast cancers.</p>

6274<p id="_3791" tabindex="-1">

6275Male breast cancer has been observed in <em class="gene-name">

6276PALB2</em>

6277 pathogenic variant&#8211;positive breast cancer families.[<a href="#cit/section_5.109">

6278109</a>

6279,<a href="#cit/section_5.115">

6280115</a>

6281,<a href="#cit/section_5.128">

6282128</a>

6283] In a study of 115 male breast cancer cases in which 18 men had <em class="gene-name">

6284BRCA2</em>

6285 pathogenic variants, an additional two men had either a pathogenic or predicted pathogenic <em class="gene-name">

6286PALB2</em>

6287 variant (accounting for about 10% of germline variants in the study and 1%&#8211;2% of the total sample).[<a href="#cit/section_5.109">

6288109</a>

6289] The RR of breast cancer for male carriers of <em class="gene-name">

6290PALB2</em>

6291 pathogenic variants compared with that seen in the general population was estimated to be 8.30 (95% CI, 0.77&#8211;88.56; <em>

6292P</em>

6293 = .08) in the study of 154 families.[<a href="#cit/section_5.128">

6294128</a>

6295]</p>

6296<p id="_3792" tabindex="-1">

6297After the identification of <em class="gene-name">

6298PALB2</em>

6299 pathogenic variants in pancreatic tumors and the detection of germline pathogenic variants in 3% of 96 familial pancreatic patients,[<a href="#cit/section_5.133">

6300133</a>

6301] numerous studies have pointed to a role for <em class="gene-name">

6302PALB2</em>

6303 in pancreatic cancer. <em class="gene-name">

6304PALB2</em>

6305 pathogenic variants were detected in 3.7% of 81 familial pancreatic cancer families [<a href="#cit/section_5.134">

6306134</a>

6307] and in 2.1% of 94 <em class="gene-name">

6308BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

6309 pathogenic variant&#8211;negative breast cancer patients who had either a personal or family history of pancreatic cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_5.135">

6310135</a>

6311] Two relatively small studies&#8212;one of 77 <em class="gene-name">

6312BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

6313 pathogenic variant&#8211;negative probands with a personal or family

6314history of pancreatic cancer, one-half of whom were of AJ descent, and another study of 29 Italian pancreatic cancer patients with a personal or family history of breast or ovarian cancer&#8212;failed to detect any <em class="gene-name">

6315PALB2</em>

6316 pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_5.136">

6317136</a>

6318,<a href="#cit/section_5.137">

6319137</a>

6320] A sixfold increase in pancreatic cancer was observed in the relatives of 33 <em class="gene-name">

6321BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

6322-negative, <em class="gene-name">

6323PALB2</em>

6324 pathogenic variant&#8211;positive breast cancer probands.[<a href="#cit/section_5.115">

6325115</a>

6326]</p>

6327<p id="_3793" tabindex="-1">

6328Overall, the observed prevalence of <em class="gene-name">

6329PALB2</em>

6330 pathogenic variants in familial breast cancer varied depending on ascertainment relative to personal and family history of pancreatic and ovarian cancers, but in

6331all studies, the observed pathogenic variant rate was lower than 4%. Data suggest that the RR of breast cancer may overlap with that of <em class="gene-name">

6332BRCA2</em>

6333, particularly in those with a strong family history; thus, it remains important to refine cancer risk estimates in larger studies. Furthermore, the risk of other cancers (e.g., pancreatic) is poorly defined. Given the low <em class="gene-name">

6334PALB2</em>

6335 pathogenic variant prevalence in the population, additional data are needed to define best candidates for testing and appropriate management.</p>

6336</section>

6337<section id="_2591">

6338<h3 id="_2591_toc">

6339De Novo Pathogenic Variant Rate</h3>

6340<p id="_2592" tabindex="-1">

6341Until the 1990s, the diagnosis of genetically inherited breast and ovarian cancer syndromes was based on clinical manifestations and family history. Now that some of the genes involved in these syndromes have been identified, a few studies have attempted to estimate the spontaneous pathogenic variant rate (<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783882&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783882&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

6342de novo pathogenic variant</a>

6343 rate) in these populations. Interestingly, PJS, <em class="gene-name">

6344PTEN</em>

6345 hamartoma syndromes, and LFS are all thought to have high rates of spontaneous pathogenic variants, in the 10% to 30% range,[<a href="#cit/section_5.138">

6346138</a>

6347-<a href="#cit/section_5.141">

6348141</a>

6349] while estimates of de novo pathogenic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

6350BRCA</em>

6351 genes are thought to be low, primarily on the basis of the few case reports published.[<a href="#cit/section_5.142">

6352142</a>

6353-<a href="#cit/section_5.150">

6354150</a>

6355] Additionally, there has been only one case series of breast cancer patients who were tested for <em class="gene-name">

6356BRCA</em>

6357 pathogenic variants in which a de novo variant was identified. Specifically, in this study of 193 patients with sporadic breast cancer, 17 pathogenic variants were detected, one of which was confirmed to be a de novo pathogenic variant.[<a href="#cit/section_5.142">

6358142</a>

6359] As such, the de novo pathogenic variant rate appears to be low and fall into the 5% or less range, based on the limited studies performed.[<a href="#cit/section_5.142">

6360142</a>

6361-<a href="#cit/section_5.150">

6362150</a>

6363] Similarly, estimates of de novo pathogenic variants in the MMR genes associated with Lynch syndrome are thought to be low, in the 0.9% to 5% range.[<a href="#cit/section_5.151">

6364151</a>

6365-<a href="#cit/section_5.153">

6366153</a>

6367] However, these estimates of spontaneous pathogenic variant rates in the <em class="gene-name">

6368BRCA</em>

6369 genes and Lynch syndrome genes seem to overlap with the estimates of nonpaternity rates in various populations (0.6%&#8211;3.3%),[<a href="#cit/section_5.154">

6370154</a>

6371-<a href="#cit/section_5.156">

6372156</a>

6373] making the de novo pathogenic variant rate for these genes relatively low.</p>

6374</section>

6424[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6425</li>

J Natl Cancer Inst 89 (23): 1758-62, 1997.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9392616&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9392616&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6428[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6429</li>

6430<li id="section_5.14">

6431Umar A, Boland CR, Terdiman JP, et al.: Revised Bethesda Guidelines for hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (Lynch syndrome) and microsatellite instability. J Natl Cancer Inst 96 (4): 261-8, 2004.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=14970275&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=14970275&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6432[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6433</li>

6928[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6929</li>

6930<li id="section_5.141">

6931Bendig I, Mohr N, Kramer F, et al.: Identification of novel TP53 mutations in familial and sporadic cancer cases of German and Swiss origin. Cancer Genet Cytogenet 154 (1): 22-6, 2004.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15381368&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=15381368&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6932[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6933</li>

6934<li id="section_5.142">

6935De Leeneer K, Coene I, Crombez B, et al.: Prevalence of BRCA1/2 mutations in sporadic breast/ovarian cancer patients and identification of a novel de novo BRCA1 mutation in a patient diagnosed with late onset breast and ovarian cancer: implications for genetic testing. 6945</li>
