6997

6998 </section>

6999

7000

7001

7002 <section id="_156">

7003

7004 <h2>

7005Moderate-Penetrance Genes Associated With Breast and/or Gynecologic Cancers</h2>

7006

7007 <div id="_section_156" class="pdq-sections">

7008<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

7009<h6>

7010In This Section</h6>

7011<ul>

7012<li>

7013<a href="#_157_toc">

7014Background</a>

7015</li>

7016<li>

7017<a href="#_1308_toc">

7018Breast and Gynecologic Cancer Susceptibility Genes Identified Through Candidate Gene Approaches<ul>

7019<li>

7020<a href="#_2779_toc">

7021Fanconi anemia genes</a>

7022</li>

7023<li>

7024<a href="#_1309_toc">

7025<em class="gene-name">

7026CHEK2</em>

7027</a>

7028</li>

7029<li>

7030<a href="#_1311_toc">

7031<em class="gene-name">

7032ATM</em>

7033</a>

7034</li>

7035<li>

7036<a href="#_2111_toc">

7037<em class="gene-name">

7038RAD51</em>

7039</a>

7040</li>

7041<li>

7042<a href="#_2872_toc">

7043<em class="gene-name">

7044SMARCA4</em>

7045</a>

7046</li>

7047</ul>

7048</a>

7049</li>

7050</ul>

7051</nav>

7052<section id="_157">

7053<h3 id="_157_toc">

7054Background</h3>

7055<p id="_1305" tabindex="-1">

7056<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7057Pathogenic variants</a>

7058 in <em class="gene-name">

7059BRCA1</em>

7060, <em class="gene-name">

7061BRCA2</em>

7062, <em class="gene-name">

7063PALB2</em>

7064, and the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7065genes</a>

7066 involved in other rare syndromes discussed in the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_88">

7067High-Penetrance Breast and/or Gynecologic Cancer Susceptibility Genes</a>

7068 section of this summary account for less than 25% of the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460148&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460148&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7069familial</a>

7070 risk of breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_6.1">

70711</a>

7072] Despite intensive genetic <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=425374&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000425374&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7073linkage studies</a>

7074, there do not appear to be other high-<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339344&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339344&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7075penetrance</a>

7076 genes that account for a significant fraction of the remaining multiple-case familial clusters.[<a href="#cit/section_6.2">

70772</a>

7078] However, several moderate-penetrance genes associated with breast and/or gynecologic cancers have been identified. Genes such as <em class="gene-name">

7079CHEK2</em>

7080 and <em class="gene-name">

7081ATM</em>

7082 are associated with a 20% or higher lifetime risk of breast cancer;[<a href="#cit/section_6.3">

70833</a>

7084,<a href="#cit/section_6.4">

70854</a>

7086] similarly, genes such as <em class="gene-name">

7087RAD51C</em>

7088, <em class="gene-name">

7089RAD51D</em>

7090, and <em class="gene-name">

7091BRIP1</em>

7092 are associated with a 5% to 10% risk of ovarian cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_6.5">

70935</a>

7094,<a href="#cit/section_6.6">

70956</a>

7096] Many of these genes are now included on <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=775581&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000775581&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7097multigene panels</a>

7098, although the clinical actionability of these findings remains uncertain and under investigation. </p>

7099</section>

7100<section id="_1308">

7101<h3 id="_1308_toc">

7102Breast and Gynecologic Cancer Susceptibility Genes Identified Through Candidate Gene Approaches</h3>

7103<p id="_1914" tabindex="-1">

7104There is a very large literature of genetic epidemiology studies describing associations between various <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460162&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460162&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7105loci</a>

7106 and breast cancer risk. Many of these studies suffer from significant design limitations. Perhaps as a consequence, most reported associations do not replicate in follow-up studies. This section is not a comprehensive review of all reported associations. This section describes associations that are believed by the editors to be clinically valid, in that they have been described in several studies or are supported by robust meta-analyses. The clinical utility of these observations remains unclear, however, as the risks associated with these variations usually fall below a threshold that would justify a clinical response.</p>

7107<section id="_2779">

7108<h4 id="_2779_toc">

7109Fanconi anemia genes</h4>

7110<p id="_2784" tabindex="-1">

7111Fanconi anemia (FA) is a rare, inherited condition characterized by bone marrow failure, increased risk of malignancy, and physical abnormalities. To date, 16 FA-related genes, including <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq">

7112BRCA1 and BRCA2</a>

7113, have been identified (as outlined in <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2837">

7114Table 7</a>

7115). FA is mainly an <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339339&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339339&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7116autosomal recessive</a>

7117 condition, except when caused by pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

7118FANCB</em>

7119, which is <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339348&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339348&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7120X-linked recessive</a>

7121. <em class="gene-name">

7122FANCA</em>

7123 accounts for 60% to 70% of pathogenic variants, <em class="gene-name">

7124FANCC</em>

7125 accounts for approximately 14%, and the remaining genes each account for 3% or fewer.[<a href="#cit/section_6.7">

71267</a>

7127]</p>

7128<table id="_2837" class="table-default expandable-container">

7129<caption>

7130Table 7. Fanconi Anemia Genes and Breast Cancer Risk</caption>

7131<colgroup>

7132<col width="100.00%">

7133</colgroup>

7134<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

7135<tr>

7136<td>

7137<span class="sup">

7138a</span>

7139Refer to the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq#_3468">

7140<em class="gene-name">

7141BRCA1</em>

7142 and <em class="gene-name">

7143BRCA2</em>

7144</a>

7145 summary for information about the cumulative risk of breast cancer in <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460132&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460132&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7146carriers</a>

7147 of <em class="gene-name">

7148BRCA1</em>

7149 and <em class="gene-name">

7150BRCA2</em>

7151 pathogenic variants.</td>

7152</tr>

7153<tr>

7154<td>

7155<span class="sup">

7156b</span>

7157Refer to the <em class="gene-name">

7158<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_3784">

7159PALB2</a>

7160</em>

7161 section for information about the cumulative risk of breast cancer in carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7162PALB2</em>

7163 pathogenic variants.</td>

7164</tr>

7254FANCA

7255</em>

7260&#8211; <em class="gene-name">

7261FANCB</em>

7262

7286</tr>

7287<tr>

7288<td>

7290<em class="gene-name">

7291FANCG</em>

7292 (<em class="gene-name">

7293XRCC9</em>

7294)

7295</td>

7296</tr>

7297<tr>

7298<td>

7299&#8211; <em class="gene-name">

7300FANCI</em>

7301 (<em class="gene-name">

7302KIAA1794</em>

7303)

7304</td>

7305</tr>

7306<tr>

7307<td>

7308&#8211; <em class="gene-name">

7309FANCL</em>

7310</td>

7311</tr>

7312<tr>

7313<td>

7314&#8211; <em class="gene-name">

7315SLX4</em>

7316 (<em class="gene-name">

7317FANCP</em>

7318)</td>

7319</tr>

7320<tr>

7321<td>

7322&#8211; <em class="gene-name">

7323ERCC4</em>

7324 (<em class="gene-name">

7325FANCQ/XPF</em>

7326)

7327</td>

7328</tr>

7329</tbody>

7330</table>

7331<p id="_2785" tabindex="-1">

7332Progressive bone marrow failure typically occurs in the first decade, with patients often presenting with thrombocytopenia or leucopenia. The incidence of bone marrow failure is 90% by age 40 to 50 years. The incidence is 10% to 30% for hematologic malignancies (primarily acute myeloid leukemia) and 25% to 30% for nonhematologic malignancies (solid tumors, particularly of the head and neck, skin, gastrointestinal [GI] tract, and genital tract). Physical abnormalities, including short stature, abnormal skin pigmentation, radial ray defects (including malformation of the thumbs), abnormalities of the urinary tract, eyes, ears, heart, GI system, and central nervous system, hypogonadism, and developmental delay are present in 60% to 75% of affected individuals.[<a href="#cit/section_6.7">

73337</a>

7334]</p>

7335<p id="_2786" tabindex="-1">

7336Variants in some of the FA genes, most notably <em class="gene-name">

7337BRCA1</em>

7338 and <em class="gene-name">

7339BRCA2</em>

7340, but also <em class="gene-name">

7341PALB2</em>

7342, <em class="gene-name">

7343RAD51C</em>

7344 (in the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2111">

7345<em class="gene-name">

7346RAD51</em>

7347 family of genes</a>

7348), and <em class="gene-name">

7349BRIP1</em>

7350, among others, may predispose to breast cancer in heterozygotes. Given the widespread availability of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=763019&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000763019&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7351multigene (panel) tests</a>

7352, genetic testing of many of the FA genes is frequently performed despite uncertain cancer risks and the lack of available evidence-based medical management recommendations for many of these genes.</p>

7353<p id="_2787" tabindex="-1">

7354FA gene pathogenic variant carrier status can have implications for reproductive decision making because pathogenic variants in these genes can lead to serious childhood onset of disease if both parents are carriers of pathogenic variants in the same gene. Partner testing may be considered.</p>

7355<section id="_2780">

7356<h5 id="_2780_toc">

7357<em class="gene-name">

7358BRIP1</em>

7359</h5>

7360<p id="_2781" tabindex="-1">

7361<em class="gene-name">

7362BRIP1</em>

7363 (also known as <em class="gene-name">

7364BACH1</em>

7365) encodes a helicase that interacts with the <em class="gene-name">

7366BRCA1</em>

7367 C-terminal domain. This gene also has a role in BRCA1-dependent DNA repair and cell cycle checkpoint function. <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=775789&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000775789&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7368Biallelic</a>

7369 pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

7370BRIP1</em>

7371 are a cause of FA,[<a href="#cit/section_6.8">

73728</a>

7373-<a href="#cit/section_6.10">

737410</a>

7375] much like such pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

7376BRCA2</em>

7377. </p>

7378<p id="_3438" tabindex="-1">

7379Monoallelic pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

7380BRIP1</em>

7381 have emerged as having a significant association with increased ovarian cancer risk. Nine-tenths to two and half percent of women with ovarian cancer carry a pathogenic variant in <em class="gene-name">

7382BRIP1</em>

7383.[<a href="#cit/section_6.11">

738411</a>

7385] Odds ratios (ORs) for ovarian cancer in individuals with a <em class="gene-name">

7386BRIP1</em>

7387 pathogenic variant range from 2.2 to 5.0.[<a href="#cit/section_6.12">

738812</a>

7389] The median age of ovarian cancer diagnosis in individuals with <em class="gene-name">

7390BRIP1</em>

7391 pathogenic variants ranges from the mid-50s to 70 years. <em class="gene-name">

7392BRIP1 </em>

7393pathogenic variants have been seen in high-grade serous, borderline, and endometrioid ovarian cancers, but not in clear-cell or mucinous types.[<a href="#cit/section_6.13">

739413</a>

7395] Per current National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) guidelines, risk-reducing salpingo-oophorectomy is recommended for women who carry a <em class="gene-name">

7396BRIP1</em>

7397 pathogenic variant.[<a href="#cit/section_6.14">

739814</a>

7399]</p>

7400<p id="_3439" tabindex="-1">

7401With respect to breast cancer risk, several studies consistently report ORs less than 2.0. A meta-analysis of 148 studies found an OR for breast cancer of 1.62 in individuals with <em class="gene-name">

7402BRIP1</em>

7403 pathogenic variants (95% confidence interval [CI], 1.20&#8211;2.20).[<a href="#cit/section_6.15">

740415</a>

7405] ORs for breast cancer in <em class="gene-name">

7406BRIP1</em>

7407 carriers ranged from 0.60 to 1.81 in other studies. There is a growing consensus that <em class="gene-name">

7408 BRIP1</em>

7409 is not a moderate- to high-risk breast cancer susceptibility gene. However, studies are looking at the possible associations between <em class="gene-name">

7410BRIP1</em>

7411 pathogenic variants and certain subtypes of breast cancer, such as triple-negative breast cancer. Limitations of these <em class="gene-name">

7412BRIP1</em>

7413 association studies include the following: rarity of <em class="gene-name">

7414BRIP1</em>

7415 pathogenic variants, heterogeneity of study methodologies, and inconsistent reporting of family histories in many of the published studies.</p>

7416</section>

7417</section>

7418<section id="_1309">

7419<h4 id="_1309_toc">

7420<em class="gene-name">

7421CHEK2</em>

7422</h4>

7423<p id="_1310" tabindex="-1">

7424<em class="gene-name">

7425CHEK2</em>

7426 is a gene involved in the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45671&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045671&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7427DNA</a>

7428 damage repair response pathway. Based on numerous studies, a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44805&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044805&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7429polymorphism</a>

7430, 1100delC, appears to be a rare, moderate-penetrance cancer susceptibility allele.[<a href="#cit/section_6.16">

743116</a>

7432-<a href="#cit/section_6.21">

743321</a>

7434] One study identified the pathogenic variant in 1.2% of the European controls, 4.2% of the European <em class="gene-name">

7435BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

7436-negative familial breast cancer cases, and 1.4% of unselected female breast cancer cases.[<a href="#cit/section_6.16">

743716</a>

7438] In a group of 1,479 Dutch women younger than 50 years with invasive breast cancer, 3.7% were found to have the <em class="gene-name">

7439CHEK2</em>

7440 1100delC pathogenic variant.[<a href="#cit/section_6.22">

744122</a>

7442] In additional European and U.S. (where the pathogenic variant appears to be slightly less common) studies, including a large prospective study,[<a href="#cit/section_6.23">

744323</a>

7444] the frequency of <em class="gene-name">

7445CHEK2</em>

7446 pathogenic variants detected in familial breast or ovarian cancer cases has ranged from 0% [<a href="#cit/section_6.24">

744724</a>

7448] to 11%; overall, these studies have found an approximately 1.5-fold to 3-fold increased risk of female breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_6.23">

744923</a>

7450,<a href="#cit/section_6.25">

745125</a>

7452-<a href="#cit/section_6.28">

745328</a>

7454] A multicenter combined analysis and reanalysis of nearly 20,000 subjects from ten case-control studies, however, has verified a significant 2.3-fold excess of breast cancer among carriers of pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_6.29">

745529</a>

7456] A subsequent meta-analysis based on 29,154 cases and 37,064 controls from 25 case-control studies found a significant association between <em class="gene-name">

7457CHEK2</em>

7458 1100delC heterozygotes and breast cancer risk (OR, 2.75; 95% CI, 2.25&#8211;3.36). The ORs and CIs in unselected, familial, and early-onset breast cancer subgroups were 2.33 (1.79&#8211;3.05), 3.72 (2.61&#8211;5.31), and 2.78 (2.28&#8211;3.39), respectively. However, study limitations included pooling of populations without subgroup analysis, using a mix of population-based and hospital-based controls, and basing results on unadjusted estimates (as cases and controls were matched on only a few common factors); therefore, results should be interpreted in the context of these limitations.[<a href="#cit/section_6.30">

745930</a>

7460] In a series of male breast cancer patients, the <em class="gene-name">

7461CHEK2</em>

7462 1100delC variant was significantly more frequently identified than in controls, suggesting that this variant is also associated with an increased risk of male breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_6.31">

746331</a>

7464]</p>

7465<p id="_1630" tabindex="-1">

7466Two studies have suggested that the risk associated with a <em class="gene-name">

7467CHEK2</em>

7468 1100delC pathogenic variant was stronger in the families of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460211&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460211&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7469probands</a>

7470 ascertained because of bilateral breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_6.32">

747132</a>

7472,<a href="#cit/section_6.33">

747333</a>

7474] Furthermore, a meta-analysis of carriers of 1100delC pathogenic variants estimated the risk of breast cancer to be 42% by age 70 years in women with a family history of breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_6.34">

747534</a>

7476] Similarly, a Polish study reported that <em class="gene-name">

7477CHEK2</em>

7478 truncating pathogenic variants confer breast cancer risks based on a family history of breast cancer as follows: no family history, 20%; one <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=485395&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000485395&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7479second-degree relative</a>

7480 (SDR), 28%; one <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460150&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460150&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7481first-degree relative</a>

7482 (FDR), 34%; and both FDRs and SDRs, 44%.[<a href="#cit/section_6.3">

74833</a>

7484] Moreover, a Dutch study suggested that female homozygotes for the <em class="gene-name">

7485CHEK2</em>

7486 1100delC variant have a greater-than-twofold increased breast cancer risk compared with heterozygotes.[<a href="#cit/section_6.35">

748735</a>

7488] Although there have been conflicting reports regarding cancers other than breast cancer associated with <em class="gene-name">

7489CHEK2</em>

7490 pathogenic variants, this may be dependent on variant type (i.e., <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783964&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783964&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7491missense</a>

7492 vs. truncating) or population studied and is not currently of clinical utility.[<a href="#cit/section_6.21">

749321</a>

7494,<a href="#cit/section_6.26">

749526</a>

7496,<a href="#cit/section_6.36">

749736</a>

7498-<a href="#cit/section_6.41">

749941</a>

7500] The contribution of <em class="gene-name">

7501CHEK2</em>

7502 variants to breast cancer may depend on the population studied, with a potentially higher variant prevalence in Poland.[<a href="#cit/section_6.42">

750342</a>

7504] Carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7505CHEK2</em>

7506 variants in Poland may be more susceptible to estrogen receptor (ER)&#8211;positive breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_6.43">

750743</a>

7508] </p>

7509<p id="_2995" tabindex="-1">

7510A large Dutch study of 86,975 individuals reported an increased risk of cancers other than breast and colon for carriers of the <em class="gene-name">

7511CHEK2</em>

7512 1100delC pathogenic variant,[<a href="#cit/section_6.44">

751344</a>

7514] although additional studies are needed to further refine these risks.</p>

7515<p id="_2590" tabindex="-1">

7516(Refer to the <em class="gene-name">

7517<a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_651">

7518CHEK2</a>

7519</em>

7520 section in Genetics of Colorectal Cancer for more information.)</p>

7521</section>

7522<section id="_1311">

7523<h4 id="_1311_toc">

7524<em class="gene-name">

7525ATM</em>

7526</h4>

7527<p id="_1312" tabindex="-1">

7528Ataxia telangiectasia (AT) is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by

7529neurologic deterioration, telangiectasias, immunodeficiency states, and

7530hypersensitivity to ionizing radiation. It is estimated that 1%

7531of the general population may be heterozygote carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7532ATM</em>

7533 variants.[<a href="#cit/section_6.45">

753445</a>

7535] More than 300 variants in the gene have been

7536identified, most of which are truncating

7537variants.[<a href="#cit/section_6.46">

753846</a>

7539] ATM proteins have been shown to play a role in cell cycle

7540control.[<a href="#cit/section_6.47">

754147</a>

7542-<a href="#cit/section_6.49">

754349</a>

7544] <em>

7545In vitro</em>

7546, AT-deficient cells are sensitive to ionizing radiation and

7547radiomimetic drugs, and lack cell cycle regulatory properties after exposure to

7548radiation.[<a href="#cit/section_6.50">

754950</a>

7550] There is insufficient evidence to recommend against radiation therapy in carriers of a single <em class="gene-name">

7551ATM</em>

7552 pathogenic variant (heterozygotes).</p>

7553<p id="_1313" tabindex="-1">

7554Initial, large epidemiological studies demonstrated a statistically increased relative risk (RR) of approximately 2.0 for breast cancer among female

7555<em class="gene-name">

7556ATM</em>

7557 heterozygotes.[<a href="#cit/section_6.4">

75584</a>

7559,<a href="#cit/section_6.51">

756051</a>

7561]

7562 Subsequent, large international consortium-based studies have refined risk estimates.[<a href="#cit/section_6.52">

756352</a>

7564,<a href="#cit/section_6.53">

756553</a>

7566] An international study based on 113,000 females from 25 countries reported an OR of 2.10 (95% CI, 1.71&#8211;2.57) for breast cancer in <em class="gene-name">

7567ATM</em>

7568 heterozygotes. <em class="gene-name">

7569ATM</em>

7570 pathogenic variants were also associated with ER-positive tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_6.52">

757152</a>

7572] Domains specifically associated with higher breast cancer risks included the FRAP&#8211;ATM&#8211;TRRAP (FAT) domain (<em>

7573P</em>

7574 = .00019 in all studies) and protein kinase domains (<em>

7575P</em>

7576 = .00092 in all studies). Similarly, a United States&#8211;based study of 63,000 women reported an OR of 1.82 for breast cancer in <em class="gene-name">

7577ATM</em>

7578 heterozygotes (95% CI, 1.46&#8211;2.27) and also reported an association between <em class="gene-name">

7579ATM</em>

7580 pathogenic variants and ER-positive breast cancers.[<a href="#cit/section_6.53">

758153</a>

7582] A similar OR of 2.03 (95% CI, 1.89&#8211;2.19) was estimated for invasive ductal breast cancer through a commercial, lab-based study of 4,607 individuals with <em class="gene-name">

7583ATM </em>

7584pathogenic or likely pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_6.54">

758554</a>

7586]</p>

7587<p id="_3440" tabindex="-1">

7588Age-specific cumulative breast cancer risks modeled through a meta-analysis were reported to be 6.02% by age 50 years and 32.83% by age 80 years.[<a href="#cit/section_6.55">

758955</a>

7590] Another meta-analysis reported the RR for female breast cancer as 3.0 in <em class="gene-name">

7591ATM</em>

7592 carriers (95% CI, 2.1&#8211;4.5).[<a href="#cit/section_6.56">

759356</a>

7594] A subsequent systematic review and meta-analysis estimated an adjusted OR of 1.67 for breast cancer risk in individuals with <em class="gene-name">

7595ATM</em>

7596 pathogenic variants (95% CI, 0.73&#8211;3.82) based on seven adjusted case-control studies.[<a href="#cit/section_6.57">

759757</a>

7598] The crude OR was 2.27 (95% CI, 1.17&#8211;4.40) based on nine unadjusted case-control studies. The RR was estimated as 1.68 (95% CI, 1.17&#8211;2.40) based on two cohort studies. Overall, the findings suggested genotype-phenotype correlations, with the<em class="gene-name">

7599 ATM</em>

7600 c.7271T&gt;G variant (also known as the <em class="gene-name">

7601ATM</em>

7602 Val2424Gly variant) as the most predisposing factor and with limited predictive ability for Asp1853Val, Leu546Val, and Ser707Pro <em class="gene-name">

7603ATM</em>

7604 variants. Per current NCCN guidelines, it is recommended that women who carry an <em class="gene-name">

7605ATM</em>

7606 pathogenic variant have annual mammograms starting at age 40 years with consideration of breast magnetic resonance imaging with contrast beginning at age 30 to 35 years.[<a href="#cit/section_6.14">

760714</a>

7608]</p>

7609<p id="_3441" tabindex="-1">

7610While multiple studies have reported that most <em class="gene-name">

7611ATM</em>

7612 pathogenic variants impart moderate risks for breast cancer, the c.7271T&gt;G missense variant has been shown to predispose individuals to higher breast cancer risks.[<a href="#cit/section_6.58">

761358</a>

7614,<a href="#cit/section_6.59">

761559</a>

7616] Specifically, in a commercial laboratory, data-based study of patients referred for hereditary cancer testing with a multi-gene panel (N = 627,742), including 4,607 <em class="gene-name">

7617ATM</em>

7618 pathogenic or likely pathogenic variant carriers, risk of invasive ductal breast cancer was higher for the c.7271T&gt;G missense variant (OR, 3.76; 95% CI, 2.76&#8211;5.12) than for other missense and truncating <em class="gene-name">

7619ATM</em>

7620 variants.[<a href="#cit/section_6.54">

762154</a>

7622]</p>

7623<p id="_3260" tabindex="-1">

7624Some studies reported an association between <em class="gene-name">

7625ATM</em>

7626 and ovarian cancer, with ovarian cancer lifetime risk approaching ~3%.[<a href="#cit/section_6.60">

762760</a>

7628,<a href="#cit/section_6.61">

762961</a>

7630] A commercial laboratory, data-based study reported an OR of 1.57 (95% CI, 1.35&#8211;1.83) for ovarian cancer in <em class="gene-name">

7631ATM</em>

7632 pathogenic variant carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_6.54">

763354</a>

7634] </p>

7635<p id="_3442" tabindex="-1">

7636Pancreatic cancer has also been associated with <em class="gene-name">

7637ATM</em>

7638 pathogenic variants, with an OR of 4.21 (95% CI, 3.24&#8211;5.47) reported through a commercial lab&#8211;based study.[<a href="#cit/section_6.54">

763954</a>

7640] Among 130 pancreatic cancer kindreds with a germline <em class="gene-name">

7641ATM</em>

7642 pathogenic variant, the cumulative risk of pancreatic cancer was 1.1% (95% CI, 0.8%&#8211;1.3%) by age 50 years, 6.3% (95% CI, 3.9%&#8211;8.7%) by age 70 years, and 9.5% (95% CI, 5.0%&#8211;14.0%) by age 80 years.[<a href="#cit/section_6.62">

764362</a>

7644] Overall, the RR of pancreatic cancer was 6.5 (95% CI, 4.5&#8211;9.5) in <em class="gene-name">

7645ATM </em>

7646pathogenic variant carriers when compared with noncarriers. The average age at diagnosis was 64 years (range, 31&#8211;98 y).</p>

7647<p id="_3443" tabindex="-1">

7648The association between <em class="gene-name">

7649ATM</em>

7650 pathogenic variants and prostate cancer risk have been inconclusive, with a commercial lab&#8211;based study reporting an OR of 2.58 (95% CI, 1.93&#8211;3.44).[<a href="#cit/section_6.54">

765154</a>

7652] For more information, see the <em class="gene-name">

7653<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-genetics-pdq#_1416">

7654ATM</a>

7655</em>

7656 section in Genetics of Prostate Cancer.</p>

7657</section>

7658<section id="_2111">

7659<h4 id="_2111_toc">

7660<em class="gene-name">

7661RAD51</em>

7662</h4>

7663<p id="_2475" tabindex="-1">

7664<em class="gene-name">

7665RAD51</em>

7666 and the family of <em class="gene-name">

7667RAD51</em>

7668-related genes, also known as <em class="gene-name">

7669RAD51</em>

7670 paralogs, are thought to encode proteins that are involved in DNA damage repair through homologous recombination and interaction with numerous other DNA repair proteins, including BRCA1 and BRCA2. RAD51 protein plays a central role in single-strand annealing in the DNA damage response. RAD51 recruitment to break sites and recombinational DNA repair depend on the <em class="gene-name">

7671RAD51</em>

7672 paralogs, although their precise cellular functions are poorly characterized.[<a href="#cit/section_6.63">

767363</a>

7674] Variants in these genes are thought to result in loss of RAD51 focus formation in response to DNA damage.[<a href="#cit/section_6.64">

767564</a>

7676]</p>

7677<p id="_2476" tabindex="-1">

7678One of five <em class="gene-name">

7679RAD51</em>

7680-related genes, <em class="gene-name">

7681RAD51C</em>

7682 has been reported to be linked to both FA-like disorders and familial breast and ovarian cancers. The literature, however, has produced contradictory findings. In a study of 480 German families characterized by breast and ovarian cancers who were negative for <em class="gene-name">

7683BRCA1</em>

7684 and <em class="gene-name">

7685BRCA2</em>

7686 pathogenic variants, six monoallelic variants in <em class="gene-name">

7687RAD51C</em>

7688 were found (frequency of 1.3%).[<a href="#cit/section_6.65">

768965</a>

7690] Another study screened 286 <em class="gene-name">

7691BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

7692-negative patients with breast cancer and/or ovarian cancer and found one likely pathogenic variant in <em class="gene-name">

7693RAD51C</em>

7694-G153D.[<a href="#cit/section_6.66">

769566</a>

7696] <em class="gene-name">

7697RAD51C</em>

7698 pathogenic variants have also been reported in Australian, British, Finnish, and Spanish non-<em class="gene-name">

7699BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

7700 ovarian cancer&#8211;only and breast/ovarian cancer families, and in unselected ovarian cancer cases, with frequencies ranging from 0% to 3% in these populations.[<a href="#cit/section_6.5">

77015</a>

7702,<a href="#cit/section_6.67">

770367</a>

7704-<a href="#cit/section_6.73">

770573</a>

7706] In a sample of 206 high-risk Jewish women (including 79 of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460127&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460127&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7707Ashkenazi</a>

7708 origin) previously tested for the common Jewish pathogenic variants, two previously described and possibly pathogenic missense variants were detected.[<a href="#cit/section_6.74">

770974</a>

7710] Four additional studies were unable to confirm an association between the <em class="gene-name">

7711RAD51C</em>

7712 gene and hereditary breast cancer or ovarian cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_6.75">

771375</a>

7714-<a href="#cit/section_6.78">

771578</a>

7716]</p>

7717<p id="_2477" tabindex="-1">

7718In addition to carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7719RAD51C</em>

7720 pathogenic variants, there are other <em class="gene-name">

7721RAD51</em>

7722 paralogs, including <em class="gene-name">

7723RAD51B</em>

7724, <em class="gene-name">

7725RAD51D</em>

7726, <em class="gene-name">

7727RAD51L1</em>

7728, <em class="gene-name">

7729XRCC2</em>

7730, and <em class="gene-name">

7731XRCC3</em>

7732, that may be associated with breast and/or ovarian cancer risk,[<a href="#cit/section_6.6">

77336</a>

7734,<a href="#cit/section_6.71">

773571</a>

7736,<a href="#cit/section_6.79">

773779</a>

7738-<a href="#cit/section_6.83">

773983</a>

7740] although the clinical significance of these findings is unknown. In a case-control study of 3,429 ovarian cancer patients, <em class="gene-name">

7741RAD51C</em>

7742 and <em class="gene-name">

7743RAD51D</em>

7744 pathogenic variants were more commonly found in ovarian cancer cases (0.82%) than in controls (0.11%, <em>

7745P</em>

7746 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_6.84">

774784</a>

7748]</p>

7749<p id="_2478" tabindex="-1">

7750In addition to <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=781852&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000781852&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7751germline variants</a>

7752, different polymorphisms of <em class="gene-name">

7753RAD51</em>

7754 have been hypothesized to have reduced capacity to repair DNA defects, resulting in increased susceptibility to familial breast cancer. The Consortium of Investigators of Modifiers of <em class="gene-name">

7755BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

7756 (CIMBA) pooled data from 8,512 carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7757BRCA1</em>

7758 and <em class="gene-name">

7759BRCA2</em>

7760 pathogenic variants and found evidence of an increased risk of breast cancer among women who were <em class="gene-name">

7761BRCA2</em>

7762 carriers and who were homozygous for CC at the <em class="gene-name">

7763RAD51</em>

7764 135G&#8594;C SNV (hazard ratio, 1.17; 95% CI, 0.91&#8211;1.51).[<a href="#cit/section_6.85">

776585</a>

7766]</p>

7767<p id="_2479" tabindex="-1">

7768Several meta-analyses have investigated the association between the <em class="gene-name">

7769RAD51</em>

7770 135G&#8594;C polymorphism and breast cancer risk. There is significant overlap in the studies reported in these meta-analyses, significant variability in the characteristics of the populations included, and significant methodologic limitations to their findings.[<a href="#cit/section_6.86">

777186</a>

7772-<a href="#cit/section_6.89">

777389</a>

7774] A meta-analysis of nine epidemiologic studies involving 13,241 cases and 13,203 controls of unknown <em class="gene-name">

7775BRCA1</em>

7776/<em class="gene-name">

7777BRCA2</em>

7778 status found that women carrying the CC <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=660739&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000660739&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7779genotype</a>

7780 had an increased risk of breast cancer compared with women with the GG or GC genotype (OR, 1.35; 95% CI, 1.04&#8211;1.74). A meta-analysis of 14 case-control studies involving 12,183 cases and 10,183 controls confirmed an increased risk only for women who were known <em class="gene-name">

7781BRCA2</em>

7782 carriers (OR, 4.92; 95% CI, 1.10&#8211;21.83).[<a href="#cit/section_6.90">

778390</a>

7784] Another meta-analysis of 12 studies included only studies of known <em class="gene-name">

7785BRCA</em>

7786-negative cases and found no association between <em class="gene-name">

7787RAD51</em>

7788 135G&#8594;C and breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_6.91">

778991</a>

7790]</p>

7791<p id="_2480" tabindex="-1">

7792In summary, among this conflicting data is substantial evidence for a modest association between germline variants in <em class="gene-name">

7793RAD51C</em>

7794 and breast cancer and ovarian cancer. There is also evidence of an association between polymorphisms in <em class="gene-name">

7795RAD51</em>

7796 135G&#8594;C among women with homozygous CC genotypes and breast cancer, particularly among <em class="gene-name">

7797BRCA2</em>

7798 carriers. These associations are plausible given the known role of <em class="gene-name">

7799RAD51</em>

7800 in the maintenance of genomic stability.</p>

7801</section>

7802<section id="_2872">

7803<h4 id="_2872_toc">

7804<em class="gene-name">

7805SMARCA4</em>

7806</h4>

7807<p id="_2873" tabindex="-1">

7808<em class="gene-name">

7809SMARCA4</em>

7810 encodes BRG1 and is a catalytic subunit of the SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complex, which plays a major role in rendering chromatin accessible to regulation of gene expression.</p>

7811<p id="_2874" tabindex="-1">

7812Small cell carcinoma of the ovary, hypercalcemic type (SCCOHT) is a rare, aggressive tumor that has an early age at onset (before age 40 y) and a poor prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_6.92">

781392</a>

7814-<a href="#cit/section_6.94">

781594</a>

7816]

7817

7818 Familial clustering is sometimes present. SCCOHT tumors may be unilateral or bilateral and have been characterized histologically by the presence of small hyperchromatic cells with brisk mitotic activity.[<a href="#cit/section_6.93">

781993</a>

7820]

7821 A multimodality approach including surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy has been suggested for the treatment of SCCOHT.[<a href="#cit/section_6.93">

782293</a>

7823,<a href="#cit/section_6.94">

782494</a>

7825] Given the paraneoplastic phenomenon of hypercalcemia in 60% of cases, tracking calcium levels is useful in monitoring the course of disease. With a wide range of differential diagnoses including germ cell tumors, sex cord&#8211;stromal tumors, and undifferentiated carcinomas, SCCOHT remains classified by the World Health Organization as a "miscellaneous tumor" but more recently has been sequenced to be a malignant rhabdoid tumor.[<a href="#cit/section_6.95">

782695</a>

7827] Through exome sequencing, most cases of SCCOHT have been found to lack functional <em class="gene-name">

7828SMARCA4</em>

7829/BRG1; in fact, pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

7830SMARCA4</em>

7831 may be the sole variants responsible for SCCOHT. </p>

7832<p id="_2875" tabindex="-1">

7833Despite only approximately 300 cases in the literature, three separate research groups showed SCCOHT to be associated with germline <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7834pathogenic variants</a>

7835 and <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46586&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046586&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

7836somatic mutations</a>

7837 in the <em class="gene-name">

7838SMARCA4</em>

7839 gene. In one study of 12 young women with SCCOHT, sequencing of paired tumor and normal samples identified inactivating biallelic <em class="gene-name">

7840SMARCA4</em>

7841 pathogenic variants in each case.[<a href="#cit/section_6.96">

784296</a>

7843]

7844Only four additional nonrecurrent somatic genes were identified in any of the other 278 genes sequenced. Immunohistochemistry demonstrated loss of SMARCA4 protein expression in seven of nine tested cases, consistent with a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46657&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046657&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7845tumor-suppressor gene</a>

7846 function. In a second study of another 12 patients, <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=763024&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000763024&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7847next-generation sequencing</a>

7848 also identified <em class="gene-name">

7849SMARCA4</em>

7850 as the only recurrently variant gene, with the majority of variants predicted to result in a truncated protein.[<a href="#cit/section_6.97">

785197</a>

7852] A third study included three families in whom whole-exome sequencing with <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=763028&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000763028&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7853Sanger sequencing</a>

7854 confirmation identified at least one germline pathogenic variant or somatic mutation in 24 of 26 cases.[<a href="#cit/section_6.98">

785598</a>

7856] Overall, 38 of 43 (88%) of SCCOHT tumors showed loss of SMARCA4 expression, in comparison to only 1 of 139 (0.7%) other ovarian tumor types. </p>

7857<p id="_2876" tabindex="-1">

7858Because of the rarity of this tumor, the penetrance of <em class="gene-name">

7859SMARCA4</em>

7860 is unknown. There is currently no consensus for management, yet <em class="gene-name">

7861SMARCA4</em>

7862 is on the larger multigene panels currently available for genetic testing, and risk-reducing surgery has been offered to pathogenic variant carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_6.99">

786399</a>

7864]</p>

7865</section>

7866</section>

7956[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7958<li id="section_6.23">

7960[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7961</li>

7962<li id="section_6.24">

7963Iniesta MD, Gorin MA, Chien LC, et al.: Absence of CHEK2*1100delC mutation in families with hereditary breast cancer in North America. 7964[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7965</li>

7967Offit K, Pierce H, Kirchhoff T, et al.: Frequency of CHEK2*1100delC in New York breast cancer cases and controls. BMC Med Genet 4 (1): 1, 2003.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12529183&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12529183&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7968[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7969</li>

7970<li id="section_6.26">

7971Oldenburg RA, Kroeze-Jansema K, Kraan J, et al.: The CHEK2*1100delC variant acts as a breast cancer risk modifier in non-BRCA1/BRCA2 multiple-case families. Cancer Res 63 (23): 8153-7, 2003.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=14678969&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=14678969&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7972[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8268

8269

8270

8271 <section id="_2857">

8272

8273 <h2>

8274Single Nucleotide VariantAssociated Cancer Risks</h2>

8275

8276 <div id="_section_2857" class="pdq-sections">

8277<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

8278<h6>

8279In This Section</h6>

8280<ul>

8281<li>

8282<a href="#_1314_toc">

8283Genome-Wide Searches<ul>

8284<li>

8285<a href="#_3239_toc">

8286Polygenic risk scores for breast and ovarian cancer</a>

8287</li>

8288</ul>

8289</a>

8290</li>

8291<li>

8292<a href="#_3243_toc">

8293Whole-Genome and Whole-Exome Sequencing</a>

8294</li>

8295</ul>

8296</nav>

8297<p id="_1306" tabindex="-1">

8298<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44805&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044805&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8299Polymorphisms</a>

8300 underlying polygenic susceptibility to breast and gynecologic cancers are considered low <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339344&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339344&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8301penetrance</a>

8302, a term often applied to sequence <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=776887&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000776887&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8303variants</a>

8304 associated with a minimal to moderate risk. This is in contrast to <em>

8305high-penetrance</em>

8306 variants or <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339337&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339337&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8307alleles</a>

8308 that are typically associated with more severe <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460203&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460203&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8309phenotypes</a>

8310, for example <em class="gene-name">

8311BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

8312 pathogenic variants leading to an <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=793860&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000793860&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8313autosomal dominant inheritance</a>

8314 pattern in a family, and <em>

8315moderate-penetrance</em>

8316 variants such as <em class="gene-name">

8317BRIP1</em>

8318, <em class="gene-name">

8319CHEK2</em>

8320, and <em class="gene-name">

8321RAD51C</em>

8322. (Refer to the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_88">

8323High-Penetrance Breast and/or Gynecologic Cancer Susceptibility Genes</a>

8324 and the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_156">

8325Moderate-Penetrance Genes Associated With Breast and/or Gynecologic Cancer</a>

8326 sections of this summary for more information.) Because these types of sequence variants (also called low-penetrance <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8327genes</a>

8328, alleles, variants, and polymorphisms) are relatively common in the general population, their overall contribution to cancer risk is estimated to be much greater than the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=485393&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000485393&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8329attributable risk</a>

8330 in the population from pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

8331BRCA1</em>

8332 and <em class="gene-name">

8333BRCA2</em>

8334. For example, it is estimated by <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=712689&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000712689&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8335segregation analysis</a>

8336 that half of all breast cancer occurs in 12% of the population that is deemed most susceptible.[<a href="#cit/section_7.1">

83371</a>

8338] There are no known low-penetrance variants in <em class="gene-name">

8339BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

8340. The N372H variation in <em class="gene-name">

8341BRCA2</em>

8342, initially thought to be a low-penetrance allele, was not verified in a large combined analysis.[<a href="#cit/section_7.2">

83432</a>

8344]</p>

8345<p id="_1307" tabindex="-1">

8346Two strategies have attempted to identify low-penetrance polymorphisms leading to breast cancer susceptibility: candidate gene and <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=636779&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000636779&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8347genome-wide searches</a>

8348. Both involve the epidemiologic case-control study design. The candidate gene approach involves selecting genes based on their known or presumed biological function, relevance to carcinogenesis or organ physiology, and then searching for or testing known genetic variants for an association with cancer risk. This strategy relies on imperfect and incomplete biological knowledge, and, despite some confirmed associations (described below), has been relatively disappointing.[<a href="#cit/section_7.2">

83492</a>

8350,<a href="#cit/section_7.3">

83513</a>

8352] The candidate gene approach has largely been replaced by genome-wide association studies (GWAS) in which a very large number of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=803525&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000803525&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8353single nucleotide variants </a>

8354(SNVs) (approximately 1 million to 5 million) are chosen within the genome and tested, mostly without regard to their possible biological function, but instead to more uniformly capture all genetic variation throughout the genome.</p>

8355<section id="_1314">

8356<h3 id="_1314_toc">

8357Genome-Wide Searches</h3>

8358<p id="_1315" tabindex="-1">

8359In contrast to assessing candidate genes and/or alleles, GWAS involve comparing a very large set of genetic variants spread throughout the genome. The current paradigm uses sets of as many as 5 million SNVs that are chosen to capture a large portion of common variation within the genome based on the HapMap and the 1000 Genomes Project.[<a href="#cit/section_7.4">

83604</a>

8361,<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

83625</a>

8363] By comparing allele frequencies between a large number of cases and controls, typically 1,000 or more of each, and validating promising signals in replication sets of subjects, very robust statistical signals of association have been obtained.[<a href="#cit/section_7.6">

83646</a>

8365-<a href="#cit/section_7.8">

83668</a>

8367] The strong correlation between many SNVs that are physically close to each other on the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46470&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046470&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8368chromosome</a>

8369 (<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=666094&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000666094&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8370linkage disequilibrium</a>

8371) allows one to &#8220;scan&#8221; the genome for susceptibility alleles even if the biologically relevant variant is not within the tested set of SNVs. Although this between-SNV correlation allows one to interrogate the majority of the genome without having to assay every SNV, when a validated association is obtained, it is not usually obvious which of the many correlated variants is causal.</p>

8372<p id="_1317" tabindex="-1">

8373Genome-wide searches are showing great promise in identifying common, low-penetrance susceptibility alleles for many complex diseases,[<a href="#cit/section_7.9">

83749</a>

8375] including breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_7.10">

837610</a>

8377-<a href="#cit/section_7.13">

837813</a>

8379] The first study involved an initial scan in <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460148&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460148&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8380familial</a>

8381 breast cancer cases followed by replication in two large sample sets of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339347&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339347&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8382sporadic breast cancer</a>

8383, the final being a collection of over 20,000 cases and 20,000 controls from the Breast Cancer Association Consortium (BCAC).[<a href="#cit/section_7.10">

838410</a>

8385] Five distinct genomic regions were identified that were within or near the <em class="gene-name">

8386FGFR2</em>

8387, <em class="gene-name">

8388TNRC9</em>

8389, <em class="gene-name">

8390MAP3K1</em>

8391, and <em class="gene-name">

8392LSP1</em>

8393 genes or at the chromosome 8q region. The 8q region and others may harbor multiple independent <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460162&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460162&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8394loci</a>

8395 associated with risk. Subsequent genome-wide studies have replicated these loci and identified additional ones.[<a href="#cit/section_7.11">

839611</a>

8397,<a href="#cit/section_7.12">

839812</a>

8399,<a href="#cit/section_7.14">

840014</a>

8401-<a href="#cit/section_7.19">

840219</a>

8403] Numerous SNVs identified through large studies of sporadic breast cancer appear to be associated more strongly with estrogen receptor (ER)&#8211;positive disease;[<a href="#cit/section_7.20">

840420</a>

8405] however, some are associated primarily or exclusively with other subtypes, including <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=639916&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000639916&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8406triple-negative disease</a>

8407.[<a href="#cit/section_7.21">

840821</a>

8409,<a href="#cit/section_7.22">

841022</a>

8411] An <a href="https://www.ebi.ac.uk/gwas/" title="https://www.ebi.ac.uk/gwas/">

8412online catalog</a>

8413 is available of SNV-trait associations

8414from published GWAS for use in investigating

8415genomic characteristics of trait/disease-associated SNVs. </p>

8416<p id="_2449" tabindex="-1">

8417Although the statistical evidence for an association between genetic variation at these loci and breast and ovarian cancer risk is overwhelming, the biologically relevant variants and

8418the mechanism by which they lead to increased risk are unknown and will require further genetic and functional characterization. Additionally, these loci are associated with very modest risk (typically, an odds ratio [OR] &lt;1.5), with more risk variants likely to be identified. No interaction between the SNVs and epidemiologic risk factors for breast cancer have been identified.[<a href="#cit/section_7.23">

841923</a>

8420,<a href="#cit/section_7.24">

842124</a>

8422] Furthermore, theoretical models have suggested that common moderate-risk SNVs have limited potential to improve models for individualized <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460214&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460214&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8423risk assessment</a>

8424.[<a href="#cit/section_7.25">

842525</a>

8426-<a href="#cit/section_7.27">

842727</a>

8428] These models used receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve analysis to calculate the area under the curve (AUC) as a measure of discriminatory accuracy. A subsequent study used ROC curve analysis to examine the utility of SNVs in a clinical dataset of more than 5,500 breast cancer cases and nearly 6,000 controls, using a model with traditional risk factors compared with a model using both standard risk factors and ten previously identified SNVs. The addition of genetic information modestly changed the AUC from 58% to 61.8%, a result that was not felt to be clinically significant. Despite this, 32.5% of patients were in a higher quintile of breast cancer risk when genetic information was included, and 20.4% were in a lower quintile of risk. Whether such information has clinical utility is unclear.[<a href="#cit/section_7.25">

842925</a>

8430,<a href="#cit/section_7.28">

843128</a>

8432]</p>

8433<p id="_2445" tabindex="-1">

8434More limited data are available regarding ovarian cancer risk. Three GWAS involving staged analysis of more than 10,000 cases and 13,000 controls have been carried out for ovarian cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_7.29">

843529</a>

8436-<a href="#cit/section_7.31">

843731</a>

8438] As in other GWAS, the ORs are modest, generally about 1.2 or weaker but implicate a number of genes with plausible biological ties to ovarian cancer, such as <em class="gene-name">

8439BABAM1</em>

8440, whose protein complexes with and may regulate BRCA1, and <em class="gene-name">

8441TIRAPR</em>

8442, which codes for a poly (ADP-ribose) polymerase, molecules that may be important in<em class="gene-name">

8443 BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

8444-deficient cells.</p>

8445<section id="_3239">

8446<h4 id="_3239_toc">

8447Polygenic risk scores for breast and ovarian cancer</h4>

8448<p id="_3240" tabindex="-1">

8449The collective influence of many genetic variants has more recently been evaluated using an aggregate score. In 2015, a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=800513&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000800513&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8450polygenic risk score</a>

8451 (PRS) comprising all of the known breast cancer risk genetic variants or SNVs was estimated in women of European ancestry using 41 studies in the BCAC, including more than 33,000 breast cancer cases and 33,000 controls.[<a href="#cit/section_7.32">

845232</a>

8453] This early attempt at estimating a PRS for breast cancer included 77 SNVs, which collectively conferred lifetime risks of developing breast cancer by age 80 years of 3.5% and 29% for women in the lowest and highest 1% of the PRS, respectively.[<a href="#cit/section_7.32">

845432</a>

8455] Since then, PRSs incorporating additional genetic variants and examining other breast cancer&#8211;related outcomes including tumor and pathological characteristics, mode of detection, and contralateral breast cancer (CBC) have been estimated.[<a href="#cit/section_7.33">

845633</a>

8457-<a href="#cit/section_7.40">

845840</a>

8459] In 2019, the PRS with the highest discriminatory ability to date was developed and prospectively validated in the largest GWAS datasets available (79 studies in BCAC and more than 190,000 women in the U.K. Biobank), which incorporates information on 313 genetic variants and is optimized for ER-positive and ER-negative breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_7.39">

846039</a>

8461] Compared with women in the middle quintile, those in the highest 1% of PRS<sub>

8462313</sub>

8463 had 4.04-, 4.37-, and 2.78-fold risks of developing breast cancer overall, ER-positive disease, and ER-negative disease, respectively.[<a href="#cit/section_7.39">

846439</a>

8465] Lifetime absolute risk (AR) of breast cancer by age 80 years for women in the lowest and highest 1% of PRS<sub>

8466313</sub>

8467 ranged from 2% to 31% for ER-positive breast cancer, while for ER-negative disease, the ARs ranged from 0.55% to 4%.[<a href="#cit/section_7.39">

846839</a>

8469] </p>

8470<p id="_3241" tabindex="-1">

8471Common genomic variants associated with the development of a first primary breast cancer are also associated with the development of CBC.[<a href="#cit/section_7.40">

847240</a>

8473] Women in the highest quartile of the PRS had a 1.6-fold increased risk of developing CBC compared with the lowest quartile.[<a href="#cit/section_7.40">

847440</a>

8475] Moreover, PRSs of breast and ovarian cancers have been assessed in women who are carriers of <em class="gene-name">

8476BRCA1</em>

8477 and <em class="gene-name">

8478BRCA2</em>

8479 pathogenic variants, and have been found to be predictive of cancer risk in these women, supporting the hypothesis of a shared polygenic component of cancer risk between the general population and variant carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_7.36">

848036</a>

8481] The PRS for ER-negative disease had the strongest association with breast cancer risk in <em class="gene-name">

8482BRCA1</em>

8483 variant carriers, while the strongest association in <em class="gene-name">

8484BRCA2</em>

8485 variant carriers was seen for the overall breast cancer PRS. <em class="gene-name">

8486BRCA1</em>

8487 variant carriers had cumulative lifetime risks of 56% and 75% of developing breast cancer at the 10<span class="sup">

8488th</span>

8489 and 90<span class="sup">

8490th</span>

8491 percentile of the PRS, respectively. The ovarian cancer PRS was strongly associated with risk for both <em class="gene-name">

8492BRCA1</em>

8493 and <em class="gene-name">

8494BRCA2</em>

8495 variant carriers. For <em class="gene-name">

8496BRCA2</em>

8497 variant carriers, the ovarian cancer risk was 6% and 19% by age 80 years for those at the 10<span class="sup">

8498th</span>

8499 and 90<span class="sup">

8500th</span>

8501 percentile of PRS, respectively. The authors noted that the incorporation of the PRS into risk prediction models may better inform decisions on cancer risk management for this population.[<a href="#cit/section_7.36">

850236</a>

8503] </p>

8504<p id="_3373" tabindex="-1">

8505Two large studies have supported that PRSs can improve breast cancer risk stratification.[<a href="#cit/section_7.41">

850641</a>

8507,<a href="#cit/section_7.42">

850842</a>

8509] PRSs were most important in the breast cancer risk stratification of individuals with <em class="gene-name">

8510CHEK2</em>

8511 and <em class="gene-name">

8512ATM</em>

8513 pathogenic variants. After PRSs were incorporated, 30% of individuals with a <em class="gene-name">

8514CHEK2</em>

8515 pathogenic variant and nearly half of the individuals with an <em class="gene-name">

8516ATM</em>

8517 pathogenic variant dipped below a 20% lifetime risk of breast cancer. This is significant, since lifetime risk values greater than 20% can prompt more frequent breast cancer screening and other types of clinical management.[<a href="#cit/section_7.41">

851841</a>

8519] PRSs were also effective when stratifying breast cancer risk in noncarriers. Gallagher et al. analyzed case-control data from 150,962 women who had multigene hereditary cancer genetic testing. This study examined the impact of a PRS with 86 SNVs on individuals with pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

8520BRCA1, BRCA2, CHEK2, ATM</em>

8521, and <em class="gene-name">

8522PALB2</em>

8523. The PRS was predictive of breast cancer in individuals with pathogenic variants. However, breast cancer risk stratification was more pronounced in noncarriers (OR, 1.47; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.45&#8211;1.49) and <em class="gene-name">

8524CHEK2</em>

8525 pathogenic variant carriers (OR, 1.49; 95% CI, 1.36&#8211;1.64) than in carriers of <em class="gene-name">

8526BRCA1</em>

8527 (OR, 1.20; 95% CI, 1.10&#8211;1.32) or <em class="gene-name">

8528BRCA2</em>

8529 (OR, 1.23; 95% CI, 1.12&#8211;1.34) pathogenic variants. The ORs for <em class="gene-name">

8530ATM</em>

8531 (OR, 1.37; 95% CI, 1.21&#8211;1.55) and <em class="gene-name">

8532PALB2</em>

8533 (OR, 1.34; 95% CI, 1.16&#8211;1.55) pathogenic variant carriers were intermediate when compared with those of <em class="gene-name">

8534BRCA1/2 </em>

8535pathogenic variant carriers, <em class="gene-name">

8536CHEK2</em>

8537 pathogenic variant carriers, and noncarriers. Even though the PRS improved breast cancer risk stratification across all groups, the PRS was most important for individuals with <em class="gene-name">

8538CHEK2</em>

8539 pathogenic variants and for noncarriers.[<a href="#cit/section_7.42">

854042</a>

8541] Similarly, Gao et al. analyzed case-control data from 26,798 non-Hispanic White individuals with breast cancer and 26,127 controls using a PRS based on 105 SNVs. More than 95% of <em class="gene-name">

8542BRCA1</em>

8543, <em class="gene-name">

8544BRCA2</em>

8545, and <em class="gene-name">

8546PALB2</em>

8547 pathogenic variant carriers had a 20% lifetime risk of breast cancer. In contrast, 52.5% of <em class="gene-name">

8548ATM</em>

8549 pathogenic variant carriers and 69.7% of <em class="gene-name">

8550CHEK2</em>

8551 pathogenic variant carriers without <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460150&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460150&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8552first-degree relatives</a>

8553 (FDRs) with breast cancer had a 20% lifetime risk of breast cancer. This was also true in 78.8% of <em class="gene-name">

8554ATM</em>

8555 carriers and 89.9% of<em class="gene-name">

8556 CHEK2</em>

8557 carriers with an FDR with breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_7.41">

855841</a>

8559]</p>

8560<p id="_3242" tabindex="-1">

8561Several studies have also examined the extent to which clinical breast cancer risk prediction models can be improved by including information on known susceptibility SNVs, and reporting improved discriminatory accuracy after inclusion of the PRS.[<a href="#cit/section_7.43">

856243</a>

8563-<a href="#cit/section_7.48">

856448</a>

8565] For example, in a study combining PRS<sub>

856677</sub>

8567 with clinical models, the AUC for predicting breast cancer before age 50 years improved by more than 20%.[<a href="#cit/section_7.44">

856844</a>

8569] Clinical trials, including <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02620852">

8570WISDOM</a>

8571 and <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT03672331">

8572MyPeBs</a>

8573, are in progress to study the potential clinical utility of the PRS for making screening decisions and understanding outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_7.49">

857449</a>

8575] Because PRSs have been largely developed and validated in populations of European ancestry, the utility and prediction accuracy of these PRSs in non-European populations is unknown. </p>

8576<p id="_3303" tabindex="-1">

8577A large study examined whether known reproductive and lifestyle risk factors interact with PRSs to increase breast cancer risk and did not find a multiplicative interaction with established risk factors.[<a href="#cit/section_7.50">

857850</a>

8579]</p>

8580</section>

8581</section>

8582<section id="_3243">

8583<h3 id="_3243_toc">

8584Whole-Genome and Whole-Exome Sequencing</h3>

8585<p id="_2483" tabindex="-1">

8586In addition to GWAS interrogating common genetic variants, sequencing-based studies involving <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=740456&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000740456&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8587whole-genome</a>

8588 or <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=740459&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000740459&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8589whole-exome sequencing</a>

8590 [<a href="#cit/section_7.51">

859151</a>

8592] are also identifying genes associated with breast cancer, such as <em class="gene-name">

8593XRCC2</em>

8594, a rare, moderate-penetrance breast cancer <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460209&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460209&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8595susceptibility gene</a>

8596.[<a href="#cit/section_7.52">

859752</a>

8598] (Refer to the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/overview-pdq#_2594">

8599Clinical Sequencing</a>

8600 section in Cancer Genetics Overview for more information about whole-exome sequencing.)</p>

8601</section>

8602<h6 do-not-show="toc">

8619[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8620</li>

Nat Methods 9 (5): 459-62, 2012.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22543379&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22543379&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8623[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8624</li>

8625<li id="section_7.6">

8626Evans DM, Cardon LR: Genome-wide association: a promising start to a long race. Trends Genet 22 (7): 350-4, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16713652&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16713652&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8627[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8628</li>

8629<li id="section_7.7">
