8794Zhang X, Rice M, Tworoger SS, et al.: Addition of a polygenic risk score, mammographic density, and endogenous hormones to existing breast cancer risk prediction models: A nested case-control study. PLoS Med 15 (9): e1002644, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=30180161&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=30180161&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8795[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8796</li>

8797<li id="section_7.49">

8798Esserman LJ; WISDOM Study and Athena Investigators: The WISDOM Study: breaking the deadlock in the breast cancer screening debate. NPJ Breast Cancer 3: 34, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28944288&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28944288&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8799[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8800</li>

8801<li id="section_7.50">

8802Rudolph A, Song M, Brook MN, et al.: Joint associations of a polygenic risk score and environmental risk factors for breast cancer in the Breast Cancer Association Consortium. Int J Epidemiol 47 (2): 526-536, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29315403&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29315403&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8803[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8804</li>

8805<li id="section_7.51">

8806Shendure J: Next-generation human genetics. Genome Biol 12 (9): 408, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21920048&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21920048&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8807[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8808</li>

8809<li id="section_7.52">

8810Park DJ, Lesueur F, Nguyen-Dumont T, et al.: Rare mutations in XRCC2 increase the risk of breast cancer. Am J Hum Genet 90 (4): 734-9, 2012.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22464251&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22464251&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8811[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8812</li>

8813</ol>

8814</div>

8815

8816 </section>

8817

8818

8819

8820 <section id="_2742">

8821

8822 <h2>

8823Clinical Management of Hereditary Breast and/or Gynecologic Cancer Syndromes</h2>

8824

8825 <div id="_section_2742" class="pdq-sections">

8826<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

8827<h6>

8828In This Section</h6>

8829<ul>

8830<li>

8831<a href="#_3827_toc">

8832<em class="gene-name">

8833BRCA1</em>

8834 and<em class="gene-name">

8835 BRCA2</em>

8836</a>

8837</li>

8838<li>

8839<a href="#_2743_toc">

8840Lynch Syndrome</a>

8841</li>

8842</ul>

8843</nav>

8844<section id="_3827">

8845<h3 id="_3827_toc">

8846<em class="gene-name">

8847BRCA1</em>

8848 and<em class="gene-name">

8849 BRCA2</em>

8850</h3>

8851<p id="_3828" tabindex="-1">

8852For more information, see the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq#_3492">

8853Management of Cancer Risks in <em class="gene-name">

8854BRCA1/2</em>

8855 Carriers</a>

8856 section in <em class="gene-name">

8857BRCA1</em>

8858 and <em class="gene-name">

8859BRCA2</em>

8860: Cancer Risks and Management.</p>

8861</section>

8862<section id="_2743">

8863<h3 id="_2743_toc">

8864Lynch Syndrome</h3>

8865<p id="_2744" tabindex="-1">

8866As mismatch repair <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8867genes</a>

8868 were identified as the genetic basis of Lynch syndrome, <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=285933&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000285933&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8869microsatellite instability</a>

8870 was identified as a common molecular marker of mismatch repair deficiency. Approximately 15% of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339347&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339347&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8871sporadic</a>

8872 colorectal cancers show microsatellite instability, while up to 28% of sporadic endometrial cancers have this molecular change.[<a href="#cit/section_8.1">

88731</a>

8874,<a href="#cit/section_8.2">

88752</a>

8876] Most frequently, sporadic tumors with microsatellite instability have hypermethylation of the <em class="gene-name">

8877MLH1</em>

8878 promoter. In Lynch syndrome&#8211;related tumors showing microsatellite instability, there is typically loss of one or more of the proteins associated with the mismatch repair genes.</p>

8879<p id="_2745" tabindex="-1">

8880Certain histopathologic features are also strongly suggestive of a microsatellite instability <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460203&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460203&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8881phenotype</a>

8882, including the presence of tumor infiltrating lymphocytes, peritumoral lymphocytes, undifferentiated carcinomas, and lower uterine segment tumors. Use of clinical criteria is one strategy of selection criteria for tumor testing. Computer models have also been used to predict the probability of a mismatch repair <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=776887&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000776887&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8883genetic variant</a>

8884 and can be used in the absence of microsatellite instability or immunohistochemistry information.[<a href="#cit/section_8.3">

88853</a>

8886-<a href="#cit/section_8.6">

88876</a>

8888] Overall, however, there is a move towards universal testing of colorectal and endometrial tumors when tumor tissue is available. (Refer to the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_1110">

8889Universal tumor testing to screen for Lynch syndrome</a>

8890 section in Genetics of Colorectal Cancer for more information.)</p>

8891</section>

8892<h6 do-not-show="toc">

8893References</h6>

J Diabetes Investig 1 (5): 208-11, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24843434&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=24843434&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9055</nav>

9056<section id="_272">

9057<h3 id="_272_toc">

9058Introduction</h3>

9059<p id="_273" tabindex="-1">

9060Psychosocial research in the context of cancer genetic testing helps to define

9061psychological outcomes, interpersonal and <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460148&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460148&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9062familial</a>

9063 effects, and cultural and

9064community responses. This type of research also identifies behavioral factors that encourage or

9065impede <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46171&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046171&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9066screening</a>

9067 and other health behaviors. It can enhance decision making

9068about risk-reduction interventions, evaluate psychosocial interventions to

9069reduce distress and/or other negative sequelae related to risk notification and

9070genetic testing, provide data to help resolve ethical concerns, and predict the

9071interest in testing of various groups.

9072</p>

9073<p id="_2749" tabindex="-1">

9074Psychosocial and screening issues related to gynecologic cancers associated with Lynch syndrome are discussed in the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_189">

9075Psychosocial Issues in Hereditary Colon Cancer Syndromes</a>

9076 section in Genetics of Colorectal Cancer.</p>

9077</section>

9078<section id="_2556">

9079<h3 id="_2556_toc">

9080Uptake of Genetic Counseling and Genetic Testing</h3>

9081<section id="_9">

9082<h4 id="_9_toc">

9083Degree of uptake of genetic counseling and genetic testing</h4>

9084<p id="_109" tabindex="-1">

9085Comparison of uptake rates among studies in which counseling and testing were offered is challenging because of differences in methodologies, including the sampling strategy used, the recruitment setting, and testing through a research protocol with high-risk cohorts or <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460158&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460158&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9086kindreds</a>

9087. In a systematic review of 40 studies conducted before 2002 that had assessed genetic testing utilization, uptake rates varied widely and ranged from 25% to 96%, with an average uptake rate of 59%.[<a href="#cit/section_9.1">

90881</a>

9089] Results of multivariate analysis found that <em class="gene-name">

9090BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

9091 genetic testing uptake was associated with having a personal or family history of breast or ovarian cancer, and with methodological features of the studies, including sampling strategies, recruitment settings, and how studies defined actual uptake versus the intention to have testing.</p>

9092<p id="_2557" tabindex="-1">

9093Other factors have been positively correlated with uptake of <em class="gene-name">

9094BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

9095 genetic testing, although these findings are not consistent across all studies. Psychological factors that have been positively correlated with testing uptake include greater cancer-specific distress and greater perceived risk of developing breast or ovarian cancer. Having more cancer-affected relatives also has been correlated with greater testing uptake. </p>

9096<p id="_2558" tabindex="-1">

9097<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2598">

9098Table 8</a>

9099 summarizes the uptake of genetic testing in clinical and research cohorts in the United States.</p>

9100<table id="_2598" class="table-default expandable-container">

9101<caption>

9102Table 8. Predictors Associated with Uptake of Genetic Testing (GT)</caption>

9103<colgroup>

9104<col width="16.50%">

9105<col width="19.89%">

9106<col width="13.53%">

9107<col width="16.77%">

9108<col width="16.50%">

9109<col width="16.77%">

9110</colgroup>

9111<THead>

9112<tr>

9113<th>

9114Study Citation</th>

9115<th>

9116Study Population</th>

9117<th>

9118Sample Size (N)</th>

9119<th>

9120Uptake of GT</th>

9121<th>

9122Predictors Associated With Uptake of GT</th>

9123<th>

9124Comments</th>

9125</tr>

9126</THead>

9127<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

9128<tr>

9129<td colspan="6">

9130GC = <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44961&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044961&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9131genetic counseling</a>

9132; HMO = health maintenance organization.</td>

9133</tr>

9134<tr>

9135<td colspan="6">

9136<span class="sup">

9137a</span>

9138Self-report as data source.</td>

9139</tr>

9140<tr>

9141<td colspan="6">

9142<span class="sup">

9143b</span>

9144Medical records as data source.</td>

9145</tr>

9146</TFoot>

9147<tbody>

9148<tr>

9149<td rowspan="4">

9150Schwartz et al. (2005) [<a href="#cit/section_9.2">

91512</a>

9152]</td>

9153<td rowspan="4">

9154Newly diagnosed and locally untreated breast cancer patients with &#8805;10% risk of having a <em class="gene-name">

9155BRCA1/BRCA2 </em>

9156<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9157pathogenic variant</a>

9158&#160;<span class="sup">

9159a</span>

9160 </td>

9161<td rowspan="4">

9162231</td>

9163<td>

9164177/231 (77%) underwent GT</td>

9165<td rowspan="2">

9166<strong>

9167Having decided on definitive local treatment.</strong>

9168 Women who were undecided on a definitive local treatment were more likely to be tested</td>

9169<td rowspan="2">

9170Testing was offered free of charge </td>

9171</tr>

9172<tr>

9173<td rowspan="2">

917434/231 (15%) had baseline interview but declined GT</td>

9175</tr>

9176<tr>

9177<td rowspan="2">

9178<strong>

9179Physician recommendation for testing.</strong>

9180 Women whose physician had recommended GT were more likely to be tested</td>

9181<td rowspan="2">

918238/177 chose to proceed with treatment before receiving test results</td>

9183</tr>

9184<tr>

9185<td>

918620/231 declined baseline interview</td>

9187</tr>

9188<tr>

9189<td rowspan="5">

9190Kieran et al. (2007) [<a href="#cit/section_9.3">

91913</a>

9192]</td>

9193<td rowspan="5">

9194Women who received GC between 2002 and 2004<span class="sup">

9195a</span>

9196</td>

9197<td rowspan="5">

9198250</td>

9199<td>

920088/250 (35%) underwent GT</td>

9201<td rowspan="2">

9202<strong>

9203Ability to pay for GT (entire cost or cost not covered by insurance).</strong>

9204 Nonuptake was 5.5 times more likely in women who could not afford testing</td>

9205<td rowspan="2">

9206450 women received GC for breast and ovarian cancer risk during study period. 250 women were retrospectively identified as eligible and were mailed a study questionnaire</td>

9207</tr>

9208<tr>

9209<td rowspan="2">

921036/88 returned surveys</td>

9211</tr>

9212<tr>

9213<td rowspan="3">

9214<strong>

9215Ability to recall risk estimates that were provided post-GC.</strong>

9216 Nonuptake was 15.5 times more likely in women who could not recall their risk estimates</td>

9217<td rowspan="3">

9218All women had some form of insurance</td>

9219</tr>

9220<tr>

9221<td>

9222162/250 (65%) eligible </td>

9223</tr>

9224<tr>

9225<td>

922665/162 returned surveys</td>

9227</tr>

9228<tr>

9229<td rowspan="4">

9230Susswein et al. (2008) [<a href="#cit/section_9.4">

92314</a>

9232]</td>

9233<td rowspan="4">

9234African American women and White women with breast cancer<span class="sup">

9235b</span>

9236</td>

9237<td rowspan="4">

9238768 </td>

9239<td>

9240529/768 (69%) underwent GT</td>

9241<td rowspan="2">

9242<strong>

9243Race and ethnicity. </strong>

9244African American women were less likely to be tested than White women</td>

9245<td rowspan="4">

9246Sample obtained from a clinical database. Testing was offered free of charge when it was not covered by insurance. This effect for time of diagnosis was significant in the African American subgroup but not in the White subgroup</td>

9247</tr>

9248<tr>

9249<td rowspan="2">

9250<strong>

9251African American women:</strong>

9252 77/132 (58%) underwent GT</td>

9253</tr>

9254<tr>

9255<td rowspan="2">

9256<strong>

9257Recent diagnosis. </strong>

9258African American women who were recently diagnosed were more likely to be tested</td>

9259</tr>

9260<tr>

9261<td>

9262<strong>

9263White women: </strong>

9264452/636 (71%) underwent GT</td>

9265</tr>

9266<tr>

9267<td rowspan="2">

9268Olaya et al. (2009) [<a href="#cit/section_9.5">

92695</a>

9270]</td>

9271<td rowspan="2">

9272Patients referred for GT between 2001 and 2008<span class="sup">

9273b</span>

9274 </td>

9275<td rowspan="2">

9276213</td>

9277<td>

9278111/213 (52%) underwent GT</td>

9279<td>

9280<strong>

9281Personal history of breast cancer.</strong>

9282 Having a personal history was associated with 3 times greater odds of being tested</td>

9283<td rowspan="2">

9284Insurance coverage for testing was available for 91.1% (175/213) of patients. Of those who had coverage for GT, 51.4% underwent testing and 48.6% did not. Of those without coverage, 41.2% had GT and 58.9% did not</td>

9285</tr>

9286<tr>

9287<td>

9288102/213 (48%) declined GT</td>

9289<td>

9290 <strong>

9291Higher level of education.</strong>

9292 Those with a high school education or less had one-third the odds of being tested, compared with those with at least some college</td>

9293</tr>

9294<tr>

9295<td rowspan="4">

9296Levy et al. (2010) [<a href="#cit/section_9.6">

92976</a>

9298] </td>

9299<td rowspan="4">

9300Women aged 20&#8211;40 y with newly diagnosed early-onset breast cancer.<span class="sup">

9301b</span>

9302</td>

9303<td rowspan="4">

93041,474</td>

9305<td>

9306446/1,474 (30%) underwent GT</td>

9307<td>

9308<strong>

9309Race and ethnicity. </strong>

9310Women of Jewish ethnicity were 3 times more likely to be tested than non-Jewish White women. African American and Hispanic women were significantly less likely to receive testing than non-Jewish White women</td>

9311<td rowspan="4">

9312Sample obtained from a national database of commercially insured individuals</td>

9313</tr>

9314<tr>

9315<td>

9316<strong>

9317Jewish women:</strong>

9318

931918/32 (56%) underwent GT

9320</td>

9321<td>

9322<strong>

9323Home location.</strong>

9324 Women living in the south were more likely to be tested than women living in the northeast</td>

9325</tr>

9326<tr>

9327<td rowspan="2">

9328<strong>

9329African American women:</strong>

9330

933110/82 (12%) underwent GT

9332</td>

9333<td>

9334<strong>

9335Insurance type.</strong>

9336 Women with point-of-service plans were more likely to be tested than women with HMO plans</td>

9337</tr>

9338<tr>

9339<td>

9340<strong>

9341Recent diagnosis.</strong>

9342 Women diagnosed in 2007 were 3.8 times more likely to be tested than women diagnosed in 2004</td>

9343</tr>

9344</tbody>

9345</table>

9346<p id="_2504" tabindex="-1">

9347Several studies conducted in non-U.S. settings have examined the uptake of genetic testing.[<a href="#cit/section_9.7">

93487</a>

9349-<a href="#cit/section_9.11">

935011</a>

9351] In studies examining the uptake of testing among at-risk relatives of carriers of <em class="gene-name">

9352BRCA1</em>

9353/<em class="gene-name">

9354BRCA2</em>

9355 pathogenic variants, uptake rates have averaged below 50% (range, 36%&#8211;48%), with higher uptake reported among female relatives than in male relatives. Other factors associated with higher uptake of testing were not consistently reported among studies but have most commonly included being a parent and wanting to learn information about a child&#8217;s risk. </p>

9356</section>

9357<section id="_14">

9358<h4 id="_14_toc">

9359Factors influencing uptake of genetic counseling and genetic testing</h4>

9360<p id="_2571" tabindex="-1">

9361In reviews that have examined the cumulative evidence concerning the predictors of uptake of <em class="gene-name">

9362BRCA1</em>

9363/<em class="gene-name">

9364BRCA2</em>

9365 genetic testing, important predictors of testing uptake include older age, <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460127&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460127&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9366Ashkenazi Jewish</a>

9367 (AJ) heritage, unmarried status, a personal history of breast cancer, and a family history of breast cancer. Studies recruiting participants in hospital settings had significantly higher recruitment rates than did studies recruiting participants in community settings. Studies that required an immediate decision to test, rather than allowing delayed decision making, tended to report higher uptake rates.[<a href="#cit/section_9.1">

93681</a>

9369] However, there is evidence that women diagnosed with breast cancer are equally satisfied with genetic counseling (including information received and strength and timing of physician recommendations for counseling), whether they received genetic counseling before or after their definitive surgery for breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_9.12">

937012</a>

9371] Another review [<a href="#cit/section_9.13">

937213</a>

9373] found that uptake of genetic testing for <em class="gene-name">

9374BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

9375 pathogenic variants was related to psychological factors (e.g., anxiety about breast cancer and perceived risk of breast cancer) and demographic and medical factors (e.g., history of breast cancer or ovarian cancer, presence of children, and higher number of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460124&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460124&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9376affected</a>

9377 <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460150&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460150&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9378first-degree relatives</a>

9379 [FDRs]). Family members with a known <em class="gene-name">

9380BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

9381 pathogenic variant were more likely to pursue testing; those with more extensive knowledge of <em class="gene-name">

9382BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

9383 testing, heightened risk perceptions, beliefs that mammography would promote health benefit, and high intentions to undergo testing were more likely to follow through with testing.[<a href="#cit/section_9.14">

938414</a>

9385]</p>

9386<p id="_1585" tabindex="-1">

9387In a review of racial and ethnic differences that affect the uptake of <em class="gene-name">

9388BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

9389 testing, intention to undergo genetic testing in African American women was related to having at least one FDR with breast cancer or ovarian cancer, higher perceived risk of being a carrier, and less anticipatory guilt about the possibility of being a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9390gene</a>

9391 carrier.[<a href="#cit/section_9.15">

939215</a>

9393] A systematic review found that certain racial and ethnic minority groups, including African American and Hispanic individuals, had more negative views and greater concerns about genetic counseling and testing when compared with White individuals. African American and Hispanic individuals were more likely to believe genetic testing could be used to show their ethnic group was inferior to other groups. Additionally, African American and Hispanic individuals were found to have low awareness and knowledge about the importance of genetics in cancer, <em class="gene-name">

9394BRCA</em>

9395 status, and genetic testing.[<a href="#cit/section_9.16">

939616</a>

9397]</p>

9398<p id="_1586" tabindex="-1">

9399 Reasons cited for following through with testing included a desire to learn about a child's risk, to feel relief from uncertainty, to inform screening or risk-reducing surgery decisions, and to inform important life decisions such as marriage and childbearing.[<a href="#cit/section_9.14">

940014</a>

9401,<a href="#cit/section_9.17">

940217</a>

9403] Among African American women, the most important reason for testing included motivation to help other relatives decide on genetic testing.[<a href="#cit/section_9.15">

940415</a>

9405]</p>

9406<p id="_2469" tabindex="-1">

9407Physician recommendation may be another motivator for testing. In a retrospective study of 335 women considering genetic testing, 77% reported that they wanted the opinion of a genetics physician about whether they should be tested, and 49% wanted the opinion of their primary care provider.[<a href="#cit/section_9.18">

940818</a>

9409] However, there is some evidence of referral bias favoring those with a maternal family history of breast cancer or ovarian cancer. In a Canadian retrospective review of 315 patients, those with a maternal family history of breast cancer or ovarian cancer were 4.9 times (95% confidence interval, 3.6&#8211;6.7) more likely to be referred for a cancer genetics consultation by their physician than were those with a paternal family history (<em>

9410P</em>

9411 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_9.19">

941219</a>

9413] Studies have found that physicians may not adequately assess paternal family history [<a href="#cit/section_9.20">

941420</a>

9415] or may underestimate the significance of a paternal family history for genetic risk.[<a href="#cit/section_9.20">

941620</a>

9417-<a href="#cit/section_9.22">

941822</a>

9419] Other studies have shown that physician referral of patients who meet U.S. Preventive Services Task Force guidelines for <em class="gene-name">

9420BRCA</em>

9421 genetic counseling has been suboptimal.[<a href="#cit/section_9.23">

942223</a>

9423]</p>

9424<p id="_2652" tabindex="-1">

9425The uptake of <em class="gene-name">

9426BRCA</em>

9427 testing to inform surgical treatment decisions when offered appears to be high in research cohorts;[<a href="#cit/section_9.2">

94282</a>

9429,<a href="#cit/section_9.24">

943024</a>

9431] however, findings from other studies suggest that testing is underutilized in clinical practice to inform breast cancer treatment decisions.[<a href="#cit/section_9.6">

94326</a>

9433,<a href="#cit/section_9.25">

943425</a>

9435,<a href="#cit/section_9.26">

943626</a>

9437] Barriers to the use of <em class="gene-name">

9438BRCA</em>

9439 testing to inform surgical treatment decisions, including lack of physician referral of newly diagnosed patients for genetic counseling, type of insurance coverage (such as Medicare or Medicaid), and challenges in the timing and coordination of testing, have been reported.[<a href="#cit/section_9.6">

94406</a>

9441,<a href="#cit/section_9.27">

944227</a>

9443-<a href="#cit/section_9.30">

944430</a>

9445] In a randomized trial that provided proactive rapid genetic counseling (delivery of genetic counseling prior to surgery) compared with usual care for patients with newly diagnosed breast cancer, results suggested that although genetic counseling uptake was higher in the intervention arm, this did not translate into higher rates of genetic testing, receipt of results before surgery, or bilateral mastectomy decisions.[<a href="#cit/section_9.31">

944631</a>

9447] </p>

9448<section id="_2559">

9449<h5 id="_2559_toc">

9450Insurance coverage</h5>

9451<p id="_2979" tabindex="-1">

9452Insurance coverage is an important consideration for individuals deciding whether to undergo genetic testing. (Refer to the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/risk-assessment-pdq#_1464">

9453Insurance coverage</a>

9454 section in the PDQ summary on <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/risk-assessment-pdq">

9455Cancer Genetics Risk Assessment and Counseling</a>

9456 for more information.)</p>

9457</section>

9458</section>

9459<section id="_1587">

9460<h4 id="_1587_toc">

9461Uptake of genetic counseling and genetic testing in diverse populations</h4>

9462<section id="_30">

9463<h5 id="_30_toc">

9464Degree of uptake of genetic counseling and genetic testing in diverse populations</h5>

9465<p id="_2561" tabindex="-1">

9466There are limited data on uptake of genetic counseling and testing among non-White populations, and further research will be needed to define factors influencing uptake in these populations.[<a href="#cit/section_9.32">

946732</a>

9468] The uptake of <em class="gene-name">

9469BRCA</em>

9470 testing appears to vary across some racial and ethnic groups. A few studies have compared uptake rates between African American and White women.[<a href="#cit/section_9.4">

94714</a>

9472,<a href="#cit/section_9.33">

947333</a>

9474] In a case-control study of women who had been seen in a university-based primary care system, African American women with family histories of breast cancer or ovarian cancer were less likely to undergo <em class="gene-name">

9475BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

9476 testing than were White women who had similar histories.[<a href="#cit/section_9.33">

947733</a>

9478] In another study among breast cancer patients who were counseled about <em class="gene-name">

9479BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

9480 risk in a clinical setting, lower uptake was reported among African American women than among White women.[<a href="#cit/section_9.4">

94814</a>

9482] </p>

9483<p id="_2606" tabindex="-1">

9484Notably, the racial differences observed in these studies do not appear to be explained by factors related to cost, access to care, risk factors for carrying a <em class="gene-name">

9485BRCA1</em>

9486 or <em class="gene-name">

9487BRCA2</em>

9488 pathogenic variant, or differences in psychosocial factors, including risk perceptions, worry, or attitudes toward testing.</p>

9489</section>

9490<section id="_1589">

9491<h5 id="_1589_toc">

9492Factors influencing uptake of genetic counseling and genetic testing in diverse populations</h5>

9493<p id="_2562" tabindex="-1">

9494Several studies have examined uptake or &#8220;acceptance&#8221; of <em class="gene-name">

9495BRCA</em>

9496 testing among African American individuals enrolled in genetic research programs. Among study enrollees from an African American kindred in Utah, 83% underwent <em class="gene-name">

9497BRCA1</em>

9498 testing.[<a href="#cit/section_9.34">

949934</a>

9500] Age, perceived risk of being a carrier, and more extensive cancer knowledge predicted testing acceptance. Another study that recruited African American women through physician and community referrals reported a <em class="gene-name">

9501BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

9502 testing acceptance rate of 22%.[<a href="#cit/section_9.35">

950335</a>

9504] Predictors of test acceptance included having a higher probability of having a pathogenic variant, being married, and being less certain about one&#8217;s cancer risk. Finally, a third study that recruited at-risk African American women from an urban cancer screening clinic found that acceptors of <em class="gene-name">

9505BRCA</em>

9506 testing were more knowledgeable about breast cancer genetics and perceived fewer barriers to testing, including negative emotional reactions, stigmatization concerns, and family-related guilt.[<a href="#cit/section_9.36">

950736</a>

9508] While these are independent predictors of genetic testing uptake, they do not explain the disparities in testing uptake across different ethnic groups. What may explain these differences are several attitudes and beliefs held about testing by individuals from diverse populations.</p>

9509<p id="_2563" tabindex="-1">

9510Work examining attitudes toward breast cancer genetic testing in Latino and African American populations indicates limited knowledge and awareness about testing but a generally receptive view once they are informed; in comparison with White populations, Latino and African American populations have relatively more concerns about testing.</p>

9511<p id="_2564" tabindex="-1">

9512For example, in a qualitative study with 51 Latino individuals unselected for risk status, important findings included the fact that participants were highly interested in genetic testing for inherited cancer susceptibility, despite very limited knowledge about genetics. One important barrier involved secrecy or embarrassment about family discussions of cancer and genetics, which could be addressed in intervention strategies.[<a href="#cit/section_9.37">

951337</a>

9514] Another qualitative study with 54 Latina women at risk of hereditary breast cancer showed that knowledge about <em class="gene-name">

9515BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

9516 counseling was low, although the women were interested in learning more about counseling to gain risk information for family members. Barriers to counseling included life demands, cost, and language issues.[<a href="#cit/section_9.38">

951738</a>

9518] </p>

9519<p id="_2994" tabindex="-1">

9520A telephone survey of 314 patients from an inner-city network of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, health centers, 50% of whom were African American, found that most participants (57%) (both African American and White participants) felt that genetic testing to evaluate disease risk was a good idea; however, more African American participants than White participants thought that genetic testing would lead to racial discrimination (37% vs. 22%, respectively) and that genetics research was unethical and tampered with nature (20% vs. 11%, respectively).[<a href="#cit/section_9.39">

952139</a>

9522] Finally, in a study of 222 women in Savannah, Georgia, where most had neither a personal history (70%) nor a family history (60%) of breast cancer, African American women (who comprised 26% of the sample) were less likely to be aware of breast cancer genes and genetic testing. Awareness was also related to higher income, higher education level, and having a family breast cancer history. However, 74% of the entire sample expressed willingness to be tested for breast cancer susceptibility.[<a href="#cit/section_9.40">

952340</a>

9524]</p>

9525<p id="_2565" tabindex="-1">

9526In a sample of 146 African American women meeting criteria for <em class="gene-name">

9527BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

9528 pathogenic variant testing, women born outside the United States reported higher levels of anticipated negative emotional reactions (e.g., fear, hopelessness, and lack of confidence that they could emotionally handle testing). Higher levels of breast cancer&#8211;specific distress were associated with anticipated negative emotional reactions, confidentiality concerns, and anticipated guilt regarding the family impact of breast cancer genetic testing.[<a href="#cit/section_9.41">

952941</a>

9530] A future orientation (e.g., "I often think about how my actions today will affect my health when I am older") was associated with overall perceived benefits of breast cancer genetic testing in this population (n = 140); however, future orientation was also found to be positively associated with family-related cons of testing, including family guilt and worry regarding the impact of testing on the family.[<a href="#cit/section_9.42">

953142</a>

9532]</p>

9533<p id="_3073" tabindex="-1">

9534There are racial differences in provider discussion and patient uptake of genetic testing for variants in <em class="gene-name">

9535BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

9536. A study of women aged 18 to 64 years and diagnosed with invasive breast cancer between 2007 and 2009 found that, even after adjusting for pathogenic variant risk, African American women were less likely to report having received a physician recommendation for genetic testing. There was no difference across all races in concerns that <em class="gene-name">

9537BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

9538 testing was too expensive and only minimal differences in testing attitudes or insurance concerns were found, none of which influenced testing uptake.[<a href="#cit/section_9.43">

953943</a>

9540] A study of breast or ovarian cancer survivors (N = 50) eligible for <em class="gene-name">

9541BRCA1</em>

9542/<em class="gene-name">

9543BRCA2</em>

9544 genetic testing found that 48% were referred for genetic counseling and testing and/or had undergone genetic testing. Individuals with higher breast cancer genetics knowledge and higher self-efficacy were more likely to have engaged in genetic counseling and testing.[<a href="#cit/section_9.44">

954544</a>

9546] In a study of women with invasive breast cancer diagnosed before age 50 years between 2009 and 2012 who were identified through the Florida Cancer Data System state registry and eligible for <em class="gene-name">

9547BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

9548 genetic testing on the basis of existing guidelines, African American individuals were less likely to report a discussion with their health care provider and undergo genetic testing.[<a href="#cit/section_9.45">

954945</a>

9550] The same study found similar overall testing rates in Hispanic (61%) and non-Hispanic (65%) White individuals. However, testing rates were lower among Hispanic individuals who spoke primarily Spanish at home (50% Spanish speaking vs. 69% English speaking; <em>

9551P</em>

9552 = .0009), and in general, Hispanic individuals were less likely to have been referred for genetic testing.[<a href="#cit/section_9.46">

955346</a>

9554] However, this finding is not consistent across all studies. In a study of women aged 20 to 79 years with ductal carcinoma <em>

9555in situ</em>

9556 or invasive breast cancer identified through the Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) registry in Georgia and Los Angeles County, all eligible for <em class="gene-name">

9557BRCA1</em>

9558/<em class="gene-name">

9559BRCA2</em>

9560 genetic testing on the basis of existing guidelines, no ethnic differences were detected in receipt of genetic counseling or physician-directed discussion about genetic testing.[<a href="#cit/section_9.30">

956130</a>

9562]</p>

9563</section>

9564</section>

9565<section id="_2566">

9566<h4 id="_2566_toc">

9567Factors associated with declining genetic counseling and testing</h4>

9568<p id="_37" tabindex="-1">

9569There is evidence that primary reasons for declining testing involves being childless, which reduces any family motivations for testing; and concerns about the negative ramifications of testing, including difficulty retaining insurance or concerns about personal health.</p>

9570<p id="_106" tabindex="-1">

9571Limited data are available about the characteristics of at-risk individuals who decline to be tested or have never been tested. It is difficult to access samples of test decliners because they may be reluctant to participate in research studies. Studies of genetic testing uptake are difficult to compare because people may decline at different points and with different amounts of pretest education and counseling. One study found that 43% of affected and <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460224&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460224&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9572unaffected</a>

9573 individuals from hereditary breast/ovarian cancer families who completed a baseline interview regarding testing declined to be tested. Most individuals who declined testing chose not to participate in educational sessions. Decliners were more likely to be male and be unmarried and have fewer relatives with breast cancer. Decliners who had high levels of cancer-related stress had higher levels of depression. Decliners lost to follow-up were significantly more likely to be affected with cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_9.47">

957447</a>

9575]</p>

9576<p id="_2607" tabindex="-1">

9577Another study looked at a small number (n = 13) of women decliners who carried a 25% to 50% probability of harboring a <em class="gene-name">

9578BRCA</em>

9579 pathogenic variant; these nontested women were more likely to be childless and to have higher levels of education. This study showed that most women decided not to undergo the test after serious deliberation about the risks and benefits. Satisfaction with frequent <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=496506&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000496506&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9580surveillance</a>

9581 was given as one reason for nontesting by most of these women.[<a href="#cit/section_9.48">

958248</a>

9583] Other reasons for declining included having no children and becoming acquainted with breast/ovarian cancer in the family relatively early in their lives.[<a href="#cit/section_9.47">

958447</a>

9585,<a href="#cit/section_9.48">

958648</a>

9587] </p>

9588<p id="_2608" tabindex="-1">

9589A third study evaluated characteristics of 34 individuals who declined <em class="gene-name">

9590BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

9591 testing in a large multicenter study in the United Kingdom. Decliners were younger than a national sample of test acceptors, and female decliners had lower mean scores on a measure of cancer worry. Although 78% of test decliners/deferrers felt that their health was at risk, they reported that learning about their <em class="gene-name">

9592BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

9593 pathogenic variant status would cause them to worry about the following:</p>

9594<div class="pdq-content-list">

9595<ul id="_107">

9596<li>

9597Their children's health (76%).</li>

9598<li>

9599Their life insurance (60%).</li>

9600<li>

9601Their own health (56%).</li>

9602<li>

9603Loss of their job (5%).</li>

9604<li>

9605Receiving less screening if they did not carry a <em class="gene-name">

9606BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

9607 pathogenic variant (62%).</li>

9608</ul>

9609</div>

9610<p id="_108" tabindex="-1">

9611Apprehension about the impact of the test result was a more important factor in the decision to decline testing than were concrete burdens such as time required to travel to a genetics clinic and time spent away from work, family, and social obligations.[<a href="#cit/section_9.49">

961249</a>

9613] In 15% (n = 31) of individuals from 13 hereditary breast and ovarian cancer (HBOC) families who underwent genetic education and counseling and declined testing for a documented pathogenic variant in the family, positive changes in family relationships were reported&#8212;specifically, greater expressiveness and cohesion&#8212;compared with those who pursued testing.[<a href="#cit/section_9.50">

961450</a>

9615]</p>

9616</section>

9617<section id="_2567">

9618<h4 id="_2567_toc">

9619Genetic counseling and testing in children</h4>

9620<p id="_39" tabindex="-1">

9621Testing for <em class="gene-name">

9622BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

9623 pathogenic variants has been almost universally limited to adults older than 18

9624years. The risks of testing children for adult-onset disorders, such as breast

9625and ovarian cancers, as inferred from developmental data on children&#8217;s medical

9626understanding and ability to provide informed consent, have been outlined in

9627several reports.[<a href="#cit/section_9.51">

962851</a>

9629-<a href="#cit/section_9.54">

963054</a>

9631] </p>

9632<p id="_2568" tabindex="-1">

9633Studies suggest that individuals who have undergone <em class="gene-name">

9634BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

9635 genetic testing or who are adult offspring of individuals who have had testing are generally not in favor of testing minors.[<a href="#cit/section_9.55">

963655</a>

9637,<a href="#cit/section_9.56">

963856</a>

9639] Although the data are limited, research suggests that males, pathogenic variant <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=556483&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000556483&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9640noncarriers</a>

9641, and those whose mothers did not have personal histories of breast cancer may be more likely to favor genetic testing in minors in general.[<a href="#cit/section_9.55">

964255</a>

9643] Of those who had minor children at the time the study was conducted, only 17% stated a preference for having their own children tested. Concerns regarding testing of minors included psychological risks and insufficient maturity. Potential benefits included the ability to influence health behaviors.[<a href="#cit/section_9.56">

964456</a>

9645]</p>

9646<p id="_2609" tabindex="-1">

9647 No data exist on the testing of children for

9648<em class="gene-name">

9649BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

9650 pathogenic variants, although some researchers believe it is necessary to test the validity

9651of assumptions underlying the general prohibition of testing children for

9652genetic variants associated with breast and ovarian cancers and other adult-onset diseases.[<a href="#cit/section_9.57">

965357</a>

9654-<a href="#cit/section_9.59">

965559</a>

9656] In one study, 20 children (aged 11&#8211;17 y) of a selected group of mothers undergoing genetic testing (80% of whom previously had breast cancer and all of whom had discussed <em class="gene-name">

9657BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

9658 testing with their children) completed self-report questionnaires on their health beliefs and attitudes toward cancer, feelings related to cancer, and behavioral problems.[<a href="#cit/section_9.60">

965960</a>

9660] Ninety percent of children thought they would want cancer risk information as adults; half worried about themselves or a family member developing cancer. There was no evidence of emotional distress or behavioral problems. </p>

9661</section>

9662</section>

9663<section id="_285">

9664<h3 id="_285_toc">

9665What People Bring to Genetic Testing: Impact of Risk Perception, Health Beliefs, and Personality Characteristics</h3>

9666<p id="_286" tabindex="-1">

9667The emerging literature in this area suggests that risk perceptions,

9668health beliefs, psychological status, and personality characteristics are important factors in

9669decision making about breast/ovarian cancer genetic testing. Many women

9670presenting at academic centers for <em class="gene-name">

9671BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

9672 testing arrive with a strong belief

9673that they have a pathogenic variant, having decided they want genetic testing, but

9674possessing little information about the risks or limitations of testing.[<a href="#cit/section_9.61">

967561</a>

9676] Most mean scores of psychological functioning at baseline for subjects in genetic counseling studies were within normal limits.[<a href="#cit/section_9.62">

967762</a>

9678] Nonetheless, a subset of subjects in many genetic counseling studies present with elevated anxiety, depression, or cancer worry.[<a href="#cit/section_9.63">

967963</a>

9680,<a href="#cit/section_9.64">

968164</a>

9682] Identification of these individuals is essential to prevent adverse outcomes. In a study of 205 women pursuing genetic counseling, interactions among cancer worry, breast cancer risk perception, and perceived severity of having a breast cancer <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=776887&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000776887&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9683genetic variant</a>

9684 were found such that those with high worry, high breast cancer risk perception, and low perceived severity were twice as likely to follow through with <em class="gene-name">

9685BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

9686 testing than others.[<a href="#cit/section_9.65">

968765</a>

9688]

9689</p>

9690<p id="_287" tabindex="-1">

9691A general tendency to overestimate inherited risk of breast and ovarian cancer

9692has been noted in at-risk populations,[<a href="#cit/section_9.66">

969366</a>

9694-<a href="#cit/section_9.69">

969569</a>

9696] in cancer patients,[<a href="#cit/section_9.67">

969767</a>

9698,<a href="#cit/section_9.70">

969970</a>

9700,<a href="#cit/section_9.71">

970171</a>

9702] in spouses of breast and ovarian cancer patients,[<a href="#cit/section_9.72">

970372</a>

9704] and among

9705women in the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_9.73">

970673</a>

9707-<a href="#cit/section_9.75">

970875</a>

9709] but underestimation of breast cancer risk in higher-risk and average-risk women also has been reported.[<a href="#cit/section_9.76">

971076</a>

9711] This overestimation may encourage a belief that

9712<em class="gene-name">

9713BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

9714 genetic testing will be more <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460156&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460156&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9715informative</a>

9716 than it is currently thought

9717to be. Some evidence exists that even counseling does not dissuade women at

9718low to moderate risk from the belief that <em class="gene-name">

9719BRCA1</em>

9720 testing could be valuable.[<a href="#cit/section_9.32">

972132</a>

9722]

9723 Overestimation of both breast and ovarian cancer risk has been associated with nonadherence to physician-recommended screening practices.[<a href="#cit/section_9.77">

972477</a>

9725,<a href="#cit/section_9.78">

972678</a>

9727] A meta-analysis of 12 studies of outcomes of genetic counseling for breast/ovarian cancer showed that counseling improved the accuracy of risk perception.[<a href="#cit/section_9.79">

972879</a>

9729]</p>

9730<p id="_288" tabindex="-1">

9731Women appear to be the prime communicators within families about the family

9732history of breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_9.80">

973380</a>

9734] Higher numbers of maternal versus paternal

9735transmission cases are reported,[<a href="#cit/section_9.81">

973681</a>

9737] likely due to family communication

9738patterns, to the misconception that breast cancer risk can only be transmitted

9739through the mother, and to the greater difficulty in recognizing paternal

9740family histories because of the need to identify more distant relatives with

9741cancer. In an analysis of 2,505 women participating in the Family Healthware Impact Trial,[<a href="#cit/section_9.82">

974282</a>

9743] not only was evidence of underreporting of paternal family history identified, but also women reported a lower level of perceived breast cancer risk with a paternal versus maternal breast cancer family history.[<a href="#cit/section_9.83">

974483</a>

9745] Physicians and counselors taking a family history are encouraged to

9746elicit paternal and maternal family histories of breast, ovarian, or

9747other associated cancers.[<a href="#cit/section_9.80">

974880</a>

9749]

9750</p>

9751<p id="_289" tabindex="-1">

9752The accuracy of reported family history of breast or ovarian cancer varies;

9753some studies found levels of accuracy above 90%,[<a href="#cit/section_9.84">

975484</a>

9755,<a href="#cit/section_9.85">

975685</a>

9757] with others finding

9758more errors in the reporting of cancer in second-degree relatives (SDRs) or more distant

9759relatives [<a href="#cit/section_9.86">

976086</a>

9761] or in age of onset of cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_9.87">

976287</a>

9763] Less accuracy has been found in the reporting of cancers other

9764than breast cancer. Ovarian cancer history was reported with 60% accuracy in

9765one study compared with 83% accuracy in breast cancer history.[<a href="#cit/section_9.88">

976688</a>

9767] Providers

9768should be aware that there are a few published cases of Munchausen syndrome in

9769reporting of false family breast cancer history.[<a href="#cit/section_9.89">

977089</a>

9771] Much more common is

9772erroneous reporting of family cancer history due to unintentional errors or

9773gaps in knowledge, related in some cases to the early death of potential

9774maternal informants about cancer family history.[<a href="#cit/section_9.80">

977580</a>

9776]

9777(Refer to the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/risk-assessment-pdq#_188">

9778Documenting the Family History</a>

9779 section in Cancer Genetics Risk Assessment and Counseling for more information.)</p>

9780<p id="_403" tabindex="-1">

9781Targeted written,[<a href="#cit/section_9.90">

978290</a>

9783,<a href="#cit/section_9.91">

978491</a>

9785] video, CD-ROM, interactive computer programs and websites,[<a href="#cit/section_9.92">

978692</a>

9787-<a href="#cit/section_9.99">

978899</a>

9789] and culturally targeted educational materials [<a href="#cit/section_9.100">

9790100</a>

9791-<a href="#cit/section_9.102">

9792102</a>

9793] may be effective and efficient methods of increasing knowledge about the pros and cons of genetic testing. Such supplemental materials may allow more efficient use of the time allotted for pretest education and counseling by genetics and primary care providers and may discourage individuals without appropriate indication of risk from seeking genetic testing.[<a href="#cit/section_9.90">

979490</a>

9795] </p>

9796</section>

9797<section id="_290">

9798<h3 id="_290_toc">

9799Genetic Counseling for Hereditary Predisposition to Breast Cancer</h3>

9800<p id="_291" tabindex="-1">

9801Counseling for breast cancer risk typically involves individuals with family

9802histories that are potentially attributable to <em class="gene-name">

9803BRCA1</em>

9804 or <em class="gene-name">

9805BRCA2</em>

9806. It also, however,

9807may include individuals with family histories of Li-Fraumeni syndrome, ataxia-telangiectasia, Cowden syndrome, or Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_9.103">

9808103</a>

9809] (Refer to the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_88">

9810High-Penetrance Breast and/or Gynecologic Cancer Susceptibility Genes</a>

9811 section of this summary for more information.)

9812</p>

9813<p id="_292" tabindex="-1">

9814Management strategies for carriers may involve decisions about the nature, frequency, and

9815timing of screening and surveillance procedures, chemoprevention, risk-reducing surgery, and use of

9816hormone replacement therapy (HRT). The utilization of breast conservation and

9817radiation as cancer therapy for women who are carriers may be influenced by knowledge of pathogenic variant status. (Refer to the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq#_3492">

9818Management of Cancer Risks in <em class="gene-name">

9819BRCA1/2</em>

9820 Carriers</a>

9821 section in <em class="gene-name">

9822BRCA1</em>

9823 and <em class="gene-name">

9824BRCA2</em>

9825: Cancer Risks and Management for more information.)</p>

9826<p id="_293" tabindex="-1">

9827Counseling also includes consideration of related psychosocial concerns and

9828discussion of planned family communication and the responsibility to warn other

9829family members about the possibility of having an increased risk of breast,

9830ovarian, and other cancers. Data suggest that individual responses to being tested as adults are influenced by the results status of other family members.[<a href="#cit/section_9.104">

9831104</a>

9832,<a href="#cit/section_9.105">

9833105</a>

9834] Management of anxiety and distress are important

9835not only as quality-of-life factors, but also because high anxiety may

9836interfere with the understanding and integration of complex genetic and medical

9837information and adherence to screening.[<a href="#cit/section_9.106">

9838106</a>

9839-<a href="#cit/section_9.108">

9840108</a>

9841] Formal, objective evaluation of these outcomes are well documented. (Refer to the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_298">

9842Emotional Outcomes</a>

9843 and <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_332">

9844Behavioral Outcomes</a>

9845 sections of this summary for more information.)

9846</p>

9847<p id="_295" tabindex="-1">

9848Published descriptions of counseling programs for <em class="gene-name">

9849BRCA1</em>

9850 (and subsequently for

9851<em class="gene-name">

9852BRCA2</em>

9853) testing include strategies for gathering a family history, assessing

9854eligibility for testing, communicating the considerable volume of relevant

9855information about breast/ovarian cancer genetics and associated medical and

9856psychosocial risks and benefits, and discussion of specialized ethical

9857considerations about confidentiality and family communication.[<a href="#cit/section_9.109">

9858109</a>

9859-<a href="#cit/section_9.116">

9860116</a>

9861]

9862Participant distress, intrusive thoughts about cancer, coping style, and social

9863support were assessed in many prospective testing candidates. The psychosocial

9864outcomes evaluated in these programs have included changes in knowledge about

9865the genetics of breast/ovarian cancer after counseling, risk comprehension,

9866psychological adjustment, family and social functioning, and reproductive and

9867health behaviors.[<a href="#cit/section_9.117">

9868117</a>

9869] A Dutch study of communication processes and satisfaction levels of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460140&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460140&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9870consultands</a>

9871 going through cancer genetic counseling for inherited cancer syndromes indicated that asking more medical questions (by the counselor), providing more psychosocial information, and longer eye contact by the counselor were associated with lower satisfaction levels. The provision of medical information by the counselor was most highly related to satisfaction and perception that needs have been fulfilled.[<a href="#cit/section_9.118">

9872118</a>

9873]</p>

9874<p id="_296" tabindex="-1">

9875Many of the psychosocial outcome studies involve specialized, highly selected

9876research populations, some of which were utilized to map and clone <em class="gene-name">

9877BRCA1</em>

9878 and

9879<em class="gene-name">

9880BRCA2</em>

9881. One such example is K2082, an extensively studied kindred of more than 800

9882members of a Utah Mormon family in which a <em class="gene-name">

9883BRCA1</em>

9884 pathogenic variant accounts for the

9885observed increased rates of breast and ovarian cancer. A study of the

9886understanding that members of this kindred have about breast/ovarian cancer

9887genetics found that, even in breast cancer research populations, there was

9888incomplete knowledge about associated risks of colon and prostate cancer, the

9889existence of options for risk-reducing mastectomy (RRM) and risk-reducing salpingo-oophorectomy (RRSO),

9890and the complexity of existing psychosocial risks.[<a href="#cit/section_9.109">

9891109</a>

9892]

9893A meta-analysis of 21 studies found that genetic counseling was effective in increasing knowledge and improved the accuracy of perceived risk. Genetic counseling did not have a statistically significant long-term impact on affective outcomes including anxiety, distress, or cancer-specific worry and the behavioral outcome of cancer surveillance activities.[<a href="#cit/section_9.62">

989462</a>

9895] These prospective studies, however, were characterized by a heterogeneity of measures of cancer-specific worry and inconsistent findings in effects of change from baseline.[<a href="#cit/section_9.62">

989662</a>

9897]</p>

9898</section>

9899<section id="_298">

9900<h3 id="_298_toc">

9901Emotional Outcomes</h3>

9902<p id="_2569" tabindex="-1">

9903Although there were initial concerns about the possibility of adverse emotional consequences from <em class="gene-name">

9904BRCA</em>

9905 testing, most studies conducted over the years have shown low levels of psychological distress among both carriers and noncarriers, particularly over the longer term.[<a href="#cit/section_9.119">

9906119</a>

9907-<a href="#cit/section_9.121">

9908121</a>

9909] In a meta-analysis examining cancer-specific distress over short (0&#8211;4 weeks), moderate (5&#8211;24 weeks), and long (25&#8211;52 weeks) periods of time since the receipt of testing results, carriers were found to demonstrate increased levels of distress shortly after receiving results, with levels returning to baseline within moderate and long periods of time.[<a href="#cit/section_9.119">

9910119</a>

9911] In contrast, noncarriers and those with inconclusive results showed reduced levels of distress over time.[<a href="#cit/section_9.119">

9912119</a>

9913,<a href="#cit/section_9.122">

9914122</a>

9915] Psychological distress patterns were found to vary as a function of several factors, including the cancer history of the individual and the country within which the study was conducted. Carriers with a personal history of cancer experienced small decreases in distress over time, whereas no changes were observed among carriers without a personal history of cancer. Among individuals with inconclusive results, greater decreases in distress were observed among those without a cancer history than among those with a cancer history. Among noncarriers, those in the United States experienced significantly greater decreases in psychological distress than noncarriers from Europe and Australia. A study conducted in Austria noted that certain subgroups of consultands experienced greater distress, including those who were older, had a more recent cancer diagnosis, or those who had received counseling but declined <em class="gene-name">

9916BRCA</em>

9917 testing.[<a href="#cit/section_9.123">

9918123</a>

9919]</p>

9920<p id="_2470" tabindex="-1">

9921Several studies have reported on emotional outcomes over longer follow-up periods (i.e., greater than 12 months after disclosure) than those reported in the meta-analysis described above.[<a href="#cit/section_9.119">

9922119</a>

9923] In a U.K. study, cancer-related worry did not differ between carriers and noncarriers at 3 years of follow-up.[<a href="#cit/section_9.124">

9924124</a>

9925] Two U.S.-based studies published since the meta-analytic review [<a href="#cit/section_9.119">

9926119</a>

9927] have reported similar findings among women who were surveyed more than 3 years after receipt of <em class="gene-name">

9928BRCA</em>

9929 test results.[<a href="#cit/section_9.125">

9930125</a>

9931,<a href="#cit/section_9.126">

9932126</a>

9933] In a cross-sectional study,[<a href="#cit/section_9.125">

9934125</a>

9935] 167 women who were surveyed more than 4 years after receiving <em class="gene-name">

9936BRCA</em>

9937 test results reported low levels of genetic testing&#8211;specific concerns, as measured using the Multidimensional Impact of Cancer Risk Assessment Scale.[<a href="#cit/section_9.127">

9938127</a>

9939] In multivariate regression models, carriers of pathogenic variants were significantly more likely to experience distress than were noncarriers. In a second study,[<a href="#cit/section_9.126">

9940126</a>

9941] 464 women were followed prospectively for a median of 5 years (range, 3.4&#8211;9.1 y) after testing. Among both affected and unaffected participants, <em class="gene-name">

9942BRCA</em>

9943 carriers reported significantly higher levels of distress, uncertainty (affected only), perceived stress (affected only), and lower positive testing experiences (unaffected only) than women who received negative results for a known pathogenic variant in the family.[<a href="#cit/section_9.126">

9944126</a>

9945] Although both studies [<a href="#cit/section_9.125">

9946125</a>

9947,<a href="#cit/section_9.126">

9948126</a>

9949] reported greater distress among <em class="gene-name">

9950BRCA</em>

9951 carriers than among noncarriers, the level of distress was not reflective of clinically significant dysfunction. </p>

9952<p id="_2506" tabindex="-1">

9953Although most studies have reported that a positive <em class="gene-name">

9954BRCA</em>

9955 test result has a relatively minimal impact on psychological distress, many of these studies were conducted among families with a strong family history of breast or ovarian cancer who underwent extensive pretest genetic counseling. Therefore, emotional responses may not generalize to individuals who test under different contexts. For example, individuals who are tested with population <em class="gene-name">

9956BRCA</em>

9957 screening may not have a family history of cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_9.128">

9958128</a>

9959-<a href="#cit/section_9.130">

9960130</a>

9961] Although pretest genetic counseling is recommended, this is not always done when genetic testing is ordered by nongenetic providers [<a href="#cit/section_9.131">

9962131</a>

9963] or directly through commercial companies.[<a href="#cit/section_9.132">

9964132</a>

9965,<a href="#cit/section_9.133">

9966133</a>

9967] </p>

9968<p id="_2596" tabindex="-1">

9969For example, in a Canadian study of 2,080 Jewish women who participated in a population-based genetic screening study to test for three <em class="gene-name">

9970BRCA</em>

9971 pathogenic variants common in families of Jewish heritage, women were not offered in-person genetic counseling but were given a pamphlet on genetic testing for <em class="gene-name">

9972BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

9973 before they provided a DNA sample. One year after genetic testing, women who were positive for a pathogenic variant (n = 18) showed significant increases in cancer-specific distress, whereas no changes in distress were observed among women who were negative for a pathogenic variant.[<a href="#cit/section_9.129">

9974129</a>

9975] The mean distress score on the Impact of Event Scale for the 18 women with a known pathogenic variant was 25.3 (range, 2&#8211;51); 10 of 18 women (56%) scored within moderate (26&#8211;43) (n = 7) or severe (44+) (n = 3) ranges. It is unclear from this study whether the increase in distress observed at 1 year of follow-up was due to the lack of in-person genetic counseling, or whether the lower levels of distress at baseline observed were because the women in the study were low risk but eligible for testing because of their ancestry. A follow-up study with this cohort found that distress decreased between 1 to 2 years after testing and that changes in distress varied by risk-reduction options undertaken by carriers. Specifically, those who had undergone RRM or risk-reducing oophorectomy experienced significant decreases in distress compared with those who did not have either surgery.[<a href="#cit/section_9.130">

9976130</a>

9977] Another smaller qualitative study also supports these findings.[<a href="#cit/section_9.134">

9978134</a>

9979]</p>

9980<p id="_2597" tabindex="-1">

9981Similarly, the impact of direct-to-consumer (DTC) <em class="gene-name">

9982BRCA</em>

9983 testing through commercial companies requires further evaluation. Case studies have reported adverse emotional responses after receipt of a positive <em class="gene-name">

9984BRCA</em>

9985 result from DTC genetic testing, suggesting the need for further evaluation of the emotional outcomes of women undergoing genetic testing through commercial companies.[<a href="#cit/section_9.132">

9986132</a>

9987,<a href="#cit/section_9.133">

9988133</a>

9989] Only one study, conducted by a commercial company, has attempted to evaluate the impact of <em class="gene-name">

9990BRCA</em>

9991 testing in this context.[<a href="#cit/section_9.135">

9992135</a>

9993] A total of 32 individuals (16 women and 16 men) who tested positive for one of three <em class="gene-name">

9994BRCA</em>

9995 <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783962&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783962&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9996founder pathogenic variants</a>

9997 common in AJs completed semi-structured interviews. None of the carriers reported extreme anxiety, although some experienced moderate anxiety (13%) or initial disappointment and anxiety that dissipated over time (28%). These findings should be interpreted with caution given that only 24% (32 of 136) of invited carriers of <em class="gene-name">

9998BRCA</em>

9999 pathogenic variants participated in the study, raising concerns about selection bias. </p>

10000<p id="_2721" tabindex="-1">

10001Despite evidence of a short-term increase in distress after the receipt of genetic testing results, any adverse responses to a positive carrier status dissipate within 12 months.[<a href="#cit/section_9.119">

10002119</a>

10003] Additional research is needed to examine emotional outcomes for those who are not provided genetic counseling before testing.[<a href="#cit/section_9.131">

10004131</a>

10005]</p>

10006<section id="_2570">

10007<h4 id="_2570_toc">

10008Emotional outcomes in newly diagnosed breast cancer patients</h4>

10009<p id="_2894" tabindex="-1">

10010 It is increasingly common for women with breast cancer to pursue genetic counseling and testing at the time of diagnosis to assist with treatment decision making. (Refer to the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_3080">

10011Benefits of offering genetic testing at the time of cancer diagnosis</a>

10012 section for more information.) Given that women with new breast cancer diagnoses are likely to experience some distress, concerns have been raised about the potential for additional adverse psychological implications of rapid genetic counseling and testing (RGT) between diagnosis and surgery.[<a href="#cit/section_9.136">

10013136</a>

10014,<a href="#cit/section_9.137">

10015137</a>

10016] However, data from several studies,[<a href="#cit/section_9.138">

10017138</a>

10018-<a href="#cit/section_9.140">

10019140</a>

10020] including a large observational study [<a href="#cit/section_9.141">

10021141</a>

10022] and a randomized trial,[<a href="#cit/section_9.142">

10023142</a>

10024] provided evidence indicating that there were no adverse psychological effects associated with RGT. For example, an observational study analyzed 1,007 genetically high-risk patients with newly diagnosed breast cancers from four Canadian academic centers. These patients underwent RGT and adverse psychological effects were not noted at one week or one year posttesting.[<a href="#cit/section_9.141">

10025141</a>

10026] There were no differences in anxiety, distress, or depression between <em class="gene-name">

10027BRCA</em>

10028 carriers (6% of the study population) and those with uninformative results in the short-term. However, after one year, <em class="gene-name">

10029BRCA</em>

10030 carriers had significantly lower depression scores when compared with patients who had uninformative, negative results. Depression scores were within the normal range for both groups, and these scores did not reach depression levels that were clinically significant. Factors associated with lower levels of psychological functioning included lower educational levels, not having family histories of cancer, and undergoing bilateral mastectomies. Of note, women who had a variant of uncertain significance in the <em class="gene-name">

10031BRCA1/2</em>

10032 genes and a bilateral mastectomy had higher depression scores than <em class="gene-name">

10033BRCA</em>

10034 carriers. One randomized controlled trial found that patients undergoing rapid genetic counseling and testing felt more actively involved in treatment decision making than those receiving standard care.[<a href="#cit/section_9.143">

10035143</a>

10036] </p>

10037</section>

10038</section>

10039<section id="_303">

10040<h3 id="_303_toc">

10041Family Effects</h3>

10042<section id="_964">

10043<h4 id="_964_toc">

10044Family communication about genetic testing and hereditary risk</h4>

10045<p id="_304" tabindex="-1">

10046Family communication about genetic testing for cancer susceptibility, and

10047specifically about the results of <em class="gene-name">

10048BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10049 genetic testing, is complex. Age and gender appear to be important variables in the disclosure of genetic test results. Studies have documented that older women were more likely to disclose genetic test results (especially to their daughters) than younger women.[<a href="#cit/section_9.144">

10050144</a>

10051,<a href="#cit/section_9.145">

10052145</a>

10053] Female carriers are more likely to disclose their genetic test results

10054to other family members [<a href="#cit/section_9.146">

10055146</a>

10056] than

10057are male carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_9.146">

10058146</a>

10059,<a href="#cit/section_9.147">

10060147</a>

10061] Among males, noncarriers were more likely than carriers

10062to tell their sisters and children the results of their tests. <em class="gene-name">

10063BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10064

10065carriers who disclosed their results to sisters had a slight decrease in

10066psychological distress, compared with a slight increase in distress for carriers

10067who chose not to tell their sisters. One study found that men reported greater difficulty disclosing a known pathogenic variant to family members than women (90% vs. 70%).[<a href="#cit/section_9.148">

10068148</a>

10069]</p>

10070<p id="_935" tabindex="-1">

10071Family communication of <em class="gene-name">

10072BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10073 test results to relatives is another factor affecting participation in testing. There have been more studies of communication with FDRs and SDRs than with more distant family members. Studies have investigated the process and content of communication among sisters about <em class="gene-name">

10074BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10075 test results.[<a href="#cit/section_9.149">

10076149</a>

10077,<a href="#cit/section_9.150">

10078150</a>

10079] Study results suggest that both carriers of pathogenic variants [<a href="#cit/section_9.149">

10080149</a>

10081] and women with uninformative results [<a href="#cit/section_9.149">

10082149</a>

10083,<a href="#cit/section_9.150">

10084150</a>

10085] communicate with sisters to provide them with genetic risk information. Similar findings were reported in women with uninformative results disclosing test results to their daughters.[<a href="#cit/section_9.150">

10086150</a>

10087] </p>

10088<p id="_3446" tabindex="-1">

10089Among relatives with whom genetic test results were not discussed, the most important reason given was that the affected women were not close to their relatives [<a href="#cit/section_9.149">

10090149</a>

10091] or had a poor relationship with them.[<a href="#cit/section_9.150">

10092150</a>

10093] Studies found that women with a <em class="gene-name">

10094BRCA</em>

10095 pathogenic variant more often shared their results with their mother and adult sisters and daughters than with their father and adult brothers and sons.[<a href="#cit/section_9.80">

1009680</a>

10097,<a href="#cit/section_9.144">

10098144</a>

10099,<a href="#cit/section_9.145">

10100145</a>

10101,<a href="#cit/section_9.151">

10102151</a>

10103-<a href="#cit/section_9.153">

10104153</a>

10105] </p>

10106<p id="_3447" tabindex="-1">

10107A study that evaluated communication of test results to FDRs at 4 months postdisclosure found that participants were more likely to inform brothers of their results if the <em class="gene-name">

10108BRCA</em>

10109 pathogenic variant was inherited through the paternal line.[<a href="#cit/section_9.145">

10110145</a>

10111] Another study found that disclosure was limited mainly to FDRs, and dissemination of information to distant relatives was problematic.[<a href="#cit/section_9.154">

10112154</a>

10113] Age was a significant factor in informing distant relatives with younger patients being more willing to communicate their genetic test result.[<a href="#cit/section_9.149">

10114149</a>

10115,<a href="#cit/section_9.151">

10116151</a>

10117,<a href="#cit/section_9.154">

10118154</a>

10119] Additionally, one study found that lower genetic worry, higher interest in genomic information, carrying a <em class="gene-name">

10120BRCA1</em>

10121 or <em class="gene-name">

10122BRCA2</em>

10123 pathogenic variant, or having never been married was associated with communication to more family members.[<a href="#cit/section_9.147">

10124147</a>

10125] In contrast, a longer time interval since diagnosis was associated with communication to fewer family members.[<a href="#cit/section_9.147">

10126147</a>

10127]</p>

10128<p id="_790" tabindex="-1">

10129A few in-depth qualitative studies have looked at issues associated with family communication about genetic testing. Although the findings from these studies may not be generalizable to the larger population of at-risk individuals, they illustrate the complexity of issues involved in conveying hereditary cancer risk information in families.[<a href="#cit/section_9.155">

10130155</a>

10131] On the basis of 15 interviews conducted with women attending a familial cancer genetics clinic, the authors concluded that while women felt a sense of duty to discuss genetic testing with their relatives, they also experienced conflicting feelings of uncertainty, respect, and isolation. Decisions about whom in the family to inform and how to inform them about hereditary cancer and genetic testing may be influenced by tensions between women's need to fulfill social roles and their responsibilities toward themselves and others.[<a href="#cit/section_9.155">

10132155</a>

10133] Another qualitative study of 21 women who attended a familial breast and ovarian cancer genetics clinic suggested that some women may find it difficult to communicate about inherited cancer risk with their partners and with certain relatives, especially brothers, because of their own fears and worries about cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_9.153">
