10134153</a>

10135] This study also suggested that how genetic risk information is shared within families may depend on the existing norms for communicating about cancer in general. For example, family members may be generally open to sharing information about cancer with each other, may selectively avoid discussing cancer information with certain family members to protect themselves or other relatives from negative emotional reactions, or may ask a specific relative to act as an intermediary to disclosure of information to other family members.[<a href="#cit/section_9.156">

10136156</a>

10137] The potential importance of individuals outside the family, such as friends, as both confidantes about inherited cancer risk information and as sources of support for coping with this information was also noted in the study.[<a href="#cit/section_9.153">

10138153</a>

10139] </p>

10140<p id="_1403" tabindex="-1">

10141A study of 31 mothers with a documented <em class="gene-name">

10142BRCA</em>

10143 pathogenic variant explored patterns of dissemination to children.[<a href="#cit/section_9.157">

10144157</a>

10145] Of those who chose to disclose test results to their children, age of offspring was the most important factor. Fifty percent of the children who were told were aged 20 to 29 years and slightly more than 25% of the children were aged 19 years or younger. Sons and daughters were notified in equal numbers. More than 70% of mothers informed their children within a week of learning their test result. Ninety-three percent of mothers who chose not to share their results with their children indicated that it was because their children were too young. These findings were consistent with three other studies showing that children younger than 13 years were less likely to be informed about test

10146results compared with older children.[<a href="#cit/section_9.145">

10147145</a>

10148,<a href="#cit/section_9.158">

10149158</a>

10150,<a href="#cit/section_9.159">

10151159</a>

10152] Another study of 187 mothers undergoing <em class="gene-name">

10153BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10154 testing evaluated their need for resources to prepare for a facilitated conversation about sharing their <em class="gene-name">

10155BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10156 testing results with their children. Seventy-eight percent of mothers were interested in three or more resources, including literature (93%), family counseling (86%), talk to prior participants (79%), and support groups (54%).[<a href="#cit/section_9.158">

10157158</a>

10158]</p>

10159<p id="_1019" tabindex="-1">

10160A longitudinal study of 153 women self-referred for genetic testing for <em class="gene-name">

10161BRCA1</em>

10162 and <em class="gene-name">

10163BRCA2</em>

10164 pathogenic variants and 118 of their partners evaluated communication about genetic testing and distress before testing and at 6 months

10165posttesting.[<a href="#cit/section_9.160">

10166160</a>

10167] The study found that most couples discussed the decision to undergo testing (98%), most test participants felt their partners were supportive, and most women disclosed test results to their partners (97%, n = 148). Test participants who felt their partners were supportive during pretest discussions experienced less distress after disclosure, and

10168partners who felt more comfortable sharing concerns with test participants pretest experienced less distress after disclosure. Six-month follow-up revealed that 22% of participants felt the need to talk about the testing experience with their partners in the week before the interview. Most participants (72%, n = 107) reported comfort in sharing concerns with their partners, and 5% (n = 7) reported relationship strain as a result of genetic testing. In couples in which the woman had a positive genetic test result, more relationship strain, more protective buffering of their partners, and more discussion of related concerns were reported than in couples in which the woman had a true-negative or uninformative result.[<a href="#cit/section_9.160">

10169160</a>

10170]</p>

10171<p id="_3168" tabindex="-1">

10172A study of 561 FDRs of women who had undergone <em class="gene-name">

10173BRCA1</em>

10174/<em class="gene-name">

10175BRCA2</em>

10176 genetic testing found that 22% of FDRs did not recall being informed of the genetic test results despite the women reporting that the results had been shared.[<a href="#cit/section_9.161">

10177161</a>

10178] Men were less likely to recall receiving the results (<em>

10179P</em>

10180 &gt; .001). Of those with recall about receiving the test results, 10.5% of FDRs did not recall the findings. For those with recall of the results, 17.9% of FDRs had an interpretation that was discordant with the correct results. Accuracy of test results recall was greater for informative test results (those that were either true positive or true negative) (<em>

10181P</em>

10182 = .029). However, regardless of the test results, FDRs perceived the cancer risk to be higher before they learned of the findings than after (74% and 53% of FDRs reported that they believed their risk for cancer was greater than average before and after hearing test results, respectively).</p>

10183<p id="_632" tabindex="-1">

10184There is a small but growing body of literature regarding psychological effects in men who have a family history of breast cancer and who are considering or have had <em class="gene-name">

10185BRCA</em>

10186 testing. A qualitative study of 22 men from 16 high-risk families in Ireland revealed that more men in the study with daughters were tested than men without daughters. These men reported little communication with relatives about the illness, with some men reporting being excluded from discussion about cancer

10187among female family members. Some men in the study also reported actively avoiding open discussion with daughters and other relatives.[<a href="#cit/section_9.162">

10188162</a>

10189] In contrast, a study of 59 men testing positive for a <em class="gene-name">

10190BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10191 pathogenic variant found that most men participated in family discussions about breast and/or ovarian cancer. However, fewer than half of the men participated in family discussions about risk-reducing surgery. The main reason given for having <em class="gene-name">

10192BRCA</em>

10193 testing was concern for their children and a need for certainty about whether they could have transmitted the pathogenic variant to their children. In this study, 79% of participating men had at least one daughter. Most of these men described how their relationships had been strengthened after receipt of <em class="gene-name">

10194BRCA</em>

10195 results, helping communication in the family and greater understanding.[<a href="#cit/section_9.163">

10196163</a>

10197] Men in both studies expressed fears of developing cancer themselves. Irish men especially reported

10198fear of cancer in sexual organs.</p>

10199</section>

10200<section id="_969">

10201<h4 id="_969_toc">

10202Family functioning</h4>

10203<p id="_936" tabindex="-1">

10204One study assessed 212 individuals from 13 families with HBOC who received genetic counseling and were offered <em class="gene-name">

10205BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10206 testing for documented pathogenic variants in the family. Individuals who were not tested were found 6 to 9 months later to have significantly greater increases in family expressiveness and cohesiveness compared with those who were tested. Individuals who were randomly assigned to a client-centered versus problem-solving genetic counseling intervention had a significantly greater reduction in conflict, regardless of the test decision.[<a href="#cit/section_9.50">

1020750</a>

10208]</p>

10209</section>

10210<section id="_1382">

10211<h4 id="_1382_toc">

10212Partners of high-risk women</h4>

10213<p id="_1384" tabindex="-1">

10214Many studies have looked at the psychological effects in women of having a high risk of developing cancer, either on the basis of carrying a <em class="gene-name">

10215BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10216 pathogenic variant or having a strong family history of cancer. Some studies have also examined the effects on the partners of such women. </p>

10217<p id="_1395" tabindex="-1">

10218A Canadian study assessed 59 spouses of women found to have a <em class="gene-name">

10219BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10220 pathogenic variant. All were supportive of their spouses&#8217; decision to undergo genetic testing and 17% wished they had been more involved in the genetic testing process. Spouses who reported that genetic testing had no impact on their relationship had long-term relationships (mean duration 27 years). Forty-six percent of spouses reported that their major concern was of their partner dying of cancer. Nineteen percent were concerned their spouse would develop cancer and 14% were concerned their children would also be carriers of <em class="gene-name">

10221BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10222 pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_9.164">

10223164</a>

10224]</p>

10225<p id="_1396" tabindex="-1">

10226In a U.S. study, 118 partners of women who underwent genetic testing for pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

10227BRCA1</em>

10228 and <em class="gene-name">

10229BRCA2</em>

10230 completed a survey before testing and then again 6 months after result disclosure. At 6 months, only 10 partners reported that they had not been told of the test result. Ninety-one percent reported that the testing had not caused strain on their relationship. Partners who were comfortable sharing concerns before testing experienced less distress after testing. Protective buffering was not found to impact distress levels of partners.[<a href="#cit/section_9.160">

10231160</a>

10232]</p>

10233<p id="_1383" tabindex="-1">

10234An Australian study of 95 unaffected women at high risk of developing breast and/or ovarian cancer (13 carriers of pathogenic variants and 82 with unknown variant status) and their partners showed that although the majority of male partners had distress levels comparable to a normative population sample, 10% had significant levels of distress that indicated the need for further clinical intervention. Men with a high monitoring coping style and greater perceived breast cancer risk for their wives reported higher levels of distress. Open communication between the men and their partners and the occurrence of a cancer-related event in the wife&#8217;s family in the last year were associated with lower distress levels. When men were asked what kind of information and support they would like for themselves and their partners, 57.9% reported that they would like more information about breast and ovarian cancer, and 32.6% said they would like more support in dealing with their partner's risk. Twenty-five percent of men had suggestions on how to improve services for partners of high-risk women, including strategies on how to best support their partner, greater encouragement from health care professionals to attend appointments, and meeting with other partners.[<a href="#cit/section_9.165">

10235165</a>

10236] </p>

10237<p id="_1968" tabindex="-1">

10238A review of this literature reported that the <em class="gene-name">

10239BRCA</em>

10240 testing process may be distressing for male partners, particularly for those with spouses identified as carriers. Male partner distress appears to be associated with their beliefs about the woman&#8217;s breast cancer risk, lack of couple communication, and feelings of alienation from the testing process.[<a href="#cit/section_9.166">

10241166</a>

10242]</p>

10243<section id="_970">

10244<h5 id="_970_toc">

10245At-risk males</h5>

10246<p id="_1573" tabindex="-1">

10247A review of the literature on the experiences of males in families with a known <em class="gene-name">

10248BRCA1</em>

10249 and <em class="gene-name">

10250BRCA2</em>

10251 pathogenic variant reported that while the data are limited, men from variant-positive families are less likely than females to participate in communication regarding genetics at every level, including the counseling and testing process. Men are less likely to be informed of genetic test results received by female relatives, and most men from these families do not pursue their own genetic testing.[<a href="#cit/section_9.167">

10252167</a>

10253]</p>

10254<p id="_633" tabindex="-1">

10255A study of Dutch men at increased risk of having inherited a <em class="gene-name">

10256BRCA1</em>

10257 pathogenic variant reported a tendency for the men to deny or minimize the emotional effects of their risk status, and to focus on medical implications for their female relatives. Men in these families, however, also reported considerable distress in relation to their female relatives.[<a href="#cit/section_9.168">

10258168</a>

10259] In another study of male psychological functioning during breast cancer testing, 28 men belonging to 18 different high-risk families (with a 25% or 50% risk of having inherited a <em class="gene-name">

10260BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10261 pathogenic variant) participated. The study purpose was to analyze distress in males at risk of carrying a <em class="gene-name">

10262BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10263 pathogenic variant who

10264applied for genetic testing. Of the men studied, most had low

10265pretest distress; scores were lowest for men who were optimistic or who did not have daughters. Most carriers of pathogenic variants had normal levels of anxiety and depression and reported no guilt, though some anticipated increased distress and feelings of responsibility if their daughters developed breast or ovarian cancer. None of the noncarriers reported feeling guilty.[<a href="#cit/section_9.169">

10266169</a>

10267] In one study,[<a href="#cit/section_9.163">

10268163</a>

10269] adherence to recommended screening guidelines after testing was analyzed. In this study, more than half of male carriers of pathogenic variants did not adhere to the screening guidelines recommended after disclosure of genetic test results. These findings are consistent with those for female carriers of <em class="gene-name">

10270BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10271 pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_9.163">

10272163</a>

10273,<a href="#cit/section_9.170">

10274170</a>

10275]</p>

10276<p id="_1404" tabindex="-1">

10277A multicenter U.K. cohort study examined prospective outcomes of <em class="gene-name">

10278BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10279 testing in 193 individuals, of which 20% were men aged 28 to 86 years. Men&#8217;s distress levels were low, did not differ among carriers and noncarriers, and did not change from baseline (before genetic testing) to the 3-year follow-up. Twenty-two percent of male carriers of pathogenic variants received colorectal cancer screening and 44% received prostate cancer screening;[<a href="#cit/section_9.124">

10280124</a>

10281] however, it is unclear whether men in this study were following age-appropriate screening guidelines.</p>

10282</section>

10283</section>

10284<section id="_972">

10285<h4 id="_972_toc">

10286Children</h4>

10287<p id="_1405" tabindex="-1">

10288Several studies have explored communication of <em class="gene-name">

10289BRCA</em>

10290 test results to at-risk children. Across all studies, the rate of disclosure to children ranging in age from 4 to 25 years is approximately 50%.[<a href="#cit/section_9.145">

10291145</a>

10292,<a href="#cit/section_9.151">

10293151</a>

10294,<a href="#cit/section_9.154">

10295154</a>

10296,<a href="#cit/section_9.158">

10297158</a>

10298,<a href="#cit/section_9.171">

10299171</a>

10300-<a href="#cit/section_9.174">

10301174</a>

10302] In general, age of offspring was the most important factor in deciding whether to disclose test results. In one study of 31 mothers disclosing their <em class="gene-name">

10303BRCA</em>

10304 test results, 50% of the children who were informed of the results were aged 20 to 29 years and slightly more than 25% of the children were aged 19 years or younger. Sons and daughters were notified in equal numbers.[<a href="#cit/section_9.157">

10305157</a>

10306] Similarly, in another study of 42 female carriers of <em class="gene-name">

10307BRCA</em>

10308 pathogenic variants, 83% of offspring older than age 18 years were told of the results, while only 21% of offspring aged 13 years or younger were told.[<a href="#cit/section_9.158">

10309158</a>

10310] </p>

10311<p id="_1409" tabindex="-1">

10312Several studies have also looked at the timing of disclosure to children after parents receive their test results. Although the majority of children were told within a week to several months after results disclosure,[<a href="#cit/section_9.145">

10313145</a>

10314,<a href="#cit/section_9.157">

10315157</a>

10316,<a href="#cit/section_9.158">

10317158</a>

10318] some parents chose to delay disclosure.[<a href="#cit/section_9.158">

10319158</a>

10320] Reasons for delaying disclosure included waiting for the child to get older, allowing time for the parent to adjust to the information, and waiting until results could be shared in person (in the case of adult children living away from home).[<a href="#cit/section_9.158">

10321158</a>

10322] </p>

10323<p id="_659" tabindex="-1">

10324In one study, participants

10325who told children younger than 13 years about their carrier status had

10326increased distress, and those who did not tell their young children experienced

10327a slight decrease in distress. Communication with young children was found to be influenced by developmental variables such as age and style of parent/child communication.[<a href="#cit/section_9.173">

10328173</a>

10329]</p>

10330<p id="_1406" tabindex="-1">

10331One study looked at the reaction of children to results disclosure or the effect on the parent-child relationship of communicating the results.[<a href="#cit/section_9.158">

10332158</a>

10333] With regard to offspring&#8217;s understanding of the information, almost half of parents from one study reported that their child did not appear to understand the significance of a positive test result, although older children were reported to have a better understanding. This same study also showed that 48% of parents reported at least one negative reaction in their child, ranging from anxiety or concern (22%) to crying and fear (26%). It should be noted, however, that in this study children's level of understanding and reactions to the test result were measured qualitatively and based only on the parents' perception. Also, given the retrospective design of the study, there was a potential for recall bias. There were no significant differences in emotional reaction depending on age or gender of the child. Lastly, 65% of parents reported no change in their relationship with their child, while 5 parents (22%) reported a strengthening of their relationship. </p>

10334<p id="_2978" tabindex="-1">

10335Interestingly, a large multicenter study of 869 mother-daughter pairs (the daughters were aged 6 to 13 y) found that girls with a family history of breast cancer or a familial <em class="gene-name">

10336BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10337 pathogenic variant compared with those without such family histories had better psychosocial adjustment by maternal report.[<a href="#cit/section_9.175">

10338175</a>

10339] However, based on a combination of maternal report and direct assessment of girls aged 10 to 13 years, girls with family histories of breast cancer or familial <em class="gene-name">

10340BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10341 pathogenic variants experienced greater breast cancer&#8211;specific distress and a higher perceived risk of breast cancer than their peers without such family histories. Moreover, higher daughter distress was associated with higher maternal distress. A similarly designed study in older girls, aged 11 to 19 years, found that higher breast cancer&#8211;specific distress in daughters was associated with perceived risk and maternal distress. This older age group had higher self-esteem than did their peers without a family history of breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_9.176">

10342176</a>

10343]</p>

10344<p id="_1407" tabindex="-1">

10345Another study of 187 mothers undergoing <em class="gene-name">

10346BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10347 testing evaluated their need for resources to prepare for a facilitated conversation about sharing their <em class="gene-name">

10348BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10349 testing results with their children. Seventy-eight percent of mothers were interested in three or more resources, including literature (93%), family counseling (86%), talking to prior participants (79%), and support groups (54%).[<a href="#cit/section_9.177">

10350177</a>

10351]</p>

10352<p id="_306" tabindex="-1">

10353Testing for <em class="gene-name">

10354BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10355 has been almost universally limited to adults older than 18

10356years. The risks of testing children for adult-onset disorders (such as breast

10357and ovarian cancer), as inferred from developmental data on children&#8217;s medical

10358understanding and ability to provide informed consent, have been outlined in

10359several reports.[<a href="#cit/section_9.51">

1036051</a>

10361-<a href="#cit/section_9.54">

1036254</a>

10363] Surveys of parental interest in testing children

10364for adult-onset hereditary cancers suggest that parents are more eager to

10365test their children than to be tested themselves for a breast cancer gene,

10366suggesting potential conflicts for providers.[<a href="#cit/section_9.178">

10367178</a>

10368,<a href="#cit/section_9.179">

10369179</a>

10370] In a general population

10371survey in the United States, 71% of parents said that it was moderately, very,

10372or extremely likely that if they carried a breast-cancer predisposing pathogenic variant,

10373they would test a 13-year-old daughter now to determine her breast cancer

10374gene status.[<a href="#cit/section_9.178">

10375178</a>

10376] To date, no data exist on the testing of children for

10377<em class="gene-name">

10378BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10379, though some researchers believe it is necessary to test the validity

10380of assumptions underlying the general prohibition of testing of children for

10381breast/ovarian cancer and other adult-onset disease genes.[<a href="#cit/section_9.57">

1038257</a>

10383-<a href="#cit/section_9.59">

1038459</a>

10385] In one study, 20 children (aged 11&#8211;17 y) of a selected group of mothers undergoing genetic testing (80% of whom previously had breast cancer and all of whom had discussed <em class="gene-name">

10386BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10387 testing with their children) completed self-report questionnaires on their health beliefs and attitudes toward cancer, feelings related to cancer, and behavioral problems.[<a href="#cit/section_9.60">

1038860</a>

10389] Ninety percent of children thought they would want cancer risk information as adults; half worried about themselves or a family member developing cancer. There was no evidence of emotional distress or behavioral problems. Another study by this group [<a href="#cit/section_9.173">

10390173</a>

10391] found that 1 month after disclosure of <em class="gene-name">

10392BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10393 genetic test results, 53% of 42 enrolled mothers of children aged 8 to 17 years had discussed their result with one or more of their children. Age of the child rather than pathogenic variant status of the mother influenced whether they were told, as did family health communication style.</p>

10394</section>

10395<section id="_975">

10396<h4 id="_975_toc">

10397Prenatal diagnosis and preimplantation genetic testing</h4>

10398<p id="_1969" tabindex="-1">

10399The possibility of transmitting a pathogenic variant to a child may pose a concern to families affected by HBOC,[<a href="#cit/section_9.180">

10400180</a>

10401] perhaps to the extent that some carriers may avoid childbearing.[<a href="#cit/section_9.181">

10402181</a>

10403,<a href="#cit/section_9.182">

10404182</a>

10405] These concerns also may prompt women to consider using prenatal testing methods to help reduce the risk of transmission.[<a href="#cit/section_9.180">

10406180</a>

10407,<a href="#cit/section_9.183">

10408183</a>

10409] Prenatal diagnosis is an encompassing term used to refer to any medical procedure conducted to assess the presence of a genetic disorder in a fetus. Methods include amniocentesis and chorionic villous sampling (CVS).[<a href="#cit/section_9.184">

10410184</a>

10411,<a href="#cit/section_9.185">

10412185</a>

10413] Both procedures carry some risk of miscarriage and some evidence suggests fetal defects may result from using these tests.[<a href="#cit/section_9.184">

10414184</a>

10415,<a href="#cit/section_9.185">

10416185</a>

10417] Moreover, discovering the fetus is a carrier for a genetic defect may impose a difficult decision for couples regarding pregnancy continuation or termination. An alternative to these tests is preimplantation genetic testing (PGT), a procedure used to test fertilized embryos for genetic disorders before uterine implantation,[<a href="#cit/section_9.180">

10418180</a>

10419,<a href="#cit/section_9.186">

10420186</a>

10421,<a href="#cit/section_9.187">

10422187</a>

10423] thereby avoiding the potential dangers associated with amniocentesis and CVS and the decision to terminate a pregnancy. Using the information obtained from the genetic testing, potential parents can decide whether or not to implant. PGT can be used to detect pathogenic variants in hereditary cancer predisposing genes, including <em class="gene-name">

10424BRCA</em>

10425.[<a href="#cit/section_9.180">

10426180</a>

10427,<a href="#cit/section_9.183">

10428183</a>

10429]</p>

10430<p id="_1970" tabindex="-1">

10431In the United States, a series of studies has evaluated awareness, interest (e.g., would consider using PGT), and attitudes related to PGT among members of Facing Our Risk of Cancer Empowered (FORCE), an advocacy organization focused on individuals at increased risk of HBOC.[<a href="#cit/section_9.180">

10432180</a>

10433,<a href="#cit/section_9.183">

10434183</a>

10435,<a href="#cit/section_9.188">

10436188</a>

10437] The first study was a web-based survey of 283 members,[<a href="#cit/section_9.180">

10438180</a>

10439] the second included 205 attendees of the 2007 annual FORCE conference,[<a href="#cit/section_9.183">

10440183</a>

10441] and the third was a web-based survey of 962 members.[<a href="#cit/section_9.188">

10442188</a>

10443,<a href="#cit/section_9.189">

10444189</a>

10445] These studies have documented low levels of awareness, with 20% to 32% of study respondents reporting having heard of PGT before study participation.[<a href="#cit/section_9.183">

10446183</a>

10447,<a href="#cit/section_9.188">

10448188</a>

10449] With respect to interest in PGT, the first study [<a href="#cit/section_9.180">

10450180</a>

10451] found only 13% of women would be likely to use PGT, whereas, 33% of respondents in the subsequent FORCE studies reported that they would consider using PGT.[<a href="#cit/section_9.183">

10452183</a>

10453,<a href="#cit/section_9.188">

10454188</a>

10455] In the third FORCE-based study (n = 962),[<a href="#cit/section_9.188">

10456188</a>

10457] multivariable analysis revealed PGT interest was associated with the desire to have more children, having previously had any prenatal genetic test, and previous awareness of PGT. Attitudinal predictors of interest in PGT included agreement that others at risk of HBOC should be offered PGT; the belief that PGT is acceptable for individuals at risk of HBOC; the belief that PGT information should be given to individuals at risk of HBOC; and endorsement of PGT benefits of having children without genetic variants and eliminating genetic diseases. Conversely, those who indicated that PGT was &#8220;too much like playing God&#8221; and reported that they considered PGT in the context of religion, had less interest in PGT.</p>

10458<p id="_2821" tabindex="-1">

10459It is unknown whether the attitudes of FORCE members toward PGT are representative of the majority of <em class="gene-name">

10460BRCA</em>

10461 carriers. A cross-sectional study of 1,081 <em class="gene-name">

10462BRCA</em>

10463 carriers, 65% of whom were recruited through FORCE and the remainder by the University of Pennsylvania, revealed that a majority of carriers were in favor of offering PGT and prenatal diagnosis to carriers (59% for PGT and 55.5% for prenatal diagnosis).[<a href="#cit/section_9.190">

10464190</a>

10465] Of those who indicated that their families were not complete, 41% of <em class="gene-name">

10466BRCA</em>

10467 carriers reported that their carrier status impacted their decision about future biological children. This study also revealed that 21.5% of unpartnered <em class="gene-name">

10468BRCA</em>

10469 carriers felt more pressure to get married. </p>

10470<p id="_1348" tabindex="-1">

10471The U.K. Human Fertilization and Embryology authority has approved the use of PGT for HBOC. In a sample of 102 women with a <em class="gene-name">

10472BRCA</em>

10473 pathogenic variant, most were supportive of PGT but only 38% of the women who had completed their families would consider it for themselves had PGT been available, and only 14% of women who were contemplating a future pregnancy would consider PGT.[<a href="#cit/section_9.191">

10474191</a>

10475] In a study of 77 individuals undergoing <em class="gene-name">

10476BRCA</em>

10477 testing as part of a multicenter cohort study in Spain, 61% of respondents reported they would consider PGT. Factors associated with PGT interest were age 40 years and older and had a prior cancer diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_9.192">

10478192</a>

10479] </p>

10480<p id="_2501" tabindex="-1">

10481In France, couples who obtain authorization from a multidisciplinary prenatal diagnosis team may access PGT free of charge as a benefit of their national

10482health care system. However, no <em class="gene-name">

10483BRCA</em>

10484 carriers have been authorized to use PGT. In a national study of 490 unaffected carriers of <em class="gene-name">

10485BRCA</em>

10486 pathogenic variants of childbearing age (women aged 18&#8211;49 y; men aged 18&#8211;69 y), 16% stated that <em class="gene-name">

10487BRCA</em>

10488 test results had altered their ongoing plans for childbearing.[<a href="#cit/section_9.193">

10489193</a>

10490] Upon qualitative analysis of written comments provided by some respondents,

10491the primary impact was related to accelerating the timing of pregnancy, feelings of guilt about possibly passing on the pathogenic variant to offspring, and having future children. In response to a

10492hypothetical scenario in which PGT was readily available, 33% of participants reported that they would undergo PGT. Factors associated with this intention were having no future reproductive plans at the time of the survey, feeling pregnancy termination was an acceptable option in the context of identifying a <em class="gene-name">

10493BRCA</em>

10494 pathogenic variant, and having fewer cases of breast and/or ovarian cancer in the family. When presented with questions about expectations about delivery of PGT or prenatal diagnosis information, 85% of respondents felt it should be provided along with <em class="gene-name">

10495BRCA</em>

10496 test results; 45% felt that it should be provided when carriers decide to have children. Respondents stated

10497that they would expect this information to be delivered by cancer geneticists (92%), obstetrician/gynecologists (76%), and general practitioners (48%).</p>

10498<p id="_2374" tabindex="-1">

10499A small (N = 25) qualitative study of women of reproductive age positive for a <em class="gene-name">

10500BRCA</em>

10501 pathogenic variant who underwent genetic testing before having children evaluated how their <em class="gene-name">

10502BRCA</em>

10503 status influenced their attitudes about reproductive genetic testing (both PGT and prenatal diagnosis) and decisions about having children.[<a href="#cit/section_9.194">

10504194</a>

10505] In this study, the decision to undergo <em class="gene-name">

10506BRCA</em>

10507 testing was primarily motivated by the desire to manage one&#8217;s personal cancer risk, rather than a desire to inform future reproductive decisions. The perceived severity of HBOC influenced concerns about passing on a <em class="gene-name">

10508BRCA</em>

10509 pathogenic variant to children and also influenced willingness to consider PGT or prenatal diagnosis. Decisions about PGT and prenatal diagnosis also varied based on the participant's personal experiences. Most did not believe that a known <em class="gene-name">

10510BRCA</em>

10511 pathogenic variant was a reason to terminate a pregnancy. As observed in prior studies, knowledge of reproductive options varied; however, there was a tendency among participants to view PGT as more acceptable than prenatal diagnosis with regard to termination of

10512pregnancy. Decisions regarding the pros and cons of PGT versus prenatal diagnosis with termination of pregnancy were driven primarily by personal preferences and experiences, rather than by morality judgments. For example, women were deterred from PGT based on the need to undergo <em>

10513in vitro</em>

10514 fertilization and to take hormones that might increase cancer risk and based on the observed

10515experiences of others who underwent this procedure.</p>

10516<p id="_2326" tabindex="-1">

10517One study has examined these issues among high-risk men recruited from FORCE and Craigslist (a bulletin board website) (N = 228).[<a href="#cit/section_9.195">

10518195</a>

10519] Similar to the previous studies of women, only 20% of men were aware of PGT before survey participation. In a multivariate analysis, those who selected the &#8220;other&#8221; option for possible benefits of PGT compared with those who selected from several predetermined options (e.g., having children without genetic variants) and those who considered PGT in the context of

10520religion (as opposed to health and safety) were less likely to report that they would ever consider using PGT.</p>

10521</section>

10522</section>

10523<section id="_308">

10524<h3 id="_308_toc">

10525Cultural/Community Effects</h3>

10526<p id="_309" tabindex="-1">

10527The recognition that <em class="gene-name">

10528BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10529 pathogenic variants are prevalent, not only in

10530breast/ovarian cancer families but also in some ethnic groups,[<a href="#cit/section_9.196">

10531196</a>

10532] has led to

10533considerable discussion of the ethical, psychological, and other implications of

10534having one&#8217;s ethnicity be a factor in determination of disease predisposition.

10535Concerns that people will think everything is solely determined by genetic factors and the creation of a genetic underclass [<a href="#cit/section_9.197">

10536197</a>

10537]

10538have been voiced. Questions about the impact on the group of being singled out

10539as having genetic vulnerability to breast cancer have been raised. There is

10540also confusion about who gives or withholds permission for the group to be

10541involved in studies of their genetic identity. These issues challenge

10542traditional views on informed consent as a function of individual autonomy.[<a href="#cit/section_9.198">

10543198</a>

10544]

10545 </p>

10546<p id="_791" tabindex="-1">

10547A growing literature on the unique factors influencing a variety of cultural subgroups suggests the importance of developing culturally specific genetic counseling and educational approaches.[<a href="#cit/section_9.100">

10548100</a>

10549,<a href="#cit/section_9.199">

10550199</a>

10551-<a href="#cit/section_9.203">

10552203</a>

10553] The inclusion of members within the community of interest (e.g., breast cancer survivors, advocates, and community leaders) may enhance the development of culturally tailored genetic counseling materials.[<a href="#cit/section_9.101">

10554101</a>

10555] One study showed that participation in any genetic counseling (culturally mediated or standard approaches) reduced perceived risk of developing breast cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_9.204">

10556204</a>

10557]</p>

10558</section>

10559<section id="_310">

10560<h3 id="_310_toc">

10561Ethical Concerns </h3>

10562<p id="_311" tabindex="-1">

10563The human implications of the ethical issues raised by the advent of genetic

10564testing for breast/ovarian cancer susceptibility are described in case studies,[<a href="#cit/section_9.205">

10565205</a>

10566] essays,[<a href="#cit/section_9.206">

10567206</a>

10568,<a href="#cit/section_9.207">

10569207</a>

10570] and research reports. Issues about rights and

10571responsibilities in families concerning the spread of information about genetic

10572risk promise to be major ethical and legal dilemmas in the coming decades.

10573</p>

10574<p id="_312" tabindex="-1">

10575Studies have shown that 62% of studied family members were aware of the family

10576history and that 88% of hereditary breast/ovarian cancer family members

10577surveyed have significant concerns about privacy and confidentiality.

10578Concern about cancer in third-degree relatives, or relatives further

10579removed, did not differ from concern about cancer in the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460211&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460211&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

10580proband's </a>

10581 FDRs or SDRs.[<a href="#cit/section_9.208">

10582208</a>

10583] Only half of surveyed FDRs of women with

10584breast or ovarian cancer felt that written permission should be required to

10585disclose <em class="gene-name">

10586BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10587 test results to a spouse or immediate family member.

10588Attitudes toward testing varied by ethnicity, previous exposure to genetic

10589information, age, optimism, and information style. Altruism is a factor

10590motivating genetic testing in some people.[<a href="#cit/section_9.209">

10591209</a>

10592] Many

10593professional groups have made recommendations regarding informed

10594consent.[<a href="#cit/section_9.113">

10595113</a>

10596,<a href="#cit/section_9.209">

10597209</a>

10598-<a href="#cit/section_9.212">

10599212</a>

10600] There is some evidence that not all practitioners are

10601aware of or follow these guidelines.[<a href="#cit/section_9.213">

10602213</a>

10603] Research shows that many <em class="gene-name">

10604BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10605

10606genetic testing consent forms do not fulfill recommendations by professional

10607groups about the 11 areas that should be addressed,[<a href="#cit/section_9.214">

10608214</a>

10609] and they omit highly

10610relevant points of information.[<a href="#cit/section_9.213">

10611213</a>

10612] In a study of women with a history of breast or ovarian cancer, the interviews yielded that the women reported feeling inadequately prepared for the ethical dilemmas they encountered when imparting genetic information to family members.[<a href="#cit/section_9.215">

10613215</a>

10614] These data suggest that more preparation about disclosure to family members before testing reduces the emotional burden of disseminating genetic information to family members. Patients and health care providers would benefit from enhanced consideration of the ethical issues of warning family members about hereditary cancer risk. (Refer to the PDQ summaries <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/risk-assessment-pdq#_240">

10615Cancer Genetics Risk Assessment and Counseling</a>

10616 and <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/overview-pdq#_31">

10617Cancer Genetics Overview</a>

10618 for more information about the ethics of cancer genetics and genetic testing.)

10619</p>

10620</section>

10621<section id="_313">

10622<h3 id="_313_toc">

10623Psychosocial Aspects of Cancer Risk Management for Hereditary Breast and Gynecologic Cancers</h3>

10624<section id="_1503">

10625<h4 id="_1503_toc">

10626Decision aids for individuals considering risk management options for hereditary breast and gynecologic cancers</h4>

10627<p id="_1504" tabindex="-1">

10628There is a small but growing body of literature on the use of decision aids as an adjunct to standard genetic counseling to assist patients in making informed decisions about cancer risk management.[<a href="#cit/section_9.216">

10629216</a>

10630-<a href="#cit/section_9.220">

10631220</a>

10632] One study showed that the use of a decision aid consisting of individualized value assessment and cancer risk management information after receiving positive <em class="gene-name">

10633BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10634 test results was associated with fewer intrusive thoughts and lower levels of depression at the 6-month follow-up in unaffected women. Use of the decision aid did not alter cancer risk management intentions and behaviors. Slightly detrimental effects on well-being and several decision-related outcomes, however, were noted among affected women.[<a href="#cit/section_9.218">

10635218</a>

10636]

10637Another study compared responses to a tailored decision aid (including a values-clarification exercise) versus a general information pamphlet intended for women making decisions about ovarian cancer risk management. In the short term, the women receiving the tailored decision aid showed a decrease in decisional conflict and increased knowledge compared with women receiving the pamphlet, but no differences in decisional outcomes were found between the two groups. In addition, the decision aid did not appear to alter the participant&#8217;s baseline cancer risk management decisions.[<a href="#cit/section_9.217">

10638217</a>

10639] A multisite randomized trial of 150 unaffected women with <em class="gene-name">

10640BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10641 pathogenic variants assessed the effect of a decision aid on breast cancer risk management decisions and psychosocial outcomes. At 6-month and 12-month follow-up, women randomly assigned to the decision aid had lower levels of cancer-related distress (<em>

10642P</em>

10643 = .01 at 6 months and <em>

10644P</em>

10645 = .05 at 12 months) than did the control group.[<a href="#cit/section_9.220">

10646220</a>

10647] Decisional conflict scores were relatively low at baseline and declined over time in both groups; the scores between the two groups were not statistically different.</p>

10648</section>

10649<section id="_1519">

10650<h4 id="_1519_toc">

10651Uptake of cancer risk management options</h4>

10652<p id="_1506" tabindex="-1">

10653An increasing number of studies have examined uptake and adherence to cancer risk management options among individuals who have undergone genetic counseling and testing for <em class="gene-name">

10654BRCA1</em>

10655 and <em class="gene-name">

10656BRCA2</em>

10657 pathogenic variants. Findings from these studies are reported in <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2613">

10658Table 9</a>

10659 and <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2614">

10660Table 10</a>

10661. Outcomes vary across studies and include uptake or adherence to screening (mammography, magnetic resonance imaging [MRI], cancer antigen&#8211;125 [CA-125], transvaginal ultrasound [TVUS]) and selection of RRM and RRSO. Studies generally report outcomes by pathogenic variant carrier or testing status (e.g., positive for pathogenic variants, negative for pathogenic variants, or declined genetic testing). Follow-up time after notification of genetic risk status also varied across studies, ranging from 12 months up to several years.</p>

10662<p id="_1522" tabindex="-1">

10663Findings from these studies suggest that breast screening often improves after notification of <em class="gene-name">

10664BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10665 pathogenic variant carrier status; nonetheless, screening remains suboptimal. Fewer studies have examined adoption of MRI as a screening modality, probably due to the recent availability of efficacy data. Screening for ovarian cancer varied widely across studies, and also varied based on type of screening test (i.e., CA-125 serum testing vs. TVUS screening). However, ovarian cancer screening does not appear to be widely adopted by carriers of <em class="gene-name">

10666BRCA1/BRCA2</em>

10667 pathogenic variants. Uptake of RRM varied widely across studies and may be influenced by personal factors (such as younger age or having a family history of breast cancer), psychosocial factors (such as a desire for reduction of cancer-related distress), recommendations of the health care provider, and cultural or health care system factors. An individual&#8217;s choice to have a bilateral mastectomy also appears to be influenced by pretreatment genetic education and counseling regardless of the genetic test results.[<a href="#cit/section_9.221">

10668221</a>

10669] Similarly, uptake of RRSO also varied across studies, and may be influenced by similar factors, including older age, personal history of breast cancer, perceived risk of ovarian cancer, cultural factors (i.e., country), and the recommendations of the health care provider.</p>

10670<table id="_2613" class="table-default expandable-container">

10671<caption>

10672Table 9. Uptake of Risk-reducing Mastectomy (RRM) and/or Breast Screening Among Carriers of <em class="gene-name">

10673BRCA1</em>

10674 and <em class="gene-name">

10675BRCA2</em>

10676 Pathogenic Variants</caption>

10677<colgroup>

10678<col width="16.66%">

10679<col width="16.66%">

10680<col width="16.66%">

10684</colgroup>

10890<tr>

10891<td>

10892&#8211; Carriers unaffected 46%

10893</td>

10894</tr>

10895<tr>

10896<td>

10897&#8211; Noncarriers 11%

10898</td>

10899</tr>

10900<tr>

10901<td>

10902&#8211; Uninformative 27%

10903</td>

10904</tr>

10905<tr>

10906<td rowspan="5">

10907Garcia et al. (2013) [<a href="#cit/section_9.226">

10908226</a>

11587236</a>

11591a</span>

11592;

11594</td>

11599</td>

11604Affected with breast cancer</strong>

11605</td>

11612</tr>

11613<tr>

11614<td>

11615<em class="gene-name">

11617carriers:</td>

11618<td rowspan="2">

11619&#8211; <em class="gene-name">

11620BRCA1</em>

11622Mean, 2.29; range, 0.1&#8211;11.45 y </td>

11627</td>

11630<td rowspan="2">

11631All carriers with no personal history of breast cancer

11634&#8211; <em class="gene-name">

11635BRCA2</em>

11636:

11637Mean, 1.77; range, 0.1&#8211;11.1 y</td>

11638</tr>

11640<td rowspan="2">

11641<strong>

11642Not affected with breast cancer</strong>

11643</td>
